The ORGANIZATION took PERSON out of GPE State with the hopes he'd be one of those advanced college lefties who could fly through their system. He hasn't disappointed on that front, reaching Triple-A in his first full season. He's not going to wow you with pure stuff and there isn't a ton of projection there, but he has an advanced feel and four pitches to work with. He pitches to contact, and can work his average fastball to both sides of the plate. His slider is the better of his two breaking balls, with late downward tilt and bite. His above-average changeup is plus at times, with good fade. His ceiling is somewhat limited, but he's not far from being ready to step in as a middle-of-the-rotation type in the big leagues.

PERSON was only throwing in the low-80s as a high school junior, but his velocity spiked later in the year and he threw much harder the following year. He now sits in the low-90s. PERSON also has a sizeable frame and can spin it. He signed for a well-over slot $540,000 as a 6th rounder. He's a really high variance prospect because the velocity is fairly new and might keep coming.

The ORGANIZATION have liked PERSON' offensive potential ever since they scouted him at ORGANIZATION leading up to the 2012 PERSON. But ever since they took him with the 45th overall pick in that June's PERSON, they've had a hard time watching him develop, as injuries have largely kept him off of the field. He was relatively healthy in 2015 and managed to reach Double-A for the first time.PERSON has always shown an ability to hit. The lack of reps means his approach is still a bit raw, but he's not clueless at the plate, with some pitch and strike zone recognition. He has plus bat speed that should lead to more power than he's shown thus far. Despite numerous leg injuries, PERSON still runs well and can steal a base. He's bounced around the outfield and seeing more time in the corners may have taken away some of the demands of playing center field on a daily basis. He'll probably end up in a corner full-time in the future, likely left due to a fringy arm.More than anything, PERSON has learned what he needs to do to keep his body intact and on the field. He'll have to continue to show he can stay healthy to succeed at the upper levels of the system.

As big of a surprise as it may have been to most when the ORGANIZATION took PERSON out of PERSON in the first round of the 2015 Draft, it may have been an even bigger shock that he hit his way to full-season ball and finished with a combined .348 average and .895 OPS during his pro debut.PERSON's advanced approach at the plate is what really sticks out. He never chases out of the zone, allowing him to draw 16 more walks than times he struck out (23). He is focused more on line-drive contact than power right now, but he does have some bat speed and he should be able to learn how to turn on some balls in hitter's counts as he progresses. PERSON's best defensive attribute is his plus arm, one that can control the running game, especially as he cleans up his release. The other parts of his receiving need some work, especially his game-calling skills, something he didn't have to work on in college.The industry may have seen PERSON more as a future backup initially, but if he can continue on the trajectory he started during his opening summer, PERSON has the chance to be a big league regular behind the plate.

PERSON is going to strike out but he has above-average pull power that he's learning to tap into in games, runs well, and should be fine at third. He has a plus arm (accuracy is sometimes an issue) and is comfortable charging slow rollers on the grass, but, generally, he is not especially polished there. PERSON hasn't played third base full-time for all that long and he should be average there at peak. He profiles as an average regular and should get plenty of playing time in 2018.

PERSON hit everywhere he'd ever played before a surprising summer slump with the GPE collegiate national team. It carried over to a slow start during his junior year at ORGANIZATION, though he turned it up a notch and went back to showing an ability to swing the bat well, enabling him to climb into the first round and sign for full pick value with the Orioles.Some felt PERSON was one of the best bats in the 2015 college class. He was named the 2014 ORGANIZATION of the Year as a sophomore, after leading the league in all three slash stats at .351/.472/.557. PERSON has a quick left-handed stroke, strength and patience. He has plus raw power but he doesn't fully tap into it because he bats from an extreme crouch and has a flat swing. He might hit 20 homers per season if he stands more upright and adds some loft. A better athlete than his build might indicate, he was an all-state running back in high school. He has close to average speed. He has good instincts as a runner and defender, though a below-average arm limits him to left field.

PERSON's strikeout rate exploded from 16% in 2017 to nearly 29% in 2018. The cause? A slight uptick in velocity paired with an arm slot change that has PERSON coming straight over the top, creating more life on his heater. It also creates more vertical action on his breaking stuff. This delivery appears tough to maintain, as PERSON has to contort his body to get to that slot, but he hasn't been wild since making the change. His well-rounded collection of stuff plays much better like this, and PERSON now projects as a No. 4 or 5 starter.

PERSON was billed as an advanced college bat coming out of ORGANIZATION, and he looked the part in his first full professional season. He advanced to Double-A Springfield, and he ended the year with a strong showing in the ORGANIZATION. PERSON has continued to rake at ORGANIZATION Memphis this season.PERSON has a mature approach at the plate, and he has the chance to be a .300 hitter in the ORGANIZATION. His swing is more geared toward hitting line drives than home runs, but he should be able to supply average power along with his high average. After playing primarily third base at ORGANIZATION, PERSON was moved to right field by the Cardinals in 2013. He handled the transition well, improving as the season went on. PERSON has a strong arm and covers ground capably.PERSON has hit everywhere he's gone, and his polish could have him in the ORGANIZATION soon.

GPE and projectable when he signed for $140,000 as a ORGANIZATION high schooler in the ninth round of the 2012 Draft, PERSON needed time to adapt to pro ball. He led the Minors with 17 losses in 2014 but his stuff kicked up a notch even while he was going 2-9 in the second half. He moved up a level in 2015 and was part of the three-team deal that sent him and PERSON, among others, to GPE in return for PERSON, PERSON and others.After working in the low 90s and topping out at 95 mph with his fastball, PERSON began dealing in the mid-90s and threatening triple digits. His heater has late life, too. He's still developing consistency with his secondary pitches, though his slider can reach the mid-80s with nice bit at times. PERSON doesn't display as much feel for his offspeed pitches. He's a good athlete but his delivery can get stiff and his control suffers as a result. Though he still has a long way to go to make it as a starter, the progress he made at the end of last year is encouraging.

Between his lack of reps during the '16-'17 Series Nacional in GPE and the arduous process of defecting, followed by slowly working out for teams, then waiting for the 2018 season to start, PERSON played very little baseball for the several months leading up to last season and it showed when he finally put on a uniform. The 20-year-old was given an assignment that matched his loud tools (teams who saw him work out were putting 6's and 7's on his speed, arm, and defense at short) but not his readiness, and he was bad early in the year at Low-A Dayton. He came on, statistically, at the end of the year, but didn't walk much in either phase. Latin GPE players who have spent their entire lives playing ball back home, or in GPE or GPE, sometimes struggle with the early-April chill of the ORGANIZATION when they're first assigned there; as if being 20 in a full-season league after not playing for over a year wasn't enough, PERSON may have struggled with this. 2019 should be a more representative sample statistically of what PERSON is. There's no question about his run, field or throw tools, and he was seen at a bat-first prospect early in his GPE career, so that might be in there, too. If he can develop some confidence around his offense, PERSON could quickly jump into 50 FV territory, which is where we had him last year based on how he worked out for teams. He signed for $5 million.

A 2011 Little League World Series star, GPE entered the season as a legitimate two-way talent. While he still pitches for his ORGANIZATION team, his bat took off early this spring, leaving no question that he will be taken in June as a hitter.GPE has positioned himself as perhaps the best pure high school bat in the country. He's always shown an advanced approach at the plate and the ability to hit for average. What's allowed him to separate from the rest of the class is the added power he showed early this season, though his bat did tail off later on in the spring. GPE isn't the biggest guy in the world, but he should have at least average in-game power in the future, using his feel for hitting to punish mistakes consistently. GPE is a plus defender at first, with better range than your average first baseman and an above-average arm that throws upper-80s fastballs off the mound.An outstanding competitor who has been on the mound for key international games as part of ORGANIZATION USA, few doubt GPE's ability to maximize his tools. High school first base-only types can be a tough profile -- PERSON and PERSON are the biggest success stories, but GPE isn't as big. Most believe in GPE's bat enough, though, to take the LOCATION commit early in the first round.Prospect Development PERSON - PERSON, GPE.

There were high hopes for PERSON in 2015, as the ORGANIZATION jumped the right-hander with outstanding stuff and an advanced feel for pitching from the Class A Short-Season New York-Penn League up to the Class A Advanced PERSON. Elbow issues hampered him when he was on the mound, then forced him off the mound for much of the season. PERSON surgery sidelined PERSON for all of 2016.When healthy, PERSON throws his fastball up to 94 mph with really good life. He'll combine that with a solid breaking ball and an average changeup to give him three average to above-average offerings, along with the ability to command all of them. PERSON will throw his slider for strikes and miss bats with it, showing good depth with the pitch when he's throwing it right. He has confidence in his changeup, throwing it in all counts and to both sides of the plate. PERSON has posted a miniscule walk rate of six percent.PERSON should get back on a mound at some point this summer, with every expectation that he'll get back to being the starting pitching prospect he was before his injury.

PERSON hit .413 at ORGANIZATION's River (Fla.) CC as a sophomore in 2015 and impressed the ORGANIZATION in a pre-Draft workout, so they took him in the 12th round and signed him for $100,000. After a mediocre pro debut, he spent the first six weeks of 2016 in extended spring training but went on to win the ORGANIZATION League batting title with a .358 average. He has continued to hit in 2017, challenging for the batting lead in the high Class A ORGANIZATION League.A right-handed hitter, PERSON utilizes an extreme opposite-field approach and has a knack for placing balls where fielders can't get them. He has turned on a few more pitches this year but is still specializing in serving line drives to right field. The tradeoff is that he doesn't produce much power, so much of his offensive value comes from his ability to control the strike zone, make contact and get on base.PERSON's best pure tool is his well-above-average speed, which he's doing a better job of translating into stolen bases. He's a legitimate center fielder with enough range and arm strength to play anywhere in the outfield.

ORGANIZATION has destroyed GPE high school pitching the past three seasons while leading PERSON to an unprecedented three straight 5-A state championships. He batted a combined .516/.618/1.126 with 54 homers and 202 RBIs in 121 games. He even pitched as a senior and threw a two-hit shutout in the state semifinals.Some veteran area scouts say that ORGANIZATION has the best bat speed they've ever seen. Combined with the strength in his 230-pound frame, it gives him considerable power to all fields. He has a sound right-handed swing, and the ball makes a different sound when it comes off his bat.Also a center in football, ORGANIZATION shed 30 pounds before his final baseball season. He runs well for his size and has some arm strength, though he likely will be limited to first base. The GPE recruit draws physical comparisons to PERSON and PERSON, and he should be a better defender than either.

ORGANIZATION Premier Event: Jan. 28, 2017 - PERSON, Fla.Favorite MLB Team: PERSON ORGANIZATION MLB Player: PERSON StromanAs a 2016 ORGANIZATION participant and an ORGANIZATION First Team All-American, PERSON shows plenty of promise. While he committed to the ORGANIZATION State PERSON, he also had plenty of interest from GPE as well.The lean middle infielder has a smooth glove and moves swiftly in the field. He is light on his feet and plays the game with energy. His body lacks ideal strength at this time, but he flashes ability to square up on fastballs on occasion.Overall, PERSON's tools, body and bat profile project as a future utility PERSON role.

Though PERSON shows no signs of ever slowing down, the ORGANIZATION invested in a pair of promising young third-base prospects in 2016. After signing PERSON for $675,000 as a third-round pick in June, they landed PERSON three months later for $1.1 million. He played two seasons in GPE's top league as a teenager, batting a combined .259/.335/.328.Like PERSON, PERSON doesn't have one standout tool but does possess the potential to contribute across the board. His raw right-handed power attracted the most attention from scouts, and he has the approach and hitting ability to translate it into game production. His speed reportedly has improved since he left GPE, with some evaluators now giving it above-average or plus grades.PERSON played five positions in GPE's PERSON: third base, first base, second base, right field and left field. He has average arm strength and should have enough quickness to stay at the hot corner. If he can't handle third base, the outfield corners are his likely next destination.

GPE, ultra-competitive righty with a nasty hook. PERSON will touch 96 but mostly pitches in the low-90s with tailing action. He has more reliever risk than the pitchers ranked above him due to his delivery and scouts' concerns about command.

PERSON was a starter at FACILITY and threw a no-hitter to beat ORGANIZATION and PERSON in 2011. He has battled injuries throughout his career and underwent PERSON surgery in 2010. His health issues scared teams again on the eve of the 2011 Draft when he was pulled from his start in the ORGANIZATION after one inning because of elbow and back discomfort. PERSON has PERSON stuff when he's healthy and could be a starter. His injury history, however, makes him a better fit in the bullpen, where his power arsenal makes him a potential high-impact reliever. PERSON throws his fastball in the upper-90s and mixes it with a solid slider and changeup. He reached Double-A Richmond this year and is moving quickly toward PERSON.

There's a lot for scouts to like about PERSON.Scouts say he can really run and play defense. Yes, PERSON has a slight frame, and there are some questions about his bat going forward, but he's the type of player teams want in their Minor League system.PERSON has shown quick feet, good hands, and a strong arm on defense. Scouts like his instincts and knack for getting to balls.In the batter's box, PERSON has proven to be a line-drive hitter while displaying some plate discipline. Some scouts do wonder about his power potential. There's no doubt that he will have to get stronger and become more physical as he matures. PERSON, who played in the ORGANIZATION, signed a $2 million deal with the ORGANIZATION.

PERSON signed for $1 million out of GPE in 2017. He can really pick it at shortstop and could be plus there at maturity. His hands, range, actions, footwork, and athleticism are all superlative, especially considering his age, and while he is phsyically projectable, he's not so big-framed that he's a threat to move off shortstop. PERSON's defensive ability was in place when he arrived for camp in the spring. By the start of the summer, he had already filled out a bit and started putting a serious charge into the baseball during BP and, occasionally, in games. That thump tapered off later in the year and PERSON has some swing length issues that will likely make him strikeout prone, but it's possible he was just tired in GPE and that there's some pop here, too. It's unlikely that he has a well-rounded, impact profile on offense, but he could be a plus glove at short who also runs into 15-plus bombs if that power develops.

Thought to be the kind of college reliever who would make a beeline to the big leagues, PERSON, the former closer at GPE, hit a stumbling block in 2015 in Double-A. He was able to right himself and pitch across three levels in 2016, then has repeated his dominance in Triple-A in 2017. Aside from that hiccup, PERSON has been a dominant short reliever with a very high strikeout rate. He does it with a fastball that sits in the mid-to-upper 90s with a ton of life and an above-average slider that is unhittable at times. His changeup is clearly his third pitch, and he's started using it more and throwing it with splitter action. He can miss bats with all three offerings and has shown he can throw multiple innings without losing any of his stuff. PERSON continues to learn how to prepare himself to pitch every night and maintain his strength for the entire season. He's just about ready to impact the big league bullpen, with the ceiling to close games at the highest level if he can continue to throw enough strikes.

The enigmatic lefty came to the Rays from the Royals in the big PERSON trade. The stuff has, and continues to be there for PERSON, but the results haven't. He was demoted in 2012 and still struggled in Double-A. Perhaps a change of scenery will help, as PERSON still has the potential to throw three above-average pitches with his fastball, slider and changeup. His curve gives him a fourth Major League average pitch. More than anything, his issues have been command and delivery-related. If the Rays can get him straightened out, he still has the tools to be one of the better young left-handers in the game.Bernie PERSON's scouting report

The ORGANIZATION got a 10th-round steal when they went to the LOCATION for a college reliever in GPE in 2007, and they may have done so again with PERSON. Signed for $100,000 in 2016, he has dominated more in pro ball than he ever did at FACILITY State JC or PERSON. He reached Double-A a little more than a year after making his pro debut.PERSON had a 90-93 mph fastball when he turned pro but now deals at 93-95 and tops out at 97. He throws from a low arm slot that adds life and angle to his pitches, and he's tough on both left-handers and right-handers with both his heater and his improved slider. He'll occasionally dust off his changeup but works primarily off his fastball and slider.PERSON entered pro ball with average control and that has improved as well. He's repeating his delivery more consistently and locating his pitches with more precision. At this rate, he should arrive in GPE at some point in 2018.

After PERSON came out of the ORGANIZATION of GPE and dominated both in his pro debut and in the ORGANIZATION in 2014, he looked poised to get to GPE in a hurry. His trip was delayed when he scuffled with a move to Double-A in 2015, though he righted the ship with a bounce-back 2016 season that saw him reach Triple-A for the first time. However, his progress was slowed by a shoulder strain that forced him out for the first two months of the 2017 season.With renewed confidence and a more streamlined delivery that was consistently online, PERSON had better results. His velocity ticked upward, sitting consistently in the 94-96 mph range and thrown with good movement to get ground-ball outs. His slider also improved and he continues to refine it. He actually has shown glimpses of a decent changeup, but he doesn't use it enough. His command got better, thanks to his online delivery. He can still get under the ball at times with too much of a low-3/4 slot, which impacts both his command and the quality of his pitches.Hard-throwing right-handed relievers are becoming a depth position for the ORGANIZATION farm system and PERSON once again looks like he belongs in the group that will help out in GPE soon.

GPE throws hard for his age, sitting in the low-90s and bumping up against 95. He's short but not small and sturdily built, quelling concerns about his durability but propagating ones about his fastball's projection. He garners swings and misses with the curveball and GPE's changeup has significant projection because his arm action is so efficient. Like many GPE prospects, GPE's cultural influence is apparent in GPE's efficient and consistent delivery.

A tiny speedster, PERSON's build is relatively unprojectable, but one can still project on most of his skills because he was only taught baseball's basics while growing up in GPE, and hasn't been switch-hitting for very long. His game has some coherent small-ball elements already, as he took  quickly to bunting and putting awkward contact into play, which, because of his speed, enables him to reach against bad low-level defenses. 
There's so little power here that PERSON likely projects as a fourth outfielder, but his feel for contact is impressive for someone of his background and seemingly insufficient physicality, and if he ends up with a 6 or 7 bat, we might be talking about a regular.

PERSON threw a shutout to win the title game of the heavily scouted 2015 World Wood Bat Association World Championship showcase, but his polish stood out more than his stuff. That contributed to him going undrafted the following June, as did his commitment to GPE. He still fits the same profile in 2019, but three years of success as a member of a weekend rotation in the LOCATION should get him picked in the first four or five rounds.PERSON lacks a true plus pitch, but he has several effective offerings and there's no clear consensus as to which is his best. Though his fastball velocity is nothing special at 88-91 mph and a peak of 93, his heater plays up because he sinks and commands it so well, and it works well in concert with his changeup that features similar movement. He has improved his curveball this year, and both it and his slider/cutter can be solid pitches.Without overpowering stuff, PERSON has little margin for error and thrives by limiting his mistakes. He has tremendous feel for locating, manipulating and sequencing his pitches, and he tossed complete-game shutouts against two of the ORGANIZATION's better clubs (ORGANIZATION and GPE) this spring. He tunnels his offerings well, adding to his deception and his chances of becoming a No. 4 or 5 starter.

PERSON was one of the better left-handed pitching prospects in the game and was on the fast track when he went down with an elbow injury that resulted in PERSON surgery. He made it back at the very end of the 2012 season and all signs point to him continuing on his journey to the big leagues. When healthy, he has the chance to have four pitches average or better, all of which play up because of his outstanding command and control. The success rate post-TJ surgery is excellent, so there's no reason PERSON can't live up to the potential people thought he had pre-injury.

PERSON, the product of the ORGANIZATION of GPE, went straight to the Class A Advanced Caliifornia League for his full-season debut and not only held his own, he topped the organization in strikeouts. He did that while posting a walk rate below 2.0, impressive for a pitcher with this much arm strength. PERSON cranks his fastball up to 97 mph at times and his heater has late cutting movement. His secondary stuff is behind the plus fastball, but he'll show glimpses of a good curve. He needs to keep his arm speed with his changeup consistent, especially if he wants to be an effective starting pitcher at the highest level. As is often the case, the next step up to Double-A should help determine just what kind of prospect he is.

PERSON would have been an elite college player with top-5 round abilty both as a hitter and pitcher, but most scouts preferred him on the mound. He was used unusually during his senior spring, and some scouts think within 12 months in a pro setting he could be 90-93 with everything average to above. But tis ounds like PERSON blew the ORGANIZATION away in a private workout and he might instead be deployed, full time, as an outfielder in pro ball.

A former ORGANIZATION World Series star, PERSON has put some medical issues behind him to emerge as one of the better two-way players in the GPE class. PERSON had some arm issues and a disorder known as thoracic outlet syndrome, but surgery corrected that, and he performed well over the summer, from the ORGANIZATION to the ORGANIZATION, PERSON and the ORGANIZATION Games.At the plate, he can put on a show in batting practice with a quiet swing that makes it look easy. He was better as a pitcher at times this summer, particularly at the ORGANIZATION Games, where he was up to 92 mph from the left side, with a put-away breaking ball. PERSON continued to look at him on both sides of the ball, and his performance on the mound was a bit inconsistent. But with that kind of raw stuff from a lefty, it shouldn't shock anyone if his future is on the mound.

PERSON was diagnosed with an elbow tear during his senior year at GPE (Ill.) High in 2012, but the ORGANIZATION gambled on him in the 15th round of the ORGANIZATION and lured him away from a commitment to GPE with a $426,000 bonus. The left-hander ended up needing PERSON surgery and missed the entire 2013 season, but he pitched well the following year, logging 57 innings between Rookie-level Bluefield and Class A Short PERSON. Unfortunately, injuries derailed what was supposed to be his first full campaign in 2015, when he experienced elbow soreness early in the season and was shut down in July with shoulder pain. PERSON has showed his pre-surgery stuff when healthy, highlighted by an 88-92 mph fastball that peaks at 94 and consistently plays up due to his deceptive delivery and long arms. His changeup is a plus pitch for which he's long demonstrated feel, while his breaking ball still needs more work. PERSON has cleaned up his delivery since being drafted and knows how to pound the zone with his entire arsenal. He has the ingredients to develop into a back-end starter, but, for now, it's more important that he stay healthy and gain experience.

GPE had been injury free since college (when he dealt with shoulder problems), until 2018, when he had hamstring issues in the spring, and biceps tendinitis later in the summer. The lost innings resulted in an ORGANIZATION stint, during which GPE was arguably the best non-Whitley pitching prospect who was a lock to start. Despite the biceps issue, his velocity was fine in the fall. GPE sits 93-96 and makes heavy use of three good secondary pitches. The horizontal action on his slider only plays away from righties, but the curveball and changeup will help mitigate some of those issues, as well as the platoon issues that may arise from GPE's lower arm slot.

A two-sport star in high school, PERSON's pro baseball career was in doubt for a moment when the GPE discovered a stress fracture in his back during his physical after the draft. After the issue was resolved, PERSON took things slow for a while at the GPE complex in GPE, limited to activities like ORGANIZATION while others played in actual games. The sound of the ball off his bat during those ORGANIZATION side sessions was very distracting. PERSON stayed in GPE during the spring of 2017 and was much more physical than most of his ORGANIZATION peers. PERSON had statistical success there and in the ORGANIZATION League the following spring, before finally scuffling at Hi-A. 
Though he has above-average raw power, PERSON's in-game cut is more contact-oriented, geared for contact to the opposite field and back up the middle. During instructional league, PERSON was awkwardly swinging without a stride, likely not a swing change, but perhaps an exercise that forces him to clear his hips and improve his ability to pull the ball with power. There's a non-zero chance PERSON stays in center field but it's more likely that he moves to a corner. He has the physical ability to profile as a regular there.

The son of former big league pitcher PERSON and brother of the ORGANIZATION' PERSON, PERSON has moved slowly and steadily, one level at a time, up the ORGANIZATION' organizational ladder ever since he was taken as the ORGANIZATION. 5 overall pick in the 2014 Draft. His move to the upper levels of the system in 2017 was largely a successful one, including a ORGANIZATION invite and LOCATION All-Star nod, though he did struggle in the second half of the season.Gordon is the type of player who may not jump off the page with any one tool, but does a number of things well. He's typically employed a successful contact-oriented, line-drive approach from the left side of the plate. He did show more extra-base power in Double-A, but with that came a higher strikeout rate, though an increased walk rate offset that to a degree. He's a solid runner with good instincts and will steal a base on occasion, and is a tick above-average defensively, both in terms of his arm and overall actions at shortstop. Many have felt his range points to being a better fit at second base and while he did still primarily play short, he did see more time on the right side of the infield in 2017.Gordon will be 22 for all of the 2018 season and is knocking on the big league door. He's more of a high floor than ceiling type and isn't far away from showing just what kind of solid everyday big leaguer he can be, on either side of second base.

PERSON went under the radar coming out of ORGANIZATION Prep in GPE in 2012, and he didn't raise his profile much in his first full professional season with the D-backs. That changed in 2014 when PERSON reached base in 74 consecutive games with PERSON. The ORGANIZATION thought enough of him to make sure he was part of the deal that sent PERSON to GPE that offseason.One of the keys to the streak was PERSON's improved approach at the plate. Armed with a better awareness of the strike zone, he has become a more disciplined hitter, though there is still some swing-and-miss in his game. His improved on-base skills and plus speed make him an ideal fit at the top of the order.Defensively, PERSON is still learning the infield after playing mostly center field in high school, and he's seen time at shortstop, second and third with the ORGANIZATION. A broken hamate in his right hand forced him out for close to two months, but he got back to swinging the bat well upon his return.

PERSON was a sleeper prep prospect as a 70 runner without much else in terms of present tools to offer, so he headed to GPE, where he blossomed in his draft year. He's now an 80 runner but still doesn't quite have the hands or actions for the infield; he could work his way into being a passable second baseman, but we would guess center field is where he lands. His approach is solid but not great, in part because he has above average bat control and, obviously, the speed to outrun softly-hit balls. There's enough power to hit homers to the pull side when he gets ahold of a fastball in, but not much in way of home run potential. He's gotten a little too pull-heavy in pro ball and should use more of an all-fields approach to have a shot to develop the contact skills he needs to turn into a low-end regular.
Made a jump late in his draft spring, sitting 94-97 and hitting 99 mph, mixing in a solid average slider and throwing decent strikes, but with a reliever arm action.
GPE was unknown to many scouts early in the spring, but slowly progressed the whole spring, peaking late with buzz he could get his solid average command and three pitch mix to the 2nd round

PERSON is one of very few GPE players in pro ball--we know of two others: PERSON (ORGANIZATION) and Hai-Cheng Gong (ORGANIZATION)--and is the most talented. The 17-year-old broke off some ferocious curveballs during instructional league that elicited verbal expletives from onlooking scouts. His fastball control is very raw. Right now, PERSON is just a very young developmental project who can really spin it.

Signed out of the ORGANIZATION back in 2011, PERSON has always intrigued with his size and arm strength. Pegged for the bullpen very early in his pro career, the big right-hander has the chance to make an impact as a late-inning reliever in the future.PERSON has always thrown hard, with a fastball that typically sits in the mid-90s. He can reach back for something extra and touches 98-99 mph with regularity. He scrapped a curveball for a developing, and more effective, slider and he'll mix in a changeup on occasion to keep hitters honest. Especially for a power arm, PERSON does an excellent job of throwing strikes, though he was more hittable than one would expect when he made his full-season debut in 2014. Some of that could be attributed to the bandbox in GPE, and he made a big step forward as he moved up the ladder in 2015, finishing the year in Double-A, opening some eyes in the ORGANIZATION and earning a spot on the 40-man roster.Giving someone a "future closer" label is always dangerous, but if PERSON can continue sharpening his breaking ball to go along with his plus fastball, he has the potential to make that kind of contribution.

A mainstay during the summer showcase circuit, GPE carried over solid performances into a senior season where he's performed well enough to enter into top three rounds consideration.The ORGANIZATION of GPE commit is the type of infielder whose whole is greater than the sum of his parts. He definitely can swing the bat, with a good line drive approach and the ability to make consistent contact. He should have some power, too, and homered during last summer's Tournament of PERSON. He's an average runner, though not a burner, but he covers ground as an infielder. He's played multiple positions, showing off his soft hands and accurate arm in various spots.Defensively, GPE might be best suited for second base as a regular, though given his aptitude and instincts, it wouldn't be surprising for the team that takes him to give him a chance to play his way off of shortstop.
GPE body and swing, could be high-contact ORGANIZATION with speed

As a $2,500 senior sign out of Massachusetts-Lowell in 2015, PERSON has had to prove himself at every level since turning pro. He has done exactly that and held his own in the ORGANIZATION League following the 2017 season. By posting the best numbers of his pro career in Triple-A this year, he's putting himself in position for his first big league callup.PERSON's best traits are his reliability and versatility. He makes consistent contract from the right side of the plate, using the entire field and providing some modest pull-side power. Though he's a fringy runner, he has good instincts on the bases and will pick his spots to steal.PERSON has bounced between shortstop, second base and third base ever since he entered pro ball, and he has added left field to his rsum this year. His sure hands stand out more than his quickness or average arm. He's an average defender at second and more fringy on the left side of the infield.

PERSON has a very quiet, easy swing but somehow still generates plus power. He has middling pitch recognition, which sometimes causes him to mistime pitches. This manifests as lots of awkward or checked swings, but he doesn't typically flail and whiff, and PERSON is strong enough that the contact has a chance to be meaningful even if he didn't take a great cut. It's a fair, power-over-hit corner profile that takes a hit if PERSON should ever need to move to first base. So far he's been playable, but not impactful, at third.

The FACILITY took ORGANIZATION closers in successive drafts, selecting PERSON in the first round in 2016 and PERSON in the fourth round last year. He overcame PERSON surgery as a high school junior in 2013 and turned down the ORGANIZATION as a sophomore-eligible 31st-rounder in 2016 before ranking third in ORGANIZATION Division I with 16 saves last spring. After signing him for $450,000, GPE shifted him to starting in August.PERSON has the three-pitch mix to make it in the rotation. When he keeps his heavy 90-95 mph fastball down in the zone, batters struggle to lift it, as evidenced by his 2.3 groundout/flyout ratio during his debut. His changeup has similar action, resembling a splitter and grading as a plus pitch at its best, while his cutter reaches the upper 80s.PERSON throws consistent strikes and has a strong build that should lend itself to durability. He started during two years of summer ball while in college, but he has yet to prove he can handle anything close to a full-season pro workload. If he doesn't make it as a starter, he could advance quickly as a reliever.

A fourth round pick by GPE in 2017, PERSON was traded to the ORGANIZATION just over a year after he was drafted. The ORGANIZATION push college pitchers up the minor league ladder very quickly, and they sent PERSON to Double-A immediately after acquiring him. Though he only sits in the low-90s, PERSON's fastball results in uncomfortable swings from opposing hitters because he generates big extension and hides the ball well. He's a low-risk middle relief prospect who should be ready for the majors relatively soon.
GPE spent most of his 2019 junior season injured, but has average stuff when healthy.

The younger brother of former ORGANIZATION big leaguer PERSON, PERSON signed for $500,000 as a 10th-round pick from a GPE high school in 2010. After stalling in Double-A in 2013 and 2014, he took a huge step forward in 2015 and earned PERSON of the Year honors in the ORGANIZATION. He led the ORGANIZATION with 14 triples and ranked second with 236 total bases and a .472 slugging percentage.Gamel found more success at the plate when he stopped trying to do too much and focused on making consistent line-drive contact. He has a knack for barreling the ball, and while he won't be a huge power threat, he might provide 12-15 homers on an annual basis. He has solid speed and runs the bases aggressively.Gamel played all three outfield positions in 2015, getting the majority of his time in center field after playing mostly in left the previous two years. He lacks the quickness of a typical center fielder but compensates by getting good jumps on balls, and he also has an average arm. He profiles as more of a fourth outfielder than a regular and should make his big league debut in 2016.

The ORGANIZATION aren't afraid to take high school pitchers in the first round, having done so with seven of their last 14 selections. Their latest is PERSON, who lasted 22 picks last June because the industry tends to downgrade prep right-handers on GPE day. Outside of PERSON, who went No. 2 to the ORGANIZATION, PERSON had as good an arm as anyone in the 2014 high school class and he signed for $2.5 million.PERSON began his high school senior season by hitting 100 mph during a preseason scrimmage and continued to bring the heat for the rest of his spring and into his pro debut. He usually works at 93-95 mph with impressive life and command. His hard breaking ball can make hitters look bad as well, combining curveball depth with slider velocity in the low 80s.PERSON also exhibits some feel for a changeup, which should become at least an average third pitch. There isn't much projection in his relatively short and stocky frame, but that doesn't matter because his present stuff is plenty good enough to make him a starter. He also does a nice job of throwing strikes for a youngster.

The ORGANIZATION didn't have a first-round pick in 2013 as a result of signing free agent PERSON, but they went with a projectable high school right-hander who could eventually develop into a first-round kind of talent. The ORGANIZATION prepster is tall and lean and a bit raw on the mound. But there's a lot to like, starting with a fastball that sits in the low-90s, with plenty of room for added velocity as he gets stronger. His secondary stuff needs work, but he does show a feel for a solid sinking changeup and his slider shows glimpses of having good, short tilt to it. Like with many high school arms like this, his command and control need a good amount of refinement. It may take a while, but his upside potential is considerable.Bernie PERSON's scouting report
Big lefty has high slot, runs his heater up to 97 mph and likely fits in relief, but command and offspeed vary.

When the ORGANIZATION drafted PERSON in the 48th round out of high school in 2010, he turned them down to play football as a defensive back at FACILITY. He also took two years off to complete a Mormon mission and didn't return to the diamond until 2013. While raw, his athleticism and upside prompted the GPE to draft him in the third round that June and sign him for $1 million.PERSON has a body that reminds scouts of PERSON and PERSON and could be a dynamic leadoff hitter in that mold. He has the well above-average speed to steal bases and the strength to hit for some power once he develops as a hitter. He's still raw at the plate, with a swing that's compact but not exactly smooth and a rudimentary grasp of the strike zone.PERSON's jumps and routes on balls in center field are still a work in progress, but his quickness helps him overcome his mistakes. Despite below-average arm strength, he recorded 13 assists in his first full pro season. His hiatus put him behind the development curve for a player his age, but his ceiling makes it worth waiting for him to figure things out.

By performing well on the summer showcase circuit and winning ORGANIZATION honors at the 18-and-under World Cup in GPE last September, PERSON positioned himself as one of the top high school pitchers available in the 2014 Draft. Forearm tightness that sidelined him for three weeks during the spring clouded his status, but he rebounded in time to go 30th overall to the ORGANIZATION and sign for $1.75 million.PERSON has a pair of swing-and-miss pitches in his 92-97 mph fastball and his low-80s slider. His changeup has the potential to become an average third offering, and he also mixes in a curveball to give hitters a different look.PERSON throws with little effort in his high-three-quarters delivery, which enables him to deliver strikes repeatedly. He's more physically mature and has less projection remaining than the typical prep pitcher, but that's not a concern because his present stuff already gives him the ceiling of a No. 2 or 3 starter.

Lefties who can touch triple digits don't exactly grow on trees. That's a big reason why the ORGANIZATION went more than $400,000 over pick value to sign PERSON out of PERSON in the sixth round of the 2014 Draft.PERSON's top-of-the-scale fastball is the big southpaw's lone calling card right now. He's hit 100 miles per hour in the past and will often sit in the mid-90s. The rest of PERSON's game is very much a work in progress. The ORGANIZATION are working with him to develop a consistent delivery so he can learn to throw his plus heater for strikes. He doesn't really have any secondary pitches he can count on, though he shows some glimpses of a slider. A broken finger suffered when he punched a wall during the offseason kept PERSON from throwing during Spring Training. He faces a long road ahead of him, with the upside of an PERSON type reliever, one who will pitch almost entirely with his fastball.

The ORGANIZATION drafted the ORGANIZATION product for his advanced bat, and he showed it off during his summer debut, hitting for average and getting on base. PERSON has the chance to be a .300 hitter at the highest level, with more of a line-drive, gap, doubles approach than anything else. He may not have a ton of over-the-fence power, but developing a bit more might help him profile in a corner. That's now an outfield corner rather than an infield one. PERSON was below average at third and he's now a right fielder, where his arm might be a plus. His bat should get him to the big leagues rather quickly; how much pop he develops could determine just how good he is once he gets there.Bernie PERSON's scouting report

PERSON missed all of 2015 and 2016 due to injury and is a bit behind other 21-year-olds, having thrown just 30 innings above rookie ball thus far. But he has three big league offerings and filled up the strike zone in 2018, so he could move quickly if he stays healthy. PERSON's delivery is pretty rough and features quite a bit of violence about his head. This, along with his lengthy injury history, has created worries about his health, and hinders his ability to locate with precision, as he throws strikes but not always where he wants to. Perception about PERSON's health may drive GPE to move him quickly so he can reach the majors before he breaks again. His stuff appeared close to ready last year, as he worked in the mid-90s with armside movement that pairs well with his power, and a mid-80s changeup, while his lower arm slot enables his slider to play against righties. He started last year but we like him as a three-pitch middle relief prospect.

The highest-priced member of the ORGANIZATION' 2011-12 international class, PERSON signed for $750,000 and spent his first two pro seasons in GPE ball. His full-season debut in 2014 was a tale of two halves, as he batted .212/.267/.335 before the low Class A GPE ORGANIZATION All-Star Game and .319/.367/.456 afterward.PERSON showed the ability to make adjustments, doing a better job of handling breaking pitches and making repeated contact in the second half. He has the potential to hit for average and power once he gets stronger and develops more patience at the plate. He has the bat speed to catch up to quality fastballs, though almost all of his present power comes against right-handers, at this point.Despite his offensive promise, there's no question that PERSON's best tool is his arm. It earns double-plus grades from scouts, one of whom guessed that he'd have a 95-mph fastball if he took to the mound. He's still seeking consistency after committing 51 errors in his first 196 pro games at third base, though he has the hands and enough range to be a capable defender.

PERSON was an outfielder who flashed a mid-90s fastball as a reliever at ORGANIZATION (ORGANIZATION, Fla.), which has produced four big leaguers and five first-round picks, including 2018 ORGANIZATION choice PERSON. PERSON went to PERSON, where he moved to shortstop and blossomed into the highest pick in school history (51st overall) as well as the ORGANIZATION USA player and defensive player of the year in 2016. Persistent hamstring injuries limited him to seven games during his first full pro season, but he stayed healthy in 2018 and finished second in the Class A Advanced PERSON batting race at .315.PERSON's most valuable attribute is his ability to make consistent line-drive contact. He hinted at average raw power as an amateur that has yet to translate to home run production as a pro, though GPE hopes he can unlock more pop if he adds some strength to his lanky frame and some loft to his relatively flat right-handed swing. He has average speed and is effective on the bases, albeit not much of a threat to steal.His instincts and quick first step allow PERSON to cover ground and get the job done at shortstop. He still has a strong arm and soft hands, and he should be able to play second or third base if needed. He has one of the higher floors among ORGANIZATION position prospects and a decent upside as a reliable if unspectacular regular.

In a relatively down year in LOCATION, PERSON has separated himself as clearly the best high school arm in the region. While there's quite a bit separating the pair, PERSON is generally thought to be No. 2 and is all about projection and future potential.PERSON does have a big fastball now and a 6-foot-4 frame that could add strength, making it easy to dream on move velocity to come. His fastball sits in the low 90s, has touched higher at times, with some good life down in the zone. He has good feel for his breaking ball, a curve that should be a least an average secondary pitch for him. His changeup is very much a work in progress and it's not a pitch he uses in games. Despite some issues with his delivery and arm action, PERSON is a decent strike thrower, but he has a way to go to develop from thrower to pitcher. Signability could be a concern, with a spot at LOCATION waiting should he go the college route.

Groshans immediately stood out to scouts on the showcase circuit, showing a ORGANIZATION starter kit with similar swing mechanics, plus raw power projection, a plus arm, and a third base defensive fit. He essentially held serve on that first impression and went 12th overall to the ORGANIZATION out of the same GPE high school as the ORGANIZATION' second round pick, PERSON. Groshans isn't quite the same level athlete as PERSON, and there are contact concerns with an active swing like that, but there are some bat-to-ball skills and plenty of mistake power he can already tap into, as shown in a loud debut in the ORGANIZATION. Many of the pro scouts who saw Groshans weren't fans and saw below average tools in their looks when he fatigued late in the pro season, but the things to watch for here are the plate discipline and contact skills, because the position and power aren't really up for debate right now.

The 2014 PERSON's crop of college hitters already stands out, with PERSON, PERSON and PERSON reaching the big leagues during the 2015 season. ORGANIZATION, taken near the end of the first round, isn't there yet.ORGANIZATION played a lot of shortstop during his first full season, then was shifted over to play some second base right at about the time he was promoted to Double-A. He continued to learn the right side of the infield during the ORGANIZATION and the ORGANIZATION feel he'll be more than capable defensively there. They also know ORGANIZATION can play third from his time there at ORGANIZATION and in 2016, while he played more second than anywhere else, he saw time at all three infield spots. The hope is his bat eventually will profile anywhere. He's shown an advanced approach at the plate with good on-base skills at times, though he's struggled with the advancement to Double-A. ORGANIZATION gets high marks for his makeup and leadership skills. Some of his PERSON-mates may have beaten him to the big leagues, but once ORGANIZATION gets there, he's going to be the type of player winning teams want to have in the lineup.

As a 17-year-old with an athletic but thin build, PERSON stood out more with his projection than his present stuff for much of the spring. That profile usually lands a high school pitcher in college, but he generated some late helium when he showed improved velocity late in the season. He still might not be easy to lure away from PERSON, where he could get a chance to contribute as a two-way player.PERSON's fastball jumped from 88-92 mph to 91-93 mph as the ORGANIZATION neared, with his low-three-quarters arm slot creating angle and sink. His slider showed more power and flashes of becoming a solid second offering as well. His fading changeup could be equally as effective.PERSON shows a willingness to use all three of his pitches, though he sometimes struggles to control them. He has the athleticism and delivery to figure out how to locate his offerings and remain a starter for the long term. His development will require time and patience if he turns pro this summer, though he has a high ceiling as a lefty with three potential solid or better pitches.

Back in 2015, the ORGANIZATION had a pair of flamethrowers create quite a buzz in the ORGANIZATION. PERSON has since been traded to the ORGANIZATION while PERSON's momentum has stalled a bit after two extended stays in the Class A Advanced PERSON League.It's not that PERSON was awful in GPE Beach in 2017; he just didn't dominate the way someone with his premium stuff should, and he was shut down at the end of July with some arm tenderness as the ORGANIZATION decided to err on the side of caution. He still has one of the best fastballs in the system, one that reaches 99 mph, and he can combine it with a changeup that flashes plus. Two things holding PERSON back are his lack of a consistent slider and a lack of command. His breaking ball is developing, but it's fringe-average at best right now, and he'll predictably rely on his fastball-changeup combination to get outs when he needs to. His control comes and goes, leading to elevated walk rates, while his lack of feel for pitching hasn't allowed him to miss as many bats as he should.PERSON is just 21, so there is time for him to turn his projection into performance. He didn't return from that issue until June, and when he did so, it was as a reliever, which could be his long-term role.

Drafted as a arm action/athleticism project out of GPE, PERSON's velocity has grown significantly since his high school days; he's developed a plus, maybe plus-plus changeup that has about 15 mph of velocity difference off his fastball. He's amassed 174 strikeouts in 123 pro innings, mostly via multi-inning relief outings. Lefties with changeups are well-positioned for when three-batter minimums are put in place for relievers. Now at Double-A, PERSON might factor into the ORGANIZATION bullpen picture this year. He projects as a middle reliever.

It looked like the ORGANIZATION were going to sign PERSON, as they were attached to the GPE shortstop almost from the minute he became eligible to be signed. It took a little longer than expected, but they finally got their man at the start of the 2016 signing period for a bonus of $7 million. During his full-season debut in the ORGANIZATION State League, PERSON both lived up to his defensive reputation and down to concerns about his potential with the bat. He wasn't able to put those questions to rest as a hamate issue sent him to the disabled list on two different occasions in 2018.PERSON hadn't been overwhelmed in a pitching-friendly environment and he did hit .270 in the first half before running out of gas in 2017. More than anything, PERSON needs to refine his approach, learning the strike zone better and working counts more. He does have some raw power to tap into and he needs to try to do more damage rather than just playing for contact.On the other side of the ball, the ORGANIZATION feel PERSON is one of the best defensive shortstops in the ORGANIZATION. He has tremendous instincts and a strong arm, making all of the routine plays and then frequently making a play you don't expect he can. Those skills alone should get him to the big leagues, but he's going to have to hit a bit more to be an all-around regular.

PERSON burst onto the prospect scene in 2015, hitting 10 homers in 48 games in the ORGANIZATION at age 17. He signed as a shortstop but has moved down the defensive spectrum to right field, retaining his loose, lefty swing and physical projection. In the interim, PERSON has had maturity and consistency issues, which he appears to be moving past now. Longer-limbed power hitters typically take the longest to develop offensively, making his pro debut that much more surprising. He'll be 21 years old next year, with a chance to get to Double-A and regain the everyday player projection some saw in 2015.

PERSON emerged as a viable first-round pick during the 2012 Cal PERSON and then solidified his status the following spring at ORGANIZATION, leading to his selection as the 13th overall pick by PERSON. In 2015, PERSON got off to a slow start at ORGANIZATION Antonio but made the necessary adjustments and found his power stroke in time to hit 20 home runs for the second straight season, finishing the year in Triple-A. PERSON picked up in 2016 where he had left off, as he entered the All-Star ranked among the ORGANIZATION leaders in most offensive categories. PERSON has plus-plus raw power to his pull side, a product of his bat speed and physical strength and an upper-cut swing that's conducive to clearing fences. He strikes out quite a bit because the approach is aggressive and he has some length to his swing that makes him vulnerable to quality secondary pitches on the outer half as well as advanced sequencing. The contact that PERSON does make is consistently hard and loud, though, and he's shown the ability to make adjustments at the plate at each level.Defensively, PERSON's arm strength is nearly as impressive as his power and makes him a clean fit in right field, where he notched 25 assists between the 2014-15 seasons. He's athletic and moves well for his size, with average speed on the bases and range in the outfield.

It's not uncommon for a team to draft a college reliever and give him a chance to start. It becomes unusual when that pitcher goes out and finishes in the top 10 in ORGANIZATION in each of his first three full pro seasons, as PERSON did in 2013-15 before being dealt to GPE in January 2016. PERSON made his ORGANIZATION debut in a spot start for PERSON at the end of May and then made two more starts at the end of the season. He's found success pitching off of his low-90s, heavy, sinking fastball. Using that closer mentality from his days at ORGANIZATION, he goes right after hitters, inducing weak contact early in counts. His slider is a solid average hard breaking ball with bite that misses bats. While his changeup isn't quite as good, it is effective at neutralizing left-handed hitters. His walk rate has gone down each year since his summer debut and he continues to get a good amount of groundball outs.His brief big league debut was just a taste, with PERSON very close to being ready to fulfill a ceiling as a mid-to-back of the rotation type of starter at the highest level.

A big international signee back in 2009, PERSON has been a little slow to develop. He's still just 20 years old while repeating the ORGANIZATION and still has some solid raw tools to work with. He has considerable raw power, though plate discipline has kept him from tapping into it consistently at this point. With below-average speed and a fringy arm, he might be a left fielder only in the future, but it's his bat that will carry him if he can refine his approach.

The ORGANIZATION made the most of their two second-round picks in the 2015 Draft by selecting the best defensive outfielders still on the board in PERSON and ORGANIZATION high school product PERSON. Though PERSON was GPE's second choice, he received the highest bonus in its Draft crop at $800,000 for his five-tool potential. He led the low Class A GPE ORGANIZATION in runs (105) and walks (72) during his introduction to full-season ball in '17 before joining the ORGANIZATION in the ORGANIZATION trade this June, going to PERSON along with third baseman PERSON and right-hander PERSON Morel.The ORGANIZATION helped PERSON become a switch-hitter upon entering the pro ranks and he made huge strides as a lefty in 2017, collecting 25 of his 39 extra-base hits (including all eight of his homers) from that side, albeit with some swing-and-miss tendencies. He's more contact-oriented with modest gap power from his natural right side, while his patient approach and discerning eye stands out on both sides of the plate.PERSON' plus speed translated to 31 steals in his first full season, and he should continue to swipe bags with ease thanks to his strong on-base skills. He gets excellent jumps and has range for days in all directions in center field, with average arm strength that allows him to play all three outfield positions if needed. He has the ceiling of a top-of-the-order center fielder, with a fourth-outfielder floor thanks to his across-the-board tools.

The ORGANIZATION used their first overall pick (in the second round) in the 2013 Draft on PERSON, an athletic and projectable right-hander from the ORGANIZATION prep ranks. He was eased into pro ball, spending two seasons in GPE ball before finally advancing to full-season Class A Wisconsin in 2015 and pitching well there. PERSON continued to make strides the following year, reaching the ORGANIZATION State League, but had his entire 2017 campaign wiped out by PERSON surgery that also cost him a portion of the '18 season. After struggling as starter upon his return from a 22-month layoff, PERSON was moved to the bullpen in 2019 and immediately took to the new role, showing improved velocity and a knack for missing bats at ORGANIZATION en route to a Futures Game selection in July. As a starter, PERSON operated with a low-90s fastball and flashed a plus breaking ball. But after tacking on some muscle while recovering from surgery, he's sitting at 95-98 mph out of the 'pen and at times touching 100 mph. He's learned to be aggressive with his heater, throwing it with late life that enables him to consistently beat hitters up in the zone His changeup features a 12-13 mph demarcation in velocity off of his fastball and has emerged as his best secondary weapon post-surgery, while his mid- to upper-80s slider gives him a third Major League-caliber offering. His control has improved along with stuff, though he still has gains to make with his command.The physical strength PERSON added during his rehab process has made him a more durable pitcher, and he's had no issues working multiple innings in 2019. The ORGANIZATION view him as potential multi-inning weapon out of the bullpen, and it's a safe bet that they'll add PERSON to their 40-man roster this offseason so as to protect him from the Rule 5 Draft.

Since his high school days, PERSON has teased with his tools and his athleticism, but he hasn't always been a consistent performer. The ORGANIZATION are hoping he can put it together in their organization.PERSON is a physical specimen, and he is the kind of player who "looks the part." He has big-time raw power, can run and he has the arm for right field. At the plate, PERSON can be a little bit of a feast-or-famine-type player, and he'll need to make more consistent contact so he can tap into that power more regularly. In the final month of his pro debut in the LOCATION in 2013, PERSON had a .973 ORGANIZATION, and he continued to build on that during his first full season.Now healthy after dealing with injuries during his junior year at ORGANIZATION, PERSON has the raw tools to fit the right-field profile to a tee.

The ORGANIZATION drafted ORGANIZATION as a shortstop, and he played the infield for two full professional seasons, advancing to Class A Advanced Carolina in 2012. But the glut of middle infielders in the organization and the recommendation of manager PERSON led the Tribe to move ORGANIZATION behind the plate in '13.ORGANIZATION has handled the move well, and he's developing into a solid defender at his new position. Offensively, he's a solid hitter with gap power.While ORGANIZATION has a chance to develop into a regular catcher, GPE has continued to give him some work in the infield, and the club sees him as a potential super-utility player capable of being in the lineup every day, albeit at several positions.

There's raw power and there's in-game power. Many a prospect over time has the former, but never can find a way to tap into it to have the latter consistently. While there is a lot of swing and miss to GPE's game, he's shown that he can hit the ball out, with 51 homers over his first two full years of pro ball. It's that power the ORGANIZATION wanted when they acquired him last fall from the D-backs in return for catcher PERSON Herrmann.GPE's power comes more from strength than bat speed and he's always going to strike out a lot. While he'll draw some walks, he'll never hit for a high average. He played both the outfield and first base in the D-backs system and the ORGANIZATION plan to let him play mostly in the outfield moving forward, though they won't abandon first base entirely. He'll mostly play the corners, but might see some time in center as well. GPE runs well for someone his size, stealing 24 bases in 2015.The upper levels should be a good challenge for GPE to see if the power will keep showing up against better pitching. If it keeps coming, his left-handed power bat could be of value, at least off of a big league bench.

The ORGANIZATION had been linked for months to PERSON, a GPE defector, before signing him in late July for $1.5 million and a matching penalty for exceeding their international bonus allotment. He was one of GPE's biggest expenditures as it exceeded its international pool for the first time. Though he had limited success in sporadic playing time in 2012-14 in GPE's PERSON, he was one of the league's youngest players and fared better in the island's 18-and-under and 23-and-under leagues.PERSON stands out most for his offensive potential. He has a quick right-handed bat and has added strength since defecting, giving him intriguing raw power for a middle infielder. He's aggressive at the plate but makes consistent contact and uses the entire field.While PERSON has just average speed, the ORGANIZATION believe he'll be able to stay at shortstop. He has good actions and a quick first step, giving him range to both sides. He also has soft hands and solid arm strength that should fit well at second or third base should he need to change positions.

The younger brother of GPE right-hander PERSON, PERSON had a big 2016 season that included a no-hitter and reaching Double-A at age 21. Despite being among the organizational leaders in several statistical categories, his struggles in Double-A showed he had work to do. To his credit, he adjusted, dominating Double-A in 2017 and earning a promotion to Triple-A in the process.Mahle is a command and control specialist, albeit it one with decent stuff. His fastball typically sits in the low 90s, but he adds and subtracts frequently, reaching as high as 96 mph when he wants to. He throws two distinct breaking balls and has good feel for a changeup, though all of his secondary stuff grades out as PERSON average. When he's at his best, he sets up hitters and mixes his pitches well, though he can rely on his plus-plus fastball command too much at times.Mahle had gotten too cute at times and tried to be too fine when he got to Double-A, perhaps giving hitters in the more-advanced league too much credit. A smart pitcher on the mound, he clearly learned from the experience and is poised to reach his ceiling of a mid-rotation starter.

Recruited by PERSON to play tight end out of high school in 2013, PERSON instead signed with the ORGANIZATION for $300,000 as a sixth-round Draft pick. A breakout 2015 full-season debut quickly made him a popular name in trade talks, and he became the key return for GPE in the July trade that sent PERSON to GPE.
