An Illinois recruit, PERSON is a better defender but has less power potential than PERSON, a Badger State prep catcher whom the ORGANIZATION drafted in the second round two years ago.PERSON has all the tools to succeed behind the plate. He receives and blocks well, and he makes accurate throws with solid arm strength. He plays with energy and has admirable leadership skills.PERSON has played through a hamate injury that has hampered him at the plate this spring. His strength stands out more than his bat speed, though his right-handed swing is quick enough. He currently employs a middle-away approach that's more conducive to hitting for average than power, though he could have more pop once he starts to turn on more pitches.

GPE shortstops with solid all-around tools aren't always easy to find in any Draft class. That's why PERSON, who looks and plays a lot like ORGANIZATION shortstop PERSON, was high on lists entering this spring. The ORGANIZATION product has continued to perform as a junior, cementing his status as a potential top 10 pick.Nearly all of PERSON's tools grade out as at least above-average. He has the chance to be a plus hitter, with very advanced bat to ball skills. He's never overmatched and always seems comfortable in the box, handling good velocity and offspeed stuff equally well, while walking more than he's struck out in his college career. Even when he's off-balance, he keeps his hands back and shoots the ball the other way to left field. And while he'll never sell out his hit tool for power, he'll show pop in batting practice and it's easy to dream on 15-18 homers annually at the next level. While PERSON does show off a plus arm at times, the one area there's a split camp might be his ability to play shortstop in the big leagues. Most give him a chance to stick there, given his makeup and instincts, unless the team he's on has a better defender on the roster. At the very least, he'll be given the opportunity to do so after hearing his name called in the first round.

Though PERSON was a left-handed pitcher with a fastball that could reach 94 mph, the ORGANIZATION preferred him as a hitter and spent $800,000 to sign him as a sixth-rounder out of a GPE high school in 2011. He fractured his right kneecap in his first pro game and missed all of 2012 after it didn't heal properly, though he made his way to Triple-A by age 22. The ORGANIZATION made him the ORGANIZATION. 2 overall pick in the 2015 Rule 5 Draft yet couldn't keep him, and GPE's glut of outfield prospects forced him to begin each of the last two seasons back in Double-A, but he has continued to persevere.While PERSON doesn't have a plus tool, he also doesn't have a glaring weakness. He has hit for average throughout the Minors, making consistent hard contact and using the entire field. After hitting just 11 homers in his first three full pro seasons, he has done a better job of using his lower half to generate power and set a career high for homers in 2017 despite missing most of the first month recovering from arthroscopic surgery on his left knee in March.PERSON's solid speed and average arm allow him to play all three outfield positions. After spending most of his time in center field earlier in his career, he has gotten most of his action in left field the last two years. While he may have a hard time claiming an everyday job with the ORGANIZATION, he could be a useful fourth outfielder.

PERSON returned from PERSON surgery to pace ORGANIZATION USA in strikeouts and innings in 2015, and the A's took the Alabama-Birmingham hurler in the 20th round that June. Though he reached Triple-A while pitching at four levels last year in his first full professional season, PERSON's shining moment came the next year in the ORGANIZATION finals, when he tossed six scoreless frames to lead Double-A GPE to its third straight title. PERSON helped the ORGANIZATION secure yet another title in 2017, though he also spent two months on the disabled list with an oblique injury. PERSON relies heavily on his sinker, an 86-90 mph offering that he consistently commands down in the zone and that has resulted in twice as many ground-ball outs than air outs in his career. He can manipulate the pitch, too, at times imparting cutting action in order to keep hitters true. His slider is an average offering, thrown in the upper 70s, and he'll also mix in a firm changeup, though it's his least advanced offering. PERSON's arsenal plays up thanks to his strike-throwing ability and bulldog mentality on the mound. Outside of the injury that sidelined him in 2017, PERSON has proven plenty durable during his professional career. He also receives high praise for his defense -- he was a Minor League Gold Glove winner in 2016 -- and feel for controlling the running game. PERSON will continue to be developed as a starter, but he also could reach the Majors quickly in a bullpen role, possibly as a long reliever, thanks to his excellent ground-ball tendencies.
Big power and shorter track record of performance entering the year but we're now in the midst of a breakout.

After beginning his college career as a swingman at Louisiana-Lafayette, PERSON' transition to the rotation as a sophomore had mixed results. That prompted to a full-time move to the bullpen as in junior in 2017, a role in which PERSON thrived. He struck out 100 batters and yielded just 29 hits in 59 1/3 innings to lead all Division I hurlers in both strikeouts-per-nine (15.17) and hits-per-nine (4.40). That overwhelming success earned him a 13th-round selection by the A's in June, and after signing for $110,000, PERSON continued to miss bats with ease across two levels in his pro debut. PERSON gets the most out of his two above-average pitches, missing bats inside and outside of the zone easily with each. He won't shy away from challenging hitters up in the zone with his low-90s fastball that he can also spot to both sides of the plate. His curveball is a hammer when it's on, registering in the low 80s with tight spin, and it serves as an ideal bat-missing complement to his fastball. PERSON has a strong track record as a strike-thrower, but he'll need to improve his fastball command for continued success at higher levels.Though he started seven of his 13 games during his pro debut and has pitched almost exclusively in that role with PERSON in 2018, PERSON' future is likely in the bullpen. His fastball-curveball combo gives him upside as a high-leverage reliever, and with improved command of both pitches, he could hop on the fast track to the ORGANIZATION.

GPE was the ORGANIZATION. 1 starter on PERSON's 2013 College World Series team, ahead of third-rounders PERSON (GPE) and PERSON (ORGANIZATION). He surprisingly lasted until the 11th round that June but shook that off to turn in a fine season as a starter in low Class A in 2014.There's little question that GPE's fastball is his best pitch. He works at 90-94 mph with some occasional life and uses his height to deliver it on a steep downhill plane. He does have a sturdy frame built for starting and has no difficulty filling the strike zone.Nevertheless, GPE may be destined for the bullpen. Both his slider and changeup are below-average offerings, and he leaves them up in the strike zone too often.
Though he lacks physical projection, PERSON has excellent and-eye coordination and feel for the barrel that might allow him to reach the Majors as a hit-first corner outfielder.

Even those casually exposed to public facing prospect analysis become familiar with a few key concepts and player archetypes, and an early lesson often addresses the volatility of players like PERSON, who have several elite tools that will lead to star-level performance if they hit enough, but who also carry significant risk that they will strike out too much to matter at all. Of course, the reason each individual player has strikeout issues can vary. Some hitters have feckless, over-aggressive approaches, while others can't recognize breaking balls or have a problem with lever length and get tied up inside. PERSON's issues -- his strikeout rate has fallen between 27% and 32% each of the last three years -- appear to stem from his bat path and limited bat control. Stiff wrists cause his bat head to drag into the zone, which can cause him to be tardy on fastballs at the letters and, more frequently, flail at soft stuff dipping down and away from him. PERSON has similar issues that have yet to be remedied. 
PERSON does enough other stuff that, even if the strike outs remain an issue, he could still be a valuable big leaguer. He crushes anything down and in, has sufficient plate coverage to hit fastballs middle away, and has enough power to do damage to the opposite field. He also has good ball/strike recognition so, again like PERSON, there should be power, walks, and up-the-middle defense. We think PERSON is likely to be an exciting but flawed everyday player, though it's not audacious to think his relative youth (he was a 20-year-old at Hi-A in 2018) and inexperience (he also missed a year of reps due to a suspension for bad paperwork) leave more room for growth than we anticipate.

There's been a seven-figure ORGANIZATION catcher near the top of every international class dating back through 2016, and ORGANIZATION is this year's model. He's a little less polished on defense than most of his predecessors but has a plus arm and mature, strength-driven power. He has everyday offensive ability if he can remain lithe and mobile enough to catch.
Long-term 3B fit due to quickness, but arm is plus and raw power will be at least average due to projectable frame.

After his strong sophomore season at ORGANIZATION, scouts were excited to see what PERSON could do to raise his profile as a power-hitting third baseman. A transfer to ORGANIZATION made it tougher for scouts to evaluate his performance, though PERSON certainly did his part by hitting .308/.351/.639 with 20 home runs and 15 doubles. It's that offensive upside that led the ORGANIZATION to take him in the second round of the 2016 Draft and then sign him for $1.15 million. PERSON made an immediate impact after signing, hitting .400/.452/.552 in GPE Pioneer League en route a quick promotion to Class A Wisconsin, followed by an Opening Day assignment to Class A Advanced Carolina for his first full season.PERSON has impact potential from the left side of the plate, with natural feel to hit, a solid approach and plus raw power that could make him a middle-of-the-order bat at maturity. Defensively, PERSON's athleticism should help him stick at third base, where he has a strong arm -- one that fired 93-94 mph fastballs as PERSON's closer -- that's ideal for the position. He also received positive reviews as a shortstop during the fall instructional league, highlighting PERSON's overall athleticism and versatility.The ORGANIZATION have long been trying to develop a homegrown third baseman, and while it's early in his career, PERSON, with his high offensive ceiling, could be the team's long-term answer.

After a very strong 2017, PERSON began 2018 as an 18-year-old in full-season ball. He didn't perform well on paper, but still has an exciting combination of defensive ability and power projection. Built like a freshman combo guard, PERSON's has a good chance to add strength as he ages without compromising his ability to play second base. His hitting hands are explosive but still pretty uncoordinated, especially from the left side of the plate. That will need to be smoothed out as PERSON develops, but he has some feel for lifting the ball and he's able to drop the bat head to get to pitches down and in. Likely a long-term developmental project, PERSON has a shot to hit for some power and play up the middle.

So unpolished is PERSON that the ORGANIZATION omitted him from 40-man protection in November and he went unpicked in the Rule 5 draft. The quality of his at-bats remains inconsistent and he has yet to have a strong full-season statistical campaign. But he's an above-average athlete with middle infield actions, a good frame, and very attractive left-handed swing. Solely on hand talent and defensive profile, we think PERSON has considerable upside, but there's a chance he's just always a frustrating guess hitter. PERSON will be the age of most college juniors next year and he's already had a taste of Hi-A. Were he a junior at an ORGANIZATION school, he'd be the kind of talent that goes in the second round if he turns a corner during the spring and performs, and in the fourth round if he doesn't.

ORGANIZATION Premier Event: Southeast 1 - 1/14/17 - PERSON MLB Team: GPE Nationals Favorite MLB Player: PERSON former ORGANIZATION commit who is now set to attend PERSON, PERSON was a 4A First Team All-State performer in GPE back in 2015. PERSON could be the ORGANIZATION' next success story with converting college relievers into pro starters, following PERSON and the since-traded PERSON. His spike curveball can be more devastating and also harder to control, combining power and 12-to-6 break. Both PERSON and PERSON added velocity and maintained it over a full season after shifting to the rotation, and if that happens with PERSON he could have a pair of well-above-average pitches.PERSON rarely employed a changeup in college, so adding a reliable third pitch will be a focal point of his development. Improving his control and command are also on his to-do list after he averaged 4.5 walks per nine innings at ORGANIZATION. He has a strong frame and his arm works well, so he should have the durability required to start.

PERSON transferred from GPE to ORGANIZATION after his sophomore year and proceeded to hit .308/.351/.639 with 20 home runs. The ORGANIZATION have long been trying to develop a homegrown third baseman, and while it's early in his career, PERSON, with his across-the-board tools and high offensive ceiling, could be the team's long-term answer.

PERSON spent two years at ORGANIZATION in the GPE, GPE., area before switching his academics to the online PERSON and his baseball to the ORGANIZATION. PERSON's changeup gives him a reliable third offering.With his big 6-foot-5 frame, PERSON does a nice job of creating plane and angle on his pitches, making him more difficult to hit. His control and command improved after he transitioned to starting, and GPE will keep him in that role going forward. The FACILITY thought PERSON might not need much more than another year in the Minors, but offseason knee surgery and elbow issues had prevented him from pitching in a game before the All-Star break.

The nephew of former ORGANIZATION star PERSON and the cousin of fellow top prospect PERSON, PERSON has a famous last name, but he's also making a name for himself.Known for his strong arm and quick feet, PERSON has opened eyes with his easy actions on defense. He's a fluid defender and has a knack for making plays look easy. His tools and athletic ability will likely keep him at the position as he grows into his body and develops as a player.On offense, the teen is not as strong as his cousin PERSON, but PERSON has shown some raw power and the ability to hit home runs. He's a decent runner and has been working on stealing bases. PERSON signed with the ORGANIZATION for $1.5 million. PERSON's older brother PERSON is a Minor League pitcher in the organization.

The ORGANIZATION high school ranks feature two right-handers who can run their fastball into the mid-90s. If his next step is attending college, he'll play at Illinois.GPE caught scouts' attention when he reached 94 mph at the World Wood Bat Association World Championship. Both his slider and changeup are low-80s offerings that are inconsistent but have the potential to become solid offerings.At 6 feet and 170 pounds, GPE lacks projection and has a smaller build than desired for a starter. He generates his velocity with a quick arm rather than effort, which helps his cause and allows him to throw strikes. PERSON praise his competitive makeup.

A ORGANIZATION junior college righty, PERSON signed for $100,000 as a 2018 23rd rounder and had a velo spike in 2019. He's now 89-92 with heavy sink (over 60% ground ball rate this year) and a good splitter, as well as a passable slider. It's probably important that PERSON's stuff keep improving, but it's trending up enough now that he's popped onto the radar.

Players who are drafted out of high school from cold-weather states need to get out and play, repetition being the key to help them catch up from not playing as much as amateurs from warm-weather areas. So when PERSON missed all of the 2016 season because of a broken hamate and ensuing complications, it wasn't ideal.The ORGANIZATION native had struggled, somewhat expectedly, out of the gate after signing in 2015. Though PERSON didn't put up numbers, he did still show outstanding plate discipline and a willingness to draw walks. His advanced approach should eventually allow him to hit for average and his bat speed should lead to decent power down the road. With a tick above-average speed, PERSON could stick in center field and also could profile in left if needed. PERSON wasn't cleared to play last fall during instructs, so it's been a very long layoff since he faced competitive pitching of any sort. He's basically starting over, but he has the offensive tools to get back on track now that he's healthy.

Signed for $35,000 as a 24th-round pick out of GPE in 2013, PERSON recorded a 6.96 ERA in his pro debut before breaking out in late 2014, when he was named Rookie-level PERSON of the Year and broke PERSON's low Class A Great Lakes single-game strikeout record with 14. PERSON took another huge step forward in 2015, when he led the ORGANIZATION with 12.8 strikeouts per nine innings, then dominated Triple-A and made his big league debut with the ORGANIZATION last year. But it will now be up to the ORGANIZATION to further his development after acquiring him from the ORGANIZATION for PERSON in January. PERSON's stuff significantly improved in pro ball after he upgraded his conditioning and mechanics. He works at 92-94 mph and can reach 96 mph with his fastball, which has riding life. PERSON's changeup progressed so much in 2015 that it has become his best secondary pitch, and he also has a low-80s slider that's effective.PERSON's control and command also have gotten better since he signed. He has gone from an unknown to a potential No. 2 starter in two years, and he may not need much more time in the ORGANIZATION. Though he has missed time in 2016 with an ankle injury and shoulder inflammation, he has maintained a similar strikeout rate while making the jump to Triple-A.

The son of former All-Star closer PERSON, PERSON showed all the components of a top-flight pitching prospect during his 2014 full-season debut, so much so that he earned a spot on the U.S. PERSON's roster in the ORGANIZATION All-Star PERSON at age 19, roughly one year after GPE had selected him with the 22nd overall pick. He finally returned to the mound in July 2017 and looked like his old self while excelling across three levels.Owner of a fastball that sits in the 92-95 mph range and reaches 96-97, PERSON also commands the pitch to both sides of the plate thanks to a smooth delivery as well as a whippy-but-clean arm action. He pairs his heater with a plus curveball that he throws with tight spin and considerable depth to create late downer action and pile up whiffs, while PERSON's changeup gives him a third average-or-better offering.His injury history aside, PERSON is still loaded with upside. The strength he's added in recent years to his formerly wiry frame has helped to assuage some concerns about his durability, and GPE officials believe he's now better off physically after going through a structured strengthening and throwing program. Barring further setbacks, PERSON, now a member of GPE's 40-man roster, could still achieve his projection as a No. 3 starter.

Not to be confused with the "other" lefty Cody PERSON, who was drafted by the ORGANIZATION and traded to the Reds in the PERSON deal, this PERSON hails from the ORGANIZATION high school ranks and has moved slowly since being the D-backs' second-round pick in 2014.Still very young -- he was drafted two days before his 18th birthday -- PERSON has a good feel for pitching for his age. His velocity has dipped a bit as he's adjusted to the pro game, going from touching the mid-90s during his senior year of high school to touching 90-91 mph with his fastball. PERSON's slider shows glimpses of being a sharp out pitch, and his changeup has some fade, albeit inconsistently. He tends to throw a lot of strikes, sometimes to his detriment. PERSON doesn't have a true out pitch, and he needs to learn to get hitters to expand their zones rather than always challenging them over the plate. That said, some deception in his delivery makes it tough to pick the ball up.Better secondary stuff, improved command within the strike zone and a continued eye on his conditioning will all be keys for PERSON moving forward. His stock may have dropped some, but there's still time for him to get it back.
Strong-bodied infielder with present power.

PERSON has a swing-and-miss heater that plays in the strike zone because of its spin and weird plane, plane caused by PERSON's lowish arm slot. His breaking ball is blunt, but it has good pure spin, he commands it, and it plays up against righties because of his slot. The changeup is PERSON's best secondary, and projects to plus, as does PERSON's command, which is already advanced. The fastball/changeup/command concoction was poisonous to rookie-level hitters in 2018; PERSON struck out 82 and walked just eight in 63 innings of ORGANIZATION and ORGANIZATION ball. 
The lack of a visibly excellent breaking ball causes some apprehension, but if everything else is a 60 or better at maturity, PERSON could be a good mid-rotation starter.

PERSON is a strong-bodied, multi-positional infielder with advanced feel for contact. He'll be 20 for the first half of the season and has already reached Hi-A, leaving comically low strikeout rates in his wake as he has climbed the minor league ladder. His strikeout rate has hovered around 10% throughout his career despite PERSON having been about a year and a half younger than the average player at each minor league stop. 
He may start trading some contact for power (his early-season strikeout and fly ball rates would seem to indicate this might be happening) but that may require more selectivity to work. PERSON's swing is currently bottom-hand heavy and he doesn't rip the bat through contact the way most power hitters do. He's been fine putting quality, low-lying contact into play to his pull side so far, but may be best served to hit for more power, especially if he eventually moves off short. He's a version of the bat control/up the middle types we so love here at ORGANIZATION, if a slightly lesser version right now due to his quieter results to date and his mature physicality.

It's the job of every scouting department to uncover talent. It's unusual, however, for ORGANIZATION-eligible talent to be found after the ORGANIZATION has been completed. It ended up being the gain of the ORGANIZATION, who signed the passed-over player for $735,000.No one, including PERSON himself, realized the speedy outfielder was eligible for the 2016 ORGANIZATION as a redshirt sophomore. PERSON started to get wind of it as PERSON was trying out and then playing for the ORGANIZATION. Several teams other than the ORGANIZATION showed interest, most notably the ORGANIZATION and PERSON. But it was the ORGANIZATION who were able to sign him. PERSON played very well for PERSON in international competition, with some feeling he was the second-best position player on the team, behind PERSON's PERSON, who will be a hot commodity in next year's ORGANIZATION. With a good approach at the plate and a line-drive, gap swing from the left side, the ORGANIZATION might have a future leadoff hitter on their hands.

The ORGANIZATION signed PERSON for $2 million just before the clock struck midnight on the 2015-2016 ORGANIZATION Agent signing period, then traded him to PERSON for PERSON a few weeks later, before PERSON had even played a pro game. He has big, all-fields raw power, and balls he mis-hits will often still find their way to the warning track. While PERSON has good natural timing in the box and isn't often fooled by breaking stuff, he does have limited bat control and we anticipate his batting averages will be lower in majors than they have been thus far. 
ORGANIZATION for his size, PERSON has mostly played left field as a pro and he's a 40 runner underway, but he appeared to stiffen last year and most teams have him projected to first base or DH. That will limit his overall value and makes his lack of bat control a little scary, but we still think PERSON will become an average regular, and possibly get an opportunity quite soon.

PERSON's velocity (mostly 91-94, flat at times) and command have backed up a bit this year but they're still at least average, his slider has retained plus projection and he has a chance at a viable three-pitch mix, though the changeup is firm and clearly below average right now. GPE, upside traditional RF profile with plus raw power, plus arm, average underway speed, contact issues at present, signed for $1.8 million.

With PERSON departed, there is no center fielder in the system who can get to a fly ball or line drive like PERSON can. And his cannon arm also enables him to be a good right fielder. Offensively, he has well above-average raw power, but he still lacks in pitch selection and discipline while being super-aggressive at the plate, keeping him from tapping into that power consistently. On any given day, a scout could give him 70 and 80 grades across the board. But he needs to improve his emotional control and be pushed at times to reach what still appears to be a high ceiling. As one scout said, "He'll show the tools at 5 o'clock, but will it translate at 7?"

About as under-the-radar international signing as there can be, PERSON got just $10,000 to sign with the ORGANIZATION in the middle of the 2014-15 signing period. His changeup is clearly his third pitch, but the 87-mph offspeed offering has improved and could potentially approach PERSON average in the future.The one thing holding PERSON back has been his command. He's walked well over four batters per nine innings in his two years of full-season ball and even though he can maintain his stuff and might have three average or better pitches to work with, he will have to find the strike zone more consistently to remain a starter. Heading into the 2013 Draft, PERSON thought he was going to go in the third round to the ORGANIZATION or ORGANIZATION. He'll have to prove it against upper-level pitching, but many feel if you can hit a fastball, you have a chance to do some damage.

At 6-foot-1, 180, PERSON would look out of place in a team photo of big league first basemen, full of big-bodied mashers and explosive rotational athletes. His 2018 post-draft showing in the ORGANIZATION was impressive from a bat-to-ball standpoint and he took great at-bats and made hard contact during instructional league, though that was all against pitching comparable to what he saw in college. He's a sleeper bat we like but it's a tough profile, one he'll have to hit his way to.

PERSON is among the most advanced switch-hitting teenagers on the planet, possessing innate feel for contact from both sides of the plate despite what can sometimes be an awkward-looking swing. As of list publication, he has a plus-plus walk rate over about 150 pro plate appearances, enough to be confident that he has value-adding feel for the strike zone.  Not only that, but he is a potential 55 or 60 glove at short. PERSON procedurally advanced, PERSON will likely get quicker and more explosive as his body matures, but his frame is not so large that he projects to third base; he's a high-probability middle infielder. 
The quality of PERSON's contact may eventually result in power output beyond his raw grade. He'll be a star if that happens. If not, a defensive asset at short with a plus bat and excellent ball/strike recognition is still an everyday player.

PERSON spent most of his career as an underclassman in the ORGANIZATION bullpen and split time between the 'pen and roation this year. PERSON was regarded highly by scouts for his athleticism and multi-sport background (baseball/football) as a prep before he signed with the ORGANIZATION for $1.1 million as a second-round pick in 2008. He makes hard contact and uses the entire field, but offers little in the way of over-the-fence pop. As a right-handed hitter, PERSON's greatest strength is his ability to hit lefty pitchers. He's long struggled against same-side hurlers, though, in turn limiting his utility as a potential everyday player.PERSON is average both as a runner and a defender and continues to see time at all three outfield spots, but his fringy arm strength likely is best suited for left field at the highest level. Late-round 2018 pick from a GPE high school signed for $50,000 and has had a loud pro debut. He has a plus arm to profile in right field and above average raw power that he's already tapping into in games.

Like his former ORGANIZATION teammate PERSON, PERSON was a highly regarded prospect coming out of high school in 2010, but chose to attend college. His advanced bat made an immediate impact at ORGANIZATION, but he didn't improve as much as scouts would have liked and struggled a bit as a junior. PERSON still has plenty of potential as a hitter. He has big raw power and hit nine home runs last summer on Cape Cod, but was never able to tap into it much at ORGANIZATION. PERSON is a good defender at first base, but his future role will be tied to the development of his bat.

After signing with PERSON out of the ORGANIZATION in 2012, PERSON made his professional debut the following summer in the ORGANIZATION. His well-above-average arm, soft hands and good range give him all the tools necessary to become a solid defender. PERSON is the nephew of former Major Leaguer PERSON.

One of the more talented prospects cut loose by the ORGANIZATION during their international scandal, PERSON's fastball creeps into the mid-90s, and he has a good curveball and a sturdy build that is admittedly less projectable than is typical for a 19-year-old. It's exciting to consider how PERSON's stuff might play in the bullpen, as his max-effort delivery and the way it detracts from his command will likely prevent him from starting for long in pro ball. His arm action has gorgeous efficiency and it, plus PERSON's full-body thrust towards the plate, helped him generate the occasional mid-90s fastball early in his college starts, before he'd settle in the low-90s and upper-80s in the later innings. His breaking ball has bat-missing vertical action and is hard for hitters to differentiate out of PERSON's hand, in part because his delivery causes the ball to suddenly appear out from behind his head, which some hitters struggle to adjust to. Most of these traits would seem to play best in short stints, and we have PERSON projected as a good middle reliever, though if his fastball ticks up in single-inning outings he could be a high-leverage option.

Undrafted and barely recruited out of high school, PERSON was one of the most reliable power hitters in college baseball over the last three seasons. His throws lack accuracy and his hands and quickness are less than desirable at the hot corner. His well below-average speed figures to land him at first base, though he experimented with catching last fall.

As the 2017 college season got underway, PERSON was regarded as perhaps the top college bat in the country. We assume PERSON was hurt for much of 2018 (he threw just two ORGANIZATION innings) but it's unclear what ailed him. It sounds like only a small subset of teams were on GPE before the draft, and those that were hoped he'd keep a low profile on GPE's inconspicuous LOCATION. That he's still relatively new to starting gives him untapped potential in the role, too, and the hope is that he'll begin to miss more bats as he refines his secondary pitches.

"Big" is the operative word when discussing GPE. The 6-foot-2,182-pound shortstop has a big frame, big raw power and a big arm. GPE trains in GPE de GPE with PERSON and has also trained with former Major Leaguer PERSON and players from his academy in GPE. The ORGANIZATION have expressed serious interest in GPE.

PERSON was an intriguing infield prospect when he burst on to the international scene 18 months ago. He's even bigger, better and more interesting now. He's shown an above-average arm and all of the skills to stay at shortstop after he signs with a team and makes his way through their Minor League system. He has a chance to be an above-average defender when you put all of his skills together.At the plate, PERSON uses a slight upstroke swing lots of bat speed to generate flashes of average power. He's been able to hit home runs consistently and has made a habit of getting multiple hits in games. He doesn't strike out often. PERSON also runs the timed 60-yard run in 6.7 seconds and there is the belief that he will increase his speed as he grows and develops as a player.The teen projects to be an everyday shortstop with some pop in the ORGANIZATION if he continues to grow and develop at a normal pace. PERSON is trained by PERSON, who a member of ORGANIZATION's PERSON, in the ORGANIZATION. The Cubs are the favorites to sign him.

The grandson of former big league catcher PERSON, PERSON caught the eye of scouts by pitching well in the ORGANIZATION during the summer of 2015 and as a junior at FACILITY's (Calif.) the following spring. He has been even more effective in 2019 while jumping from Double-A to the big leagues.PERSON works at 90-93 mph and touches 95 mph with his fastball, which he can work to either side of the plate. It generates a surprising amount of swings and misses because its high spin rate creates the illusion that it rises. His slider also misses bats and serves as is his best secondary pitch, followed by his changeup and curveball.PERSON has some deception in his delivery that throws off hitters' timing, though he sometimes battles the strike zone as well. He has enjoyed more success against left-handers than right-handers, and he should have a floor as at least a situational reliever. But he continues to thrive as a starter and could get an opportunity in GPE's rotation before too long.

After initially looking like he was an egregious underdraft immediatley following his 2016 matriculation from ORGANIZATION, PERSON has been frustrating and enigmatic. Whatever the reasons for PERSON's struggles, he has hit. He has made progress as an infield defender, but he has to hit some to profile. He'll be 24 in May.

PERSON, a native of GPE, was originally signed by the ORGANIZATION in 2011. PERSON, who gets a ORGANIZATION comp, has been developed as a starter, but his stuff could also make him a dominant left-handed reliever.

The ORGANIZATION aren't afraid to buck the industry consensus in the GPE, and they did so by spending the 25th overall pick in the 2013 GPE and a $1,866,500 bonus to land PERSON. He won ORGANIZATION honors in the Rookie-level PERSON in his debut, then shook off a rough first month in low Class A and a thumb injury to finish second in the short-season LOCATION batting race (.333) in 2014.An accomplished amateur hitter who was named ORGANIZATION as the 18-and-under world championships in 2012, PERSON has tremendous hand-eye coordination and understands the strike zone, allowing him to repeatedly barrel balls. PERSON has just fringy speed and average athleticism, so most scouts outside the organization give him no chance to stay at shortstop. PERSON thinks he has underrated quickness and a chance to stick there. He probably profiles best as a third baseman and has the solid arm strength for the hot corner.

Another of the mid-round high school pitchers the ORGANIZATION paid over-slot bonuses in 2014, PERSON got the highest fifth-round bonus in the Draft at $1,000,000. He has some fade to his changeup but sometimes tips it off by slowing his arm speed, a correctable flaw. He's athletic but lacks size and true command, so some scouts believe he'll wind up in the bullpen.

As the ORGANIZATION know well, PERSON has produced several talented middle infielders over the years, and PERSON hopes to continue that line. PERSON has a strong arm and scouts believe he has the defensive skills necessary for shortstop. He's a long way from the big leagues, but his upside and impressive performance in his professional debut are cause for excitement.

ORGANIZATION Premier Event: Jan. 14, 2017 - ORGANIZATION MLB Team: PERSON ORGANIZATION MLB Player: PERSON was a 2015 Perfect Game Underclass High Honorable Mention and a member of the 2016 Perfect Game Underclass 3rd Team.The Stanford commit threw a perfect game in the 2014 GPE Cobb Invitational as a member of the ORGANIZATION, led his high school to the second round of the 2016 state playoffs and was named the ORGANIZATION at the inaugural PERSON, a tournament for the top national travel teams in the country, in September 2016.

GPE body comps to a young PERSON and is remarkably athletic for his size. PERSON was an athletic, multi-positional prospect at ORGANIZATION whose stock spiked close to draft time. He was considered a potential plus defensive catcher who might hit an empty .280. In the last year, PERSON has altered his stride in a way that has increased his in-game power rather significantly. He has terrific natural bat control and finds a way to get the barrel to various parts of the hitting zone and the change is offensive footwork didn't alter his peripherals. He remains a strong defensive catcthing prospect who now has a chance to hit for average and power while also moonlighting at second and third base when needed. He's an ORGANIZATION sequel who's perhaps two years from the Majors.

PERSON is a projectable athlete who brings to mind another former ORGANIZATION multisport star, PERSON Holliday. His father PERSON is the women's basketball coach there and the son would play for coach PERSON Holliday, PERSON's older brother.Scouts expected PERSON to hit for more power this spring, but instead he has produced more line drives. A former infielder, he has done a nice job of converting to the outfield and profiles best as a right fielder. He has the strong arm for the position and moves well for his size.

ORGANIZATION Premier Event: Feb. 4, 2017 - PERSON, GPEFavorite MLB Team: GPE ORGANIZATION MLB Player: PERSON, a Saint Mary's commit, has been a staple of ORGANIZATION since he was selected onto the 2013 14U ORGANIZATION Development Program roster. He impresses scouts with a 90-92 mph fastball that sneaks up on hitters and pairs the heater with a curveball and an occasional slider. He has the look of a reliever and has the ability to continue to develop.

PERSON pitched PERSON to the ORGANIZATION Division I ORGANIZATION in 2014 and himself into the seventh round of the 2015 Draft. His slider/cutter can be a solid pitch at times and he also can mix in a changeup to keep hitters off balance.Originally projected as a back-of-the-rotation starter, PERSON has made up for lost time by developing quickly as a reliever who's more than just a lefty specialist. The ORGANIZATION will have to keep him on their active roster all season, or else place him on waivers and offer him back to the ORGANIZATION for half of his $100,000 Draft price.

PERSON popped up pretty late, at a point in March when multiple clubs were sending in heat week after week to get some history. Some teams were out when they got multiple outings where he was mostly 84-89, while others are still hot on his trail. We saw him late when he was opening 90-93, cruising 88-91, and reaching back for 93 when he needed it. There's feel for a changeup and command, but this is a projection case and some have mentioned names like PERSON on where this could be headed. PERSON's summer started with a bang as he lit up radar guns at the ORGANIZATION. He was up to 96-97 mph in those summer outings, and sat in the mid 90s without too much effort, though he wasn't close to that when he first returned to action this spring. He has the prototypical projectable build at 6-foot-4 with room to add strength. PERSON throws two breaking balls, with scouts preferring his low-80s tight slider to his slow curveball, though he does show the ability to spin that as well. A 2013 international signee out of the ORGANIZATION, PERSON opened eyes the next year during his impressive professional debut in the ORGANIZATION. PERSON is an exception to the rule that high school second basemen aren't usually highly regarded as top pro prospects. His stock soared right before the 2013 Draft, and the ORGANIZATION didn't let him get past their second-round pick at ORGANIZATION. 66 overall.PERSON continued to raise his profile in pro ball, leading the Rookie-level Gulf Coast League with six home runs and a .924 ORGANIZATION. He has struggled in low Class A in 2014, but his bat-on-ball skills and his plus speed should help hit for average as he climbs the ladder. PERSON also has wiry strength and good pop for a middle infielder.PERSON's high baseball IQ and athleticism make him a fine defender at second base. He has quick feet and turns the double play well. GPE may give PERSON a chance to show what he can do at shortstop.

Some international prospects generate a ton of buzz and get huge seven-figure bonuses. Others sign for a lot less and end up being huge bargains. He should have an above-average fastball that he commands well, a solid curve and even a feel for his changeup. His secondary stuff is still inconsistent, though time is still very much on his side, even after missing most of the 2013 season.

A senior sign out of GPE in the 22nd round of the 2014 Draft, PERSON has already far exceeded expectations as a reliever getting close to knocking on the big league door. A sidearmer/underarmer, PERSON will throw his fastball in the 89-91 mph range from that arm slot. He throws it with heavy sink to generate a ton of ground-ball outs. He mixes in a very good changeup as well and then, to give hitters a surprising look, he'll go high three-quarters with his arm slot and deliver a 94 mph downhill fastball to miss bats. While he's closed games since joining the organization -- he led the ORGANIZATION system in saves in 2015 -- his ceiling is probably that of a middle reliever, but it's one he's close to reaching.

When the ORGANIZATION selected ORGANIZATION in the fifth round of the 2013 PERSON as one of the seven straight pitchers the organization selected to start that PERSON, the hope was the ORGANIZATION State product could use his pitchability to make a beeline to the big leagues. His fastball sits at 90-92 mph with some sink on account of his three-quarter action. His slider started to snap back into shape during his ORGANIZATION stint and serves as his go-to secondary pitch, featuring wipeout action that helps him induce whiffs. ORGANIZATION also throws an average changeup and is generally around the strike zone with his entire arsenal.ORGANIZATION's resurgence in 2018 was largely tied to his improved mental approach on the mound, as he showed aggressiveness and confidence that he had struggled to channel in previous seasons. Because he has an out pitch in his slider and a full repertoire, ORGANIZATION has the chance to be a No. 4 or 5 starter, or perhaps a solid long reliever in the big leagues.

A former two-sport standout who served as ORGANIZATION's backup quarterback and played four years of baseball as well, PERSON signed for $100,000 in the fifth round of the 2015 Draft, more than $200,000 under the pick value as a money-saving senior sign. With his athleticism and tools, though raw, the ORGANIZATION feel they may have gotten a real bargain.PERSON played second base during his senior year of college, but he's a full-time outfielder now. That should allow him to steal some bases and cover ground in the outfield, especially as he learns better reads and routes.
