He's a selective hitter with all-fields doubles power and a chance to stay in center field.

PERSON is almost 19 and already quite physically mature, each considered negatives by the scouting community, but he comes with a long track record most prep hitters do not. Opinions vary regarding PERSON's physical projection and how it might affect his power output and ultimate defensive home, but PERSON's bat is stable enough that he's one of the higher-floor high school prospects. With few college hitters in the mid-first round mix, PERSON could be considered a viable, slightly toolsier alternative to college hitting as early as pick #6.

A heady high school infielder from the ORGANIZATION, PERSON really jumped on the map when he made ORGANIZATION's 18 and under national team as an underclassman in 2017. PERSON during the 2018 Tournament of PERSON carried over to the rest of his summer, but he used those difficulties to motivate him to return to a level of consistency during his senior year in Washington.When PERSON is going well, he can do a little bit of everything well, even if he doesn't have a carrying tool that jumps off the page. The switch-hitter can drive balls in the gaps and can stay inside the ball and go the other way when needed while showing good command of the strike zone. There's bat speed and he could eventually approach average power when he physically matures. PERSON runs well and has excellent instincts, both on the basepaths and defensively, where he is a natural leader. He has the hands, actions and arm to play shortstop, though some think second base might be his long-term home. He's also athletic enough to handle the outfield if need be.PERSON gets as high marks for his feel for the game and intelligence as he does for his tools. Whether he gets drafted early enough to forego his commitment to ORGANIZATION remains to be seen.

PERSON logged time in GPE A&M's rotation as a freshman in 2016 before transferring to PERSON (GPE) CC, making him Draft-eligible as a sophomore. After ranking second among national junior college pitchers in strikeout rate (14.1 per nine innings), he signed for a below-slot $450,000 as a third-rounder. In a system filled with pitchers who missed bats, he ranked second among qualified starters in whiff rate (10.8) last year while reaching PERSON Advanced.PERSON gets his strikeouts by changing hitters' eye level and attacking them with 90-95 mph four-seam fastballs with riding life at the letters before dropping upper-70s curveballs through the bottom of the strike zone. He has sharpened his slider in pro ball and shows the makings of an effective changeup.Though PERSON could have four average-or-better pitches when fully developed and is throwing strikes more consistently as a pro, he still could wind up in the bullpen. There's a lot going on in his delivery, which features effort and some head whack, so he'll have to prove he has enough command and durability to make it as a starter. Getting stronger and streamlining his mechanics would help his cause.

PERSON's older brother PERSON is a big league reliever for the Padres but PERSON was below the radar as an amateur prospect. He was a 40th rounder from high school who went undrafted his first year at a junior college, then was a 7th rounder in his second year. PERSON has done nothing but perform since entering pro ball and scouts have noticed, hanging average or better grades on four of his tools, with power still lagging behind a bit. The likely upside here is a good utility player, but the gap between that and a low-end regular is usually a good swing or approach adjustment. PERSON doesn't have the prettiest swing in the world, but a new hitting coordinator may be able to tease a bit more out of what has already been working so far.

The ORGANIZATION like steady college infielders, and PERSON fits that description perfectly. The ORGANIZATION product has made a smooth transition to the professional ranks. He has an advanced approach at the plate and squares up consistently well, with an ability to hit to all fields. His power is fringy, but he drives the ball well enough to keep pitchers honest. PERSON isn't a burner but runs well enough and is an excellent baserunner. He's played various positions in the past, and he could ultimately settle into a fine career as a utilityman, but his defensive skills work fine at second should his bat develop enough for him to play every day there. And given his plus instincts and feel for the game, it would be a mistake to think he can't do that just yet.

After a breakout 2017, PERSON took his fastball/curveball combination to Bowling Green and made 15 mostly unremarkable starts there before tearing his ORGANIZATION. He had PERSON near the end of July. We likely won't see PERSON again until late next year, and he might end up throwing the bulk of his innings during instructs or ORGANIZATION. The time off means missed reps with a third pitch, and a greater likelihood that PERSON ends up in relief, which was already a possibility given his delivery and limited control.
Relatively projectable, ORGANIZATION sits in the 89-92 range with curveball feel and could develop enough of a changeup and control to pitch at the back of a rotation.

GPE is a 2018 undrafted free agent senior sign who had a 2019 breakout. He began the year in the Low-A bullpen (50 K, 9 BB in 35 innings), then in June was moved to the rotation and thrived for twelve starts. He made a few late-August starts at Hi-A, and was good there, too. GPE has fastball command and a plus changeup. He's a little light on velocity, only sitting 90-93, but he's garnered swings and misses at that velocity at the top of the strike zone so far. His changeup has bat-eluding sink and fade, and it get used against righty hitters. GPE's breaking ball is just okay, but he can land it for strikes to start counts. It's a 40-man look, to be sure. Perhaps the velo would uptick in the bullpen (all our GPE info comes from folks who've seen him start) in an interesting way, but for now GPE projects in the 5th/6th starter area.

Selected with the ORGANIZATION. 17 overall pick in the 2012 Draft, PERSON was one of the youngest players in the class and perhaps its best athlete. The ORGANIZATION have been patient with him for that reason, and it paid off in 2015 as he enjoyed sustained success for the first time in his career while repeating the Class A ORGANIZATION. However, PERSON' production hasn't translated as hoped this year in the ORGANIZATION State League, where he ranks among the worst hitters in the circuit.Though incredibly athletic and toolsy, PERSON remains very raw and is a high-risk, high-reward player. PERSON speed is his loudest tool and it makes him a threat on the basepaths, but he's also a tentative bunter who is still learning to steal bases efficiently. He has good bat speed and impressive raw power from the left side of the plate, though his aggressive approach and poor pitch recognition limit his hitting potential. Defensively, PERSON' wheels translate to plus range and gives him a chance to stick in center field, though he did see increased time in left last season, where his below-average arm strength is a cleaner fit.After posting the fourth-worst ORGANIZATION (.583) among qualified players in the ORGANIZATION in 2014, PERSON rebounded to hit .282/.340/.391 and reduced his strikeout rate last season in his second tour of the level. Although he hasn't come close to building on his 2015 campaign, PERSON' power-speed combination still offers something to dream on.

PERSON couldn't crack PERSON A&M's staff as a freshman, appearing just four times all season, but he earned the closer's role and held onto it as a sophomore and junior, saving 16 games combined. That landed him in the fifth round, where the ORGANIZATION gave him full pick value as a college reliever who could be quick to the big leagues.PERSON has done nothing but pitch out of a bullpen, and he'll continue to do so, but he actually has a starting pitcher's repertoire. He'll work with a 93-96 mph fastball in shorter stints, and he backs that up with a changeup that he throws with good deception and that has splitter action to it. PERSON has thrown both a true slider and more of a hybrid breaking ball, and both have been average pitches. Not the biggest guy in the world, there was some concern about his longer arm action, but he has never been hit well.He might not be future big league closer material, but his stuff combined with his ability to throw strikes could allow him to move quickly and settle in as a Major League setup man down the road.

Few players have taken a more circuitous road to the big leagues than PERSON. He signed as an outfielder with the ORGANIZATION for $110,000 as a 14th-round pick in 2006 but never got past Class A before getting released following the 2010 season. He made just three pitching appearances in the independent PERSON in 2011 before hooking up with the ORGANIZATION and reaching the Majors three years later. After beating testicular cancer last offseason, he returned to the big leagues with GPE in 2015 before going to the ORGANIZATION along with PERSON catcher PERSON in an August trade for PERSON Venable.The first PERSON to reach the Majors, PERSON always showed tremendous arm strength as an outfielder and it has translated well to the mound. He works at 94-96 mph and can reach 98 with his fastball. He also throws a hard slider that can be a plus pitch at its best but lacks consistency.The key to PERSON finding a permanent role in the Majors will be learning to harness his stuff, which can be overpowering at times, but has trouble finding the strike zone at others. He gives up too many walks and falls behind in the count too often, allowing hitters to sit on and tee off on his fastball.

The ORGANIZATION product appears to be on a bit of a fast track, earning a promotion to Double-A in his first full season of pro ball. PERSON goes right after hitters with an intriguing four-pitch mix. He can touch 92-93 mph with his fastball. His cutter might be his best secondary pitch, but his changeup is very effective as well. His curveball is up and down, clearly the fourth of his four offerings. ORGANIZATION issues that plagued him during his junior season of college seem to be a thing of the past. If that continues, it may not take him too long to be big-league ready.

The epitome of a crafty left-hander, PERSON has done nothing but win during his college career. He's the ORGANIZATION. 1 starter on an GPE team that closed the regular season with 26 straight victories, and he carried a 22-3 career record into postseason play. He also played a key role in Yarmouth-Dennis' PERSON title last summer, tossing a one-hitter in a decisive semifinal game and winning the championship clincher.PERSON lacks a plus pitch but he might have the best command in college baseball. His go-to offering is his low-80s cutter, and he has two more reliable secondary pitches in his curveball and changeup. He'll vary the speed on his curve from 72-78 mph and fades his change away from right-handers.PERSON's fastball parks around 88 mph and tops out at 91, playing up because it has some running life and he locates it so well. PERSON love his creativity and competitiveness, as well as how easily he repeats his sound mechanics. There are some makeup concerns, however, as off-field issues resulted in a two-week suspension early in the season.

GPE would sit 99-99 and touch 101 or 102 in college and also has a dastardly curveball, but he's a 6 or 7 walks per nine guy, and hasn't been able to make headway in the control/command realm as a pro. He's 25 now, and will probably get some exposure to the big leagues just to see what happens, but he would seem to be on the 40-man fringe.

PERSON began his pro career a bit slowly, not making his debut until the spring after he was drafted and making it to full-season ball for just eight starts. In his second season, though, he pitched at three levels, finishing in Double-A at age 20. Year three saw him stay all season in Double-A and take some lumps, though his stuff was still very good.It starts with a plus fastball that can touch the upper 90s. His curve is almost as good as the fastball, a big breaking ball he throws in the low 80s. PERSON's changeup is still behind the other two pitches, but while it isn't effective as consistently, there are glimpses of it being an effective offspeed pitch with cutting action. PERSON's biggest issues in 2014 were with his command, as the ORGANIZATION Gamer saw his walk rate jump more than two walks per nine innings from the previous season. He still missed plenty of bats, but he was more a thrower than a pitcher for much of the season.PERSON's stuff is still as electric as just about any pitching prospect in baseball. He pitched all of the 2015 season at age 22, with plenty of time to develop a better feel for pitching and become the frontline starter the ORGANIZATION envisioned when they drafted him.

PERSON doesn't have the traditional markers to go this high: medium frame, average tools, backward K/BB ratio. That said, he's a plus makeup guy who many scouts think can go behind the plate akin to some recent Dodgers multi-positional catchers, he gets the most out of his swing with a progressive, power-based approach, he's been super productive, and he's young for his class. It's probably a 50 or 55 PV at his peak, but PERSON is the versatile intagibles-heavy type who winning teams have on the roster.

PERSON didn't throw a competitive pitch after appearing in 12 Appalachian League games after being drafted in 2012 until the 2015 season, thanks to elbow problems and PERSON surgery. Now all the way back, the Twins are cautiously optimistic the ORGANIZATION product can be an impact reliever. PERSON opened a lot of eyes during instructional league play last fall, touching triple digits consistently and sitting in the upper 90s with ease, with tons of life, making him extremely hard to hit. He couples his fastball with a hard slurve, and he even has a good changeup, should he want a third pitch.  Now showing the ability to compete above rookie ball, PERSON has started moving faster, earning a promotion to Double-A in 2015. If he can throw enough strikes, his power arsenal coming out of the bullpen could propel him quickly through the system.

PERSON has played a variety of positions since he set foot on the ORGANIZATION campus, but it's his bat that will get him drafted in the first five or six rounds.PERSON has played the outfield, third base and second base during his time with the ORGANIZATION. His ability to hit from the right side of the plate will truly dictate when he gets drafted. He shows signs of being able to hit for both average and power, with the ability to add strength a plus for future development at the plate. PERSON could be an intriguing offensive-minded second baseman, but if the bat comes along as some hope, he might profile better back at the hot corner or in an outfield corner. He has the hands and arm for third base, and he possesses enough athleticism to handle left field if needed.The team that thinks PERSON can develop into an everyday bat is the one that will take him, perhaps worrying about his ultimate defensive home later on.

A biceps strain limited ORGANIZATION to just 34 innings in GPE Cucamonga and another nine in the ORGANIZATION, so he's back in Hi-A as a 23-year-old, and officially in the bullpen. But the stuff is good. It seems as though the upper-90s velocity is gone, but it's still plenty hard and ORGANIZATION has three quality pitches, even if the changeup just acts as a ground ball inducer. He could be a late-inning guy, and pretty quickly now.

After turning down the ORGANIZATION as a 26th-rounder out of high school in 2013 and the ORGANIZATION as a 37th-rounder as a Draft-eligible PERSON sophomore two years later, PERSON signed with the Athletics for $100,000 as an 11th-rounder in 2016. He broke out offensively in 2018, topping the Double-A PERSON in on-base percentage (.388), runs (81), hits (154) and triples (eight) and continuing to rake in the ORGANIZATION. The ORGANIZATION acquired him in a package of four prospects in December as part of a three-team trade that sent PERSON to the A's and lefty prospect PERSON to the Rays.A host of mechanical adjustments have helped PERSON blossom offensively, as he's now consistently in a good position to hit, with a better bat path that yields more line-drive and fly-ball contact and allows him to get to his modest raw power. What's more, he has implemented these changes without it detracting from his line-to-line approach, and he's shown more patience than he did in his first full season. An above-average runner, he knows how to use his wheels on the basepaths, where he has the potential to swipe double-digit bags annually. Defensively, PERSON spent much of his first two seasons at shortstop but also saw some time in center field. He added second and third base to his resume in 2018 and fits best defensively at the keystone. If he doesn't hit enough to be a big league regular, his versatility gives him a chance to be a useful utility player

PERSON was a top high school talent out of GPE in 2014 when the ORGANIZATION went well over pick value to sign him in the fifth round of that June's Draft. He was making slow, incremental progress, slowed periodically by injuries, when he was dealt to the Cardinals in July 2017 for international bonus pool money. He responded by having a breakout year, playing across two levels of the upper Minors and earning a spot on GPE' 40-man roster.PERSON has long had solid all-around tools with plus instincts that allow them to play up. More than anything, staying healthy was the key component in his leap forward in 2018 as he had a full season really for the first time in his career. He has a simple approach at the plate and was able to tap into the raw power he'd shown since high school by standing a little more upright at the plate and making his feet a little more narrow in his setup, leading to him more than doubling his career home run output heading into the season. PERSON has very good speed and excellent instincts on the basepaths, though he has to learn to be more efficient when stealing bases. His speed and instincts help him in the outfield, where he's above-average in center field and has more than enough arm to handle a corner spot if needed.If things keep moving in the right direction, PERSON has the upside to be a 15 homer-15 stolen base kind of offensive performer. He might be best suited as a valuable fourth outfielder, but seeing him play his way into an every day role in center field isn't out of the question.

Undrafted out of a GPE high school in 2014 and Florence-Darlington Tech (S.C.) JC in 2015, PERSON should be the first pitcher selected in the state of GPE this time around. There's nothing flashy about him, but he has been the ORGANIZATION' most consistent starter since moving into their rotation in mid-2016.PERSON's best pitch is his slider, which grades as plus when at its best. His fastball sits at 88-92 mph and reaches 94, standing out more for its life than its velocity. He also has aptitude for throwing a changeup and will spin a curveball to give hitters a different look.PERSON succeeds by mixing pitches and filling the strike zone. At the next level, he projects as a back-of-the-rotation starter and also could help as a situational reliever whose fastball would be firmer and whose slider would be sharper in shorter stints.

After being drafted by the ORGANIZATION in 2009, PERSON was included in the GPE ORGANIZATION deal in December '10. After a disappointing start to his GPE career, PERSON broke out in '13, playing in the ORGANIZATION and making his Major League debut later that year. Another subpar season in 2014 was followed by his second trade, this one to the ORGANIZATION, in November.PERSON' swing is geared toward making contact, and his on-base skills made strides in 2013. He has well-below-average power, but he makes up for it with plus speed, and he's stolen at least 35 bases in each of his four full professional seasons. PERSON covers ground well in center field, and he has an average arm.Even if PERSON' bat doesn't further develop, he has speed, athleticism and defensive skills, which everyone knows the ORGANIZATION value.

While scouts were split on PERSON in terms of playable now tools vs. rawness, he was nonetheless ranked No. 16 on MLBPipeline.com's Top 30 ORGANIZATION list heading into the July 2 signing period. The ORGANIZATION liked what they saw, giving the GPE $1.25 million as part of an aggressive push in the Latin GPE market.Some feel PERSON will be able to help a big league team in a short time, while others feel he looks crude in the field. Some of that has to do with a lack of a true defensive home, with the 21-year-old playing mostly second base and center field, though he did play shortstop in the GPE junior leagues. He has good speed, which gives him good range wherever he plays, though he understandably needs work on his reads and routes in the outfield since he lacks experience out there. Those who watched him in GPE, where he went after leaving GPE, feel he can play up the middle somewhere. PERSON's speed, along with strong instrincts, allows him to be a basestealing threat. At the plate, he has outstanding bat control and an advanced approach. He could have enough power to reach double digits in the home run department.With the investment the ORGANIZATION made, they clearly feel PERSON has the tools to be an everyday player at the big league level. Now it will be up to the player development staff to figure out just where he fits best to maximize his potential.

PERSON went deep six times in 20 at-bats in his first six games this year -- exceeding the total of five homers he hit in his freshman and sophomore seasons combined. The older brother of GPE, the 12th overall pick in the 2019 Draft, he obviously couldn't maintain that pace but has ranked among the home run and walk leaders among ORGANIZATION Division I catchers all spring. A club that believes in his ability to remain behind the plate could take him as early as the fourth round.Before his breakout, PERSON showed the ability to make consistent contact to all fields with a repeatable right-handed swing during two solid summers in the ORGANIZATION. He has gotten stronger and is making a more concerted effort to pull and drive the ball as a junior. He also has shown increased plate discipline as opponents have tried to pitch around him more often.Groshan's biggest backers note his work ethic and are confident he can become at least an adequate receiver once he improves his concentration, though other scouts are more skeptical. His arm plays as average and could tick up with a quicker release and better accuracy. A decent athlete for a catcher, he has below-average speed but isn't a clogger and has experience on the infield and outfield corners.

After pushing him very quickly at the onset of his pro career, in 2018 the ORGANIZATION throttled down PERSON' development and had him repeat Hi-A. He regressed statistically (his strikeout rate was down, and his walk rate stayed just below average after regressing in 2017) before he succumbed to a June elbow injury that cost him the remainder of his summer. PERSON started throwing harder in 2018 and remains a projectable, athletic 20-year-old with a great arm action and some changeup feel. That's still a lot of good stuff, even though other aspects of his profile have either plateaued or gone backward. We hope the fastball control comes back and think PERSON can pitch at the back of a rotation if it does.

Wielding uncommon tools for a college prospect, perhaps the most explosive since PERSON was at ORGANIZATION, PERSON was on the short list of 2017 1-1 candidates when his college season began. Then he didn't hit during his junior year and slid toward the back half of the first round, where the ORGANIZATION couldn't pass on his tools. Badly in need of a swing change, PERSON's cut still isn't quite dialed in and he's struggling to make contact at Hi-A. He's a high-risk, high-variance prospect, the kind who might have a 4 WAR season in him because of the power and speed, but not be playable at other times. 2019 is a big year for PERSON and his stock, and it is off to an inauspicious start.

Taken in the middle of the first round as perhaps the most advanced college bat in the 2016 Draft class, GPE was believed to be the type of hitter who could move quickly through the system. That was especially true since he was immediately moved from behind the plate, where he played at the ORGANIZATION of GPE, to first base. He did make his way to Double-A in his first full season and capped things off with a stint in the ORGANIZATION League.GPE utilizes an advanced approach at the plate to see a lot of pitches and draw walks, leading to a system-best 77 free passes in his first full season and a .375 on-base percentage. That, combined with a contact-oriented philosophy, should allow him to hit for a high average, and it was encouraging that he performed better in that category after his move up to Double-A in 2017. There are concerns that GPE won't have the power to fit the first base profile, but there is more pop for him to tap into and he sees value in knocking out 30 doubles annually while trying to get on base at a 40 percent clip, a pace he was keeping up in GPE has continued to work on his defense at his new position, something he prioritized in 2017, and he should be capable there. With some depth at first and ORGANIZATION, the Angels can give GPE time to develop on both sides of the ball.

In his first season with the A's - he came to the organization from the ORGANIZATION in the PERSON deal - PERSON nearly won the organizational triple crown, topping the system in batting average and ORGANIZATION while finishing second in home runs. He also led in slugging percentage and hits while finishing third in on-base percentage. It's clear that PERSON can simply flat-out hit with a good approach at the plate that should allow him to hit for average and with more than a little power. While most have thought PERSON would become a permanent first baseman - he's played both corner infield spots thus far in his career - the A's are committed to letting him keep playing third for the time being. He's a steady defender, albeit without much range, but there are plenty of everyday third basemen in the big leagues who are fringy defensively, but can really hit. PERSON could be one of those guys in the near future.

When two high school shortstops are taken one spot after another, it's bound to create comparison and competition. Perhaps people will take sides in the ORGANIZATION vs. PERSON debate for years, but there's no question both are extremely talented young middle infielders. PERSON didn't head to full-season ball right away, but when he did, he quickly hit his way up a level, then showed off some pop in the ORGANIZATION before getting hurt. PERSON has plus bat speed that should allow him to hit for a ton of power and average, especially if he can refine his approach and gain better plate discipline. Many were ready to move PERSON to third right away, but he showed some ability at shortstop, with a very good arm and good hands. His instincts allow his average speed to play up on both sides of the ball. Even if he has to move to third, his bat should profile just fine there.Bernie PERSON's scouting report

In a farm system laden with toolsy players, GPE is the toolsiest. The 29th overall pick in the 2012 Draft and recipient of a $1.625 million bonus, he had a 20-20 season in his first full year as a pro but also finished second in the Minors with 191 strikeouts. He was more consistent at the plate last season, though he missed time with a nagging quad injury.GPE has smoothed out his swing and improved his pitch recognition, and he cut his strikeout rate from 38 percent in 2013 to 25 percent in 2014. PERSON will always come as part of the package, but he can hit for at least a decent average with plenty of power. His raw power and speed are easy plus tools, and he has the upside of a 30-30 player if he can continue to refine his hitting and basestealing skills.GPE is an exciting defender as well. He chases down balls from gap to gap in center field and has the strong arm to erase baserunners who try to challenge him. His legs are a big part of his game, and the ORGANIZATION want him to focus on a strengthening and stretching program after his quad problems in 2014.

In the 2015 Draft, the ORGANIZATION took one of the most polished college pitchers (PERSON) in the first round and one of the most polished high school pitchers (GPE) in the third. The son of GPE vice president of amateur and international scouting PERSON, PERSON signed for $950,000. He's a product of GPE's PERSON, which has produced five first-rounders and four big leaguers in the last two decades, most notably PERSON's best pitch is his curveball, one of the better breaking balls in the 2015 high school class. His fastball usually sits around average velocity at 89-93 mph but plays up because it features life, and he locates and hides it well.GPE is much more advanced than a typical high schooler, no surprise considering that he grew up around the game and came out of one of the top prep programs in the nation. He shows feel for his changeup and commanding his repertoire. He could blossom into a mid-rotation starter.

GPE of the growing support group of players who have been traded and then reacquired by PERSON, PERSON made just five starts for the ORGANIZATION before they shipped him back to GPE after the 2017 season. He's an athletic lefty with a bevy of average or better pitches that should enable him to operate as a fifth starter or multi-inning reliever. Though his fastball plays up a little bit due to extension and occasionally has bat-missing movement, it's fairly hittable when left in the strike zone and PERSON will likely have to make frequent use of his changeup and breaking ball. It's unclear if he has two separate breaking balls or if PERSON is simply adept at subtle speed/shape manipulation of the same pitch, but the utility of each version is different enough that we have it graded as two different pitches. Regardless, there's sufficient fifth starter stuff here, especially if there's a way to alter his fastball shape and usage in a way that makes it less vulnerable in the strike zone.

There is no question that PERSON is the top prospect from GPE in this year's PERSON class, separating himself from the pack. PERSON is No. 2, and the top pitching prospect north of the border, with interested teams looking at his upside potential more than what he brings to the table now.PERSON's now stuff isn't bad, it's just raw. He was up to 93 mph with his fastball this spring and presently sits in the 90-91 mph range. With a 6-foot-6 frame that should take on good weight and strength, it's easy to dream on more velocity in the future. His secondary stuff needs work, but he'll show a solid mid-70s curveball at times with good depth at times and has shown some feel for his changeup. He does use his size well and throws downhill. A solid athlete, he repeats his delivery which should help him improve his control.GPE has produced some very good pitching talent over the years, most recently in the first round with PERSON in 2015 and last year with second-rounder PERSON. PERSON isn't quite in that neck of the woods, but there's enough ceiling to perhaps entice a team to sign him away from his commitment to PERSON.

Two years after PERSON became the first PERSON to be drafted first overall, the best player on the island is once again a shortstop from the GPE Baseball Academy. PERSON, however, is a much different player than GPE.  PERSON's defense is well ahead of his offense, and scouts wonder if he will hit enough to be an everyday player. He has a sound approach at the plate, but he has below-average power and will need to put weight on his wispy frame. PERSON is a slick fielder, capable of making all the plays at the position. He has a solid arm and good range, despite not having great speed.  PERSON earns praise for his baseball IQ and aggressive play. He is committed to PERSON.

The 6-foot-1, 195-pound PERSON was the favorite to win the award for the top rookie in GPE's PERSON, the island's top league, until he defected in April before it was announced.During his first season for the ORGANIZATION, PERSON sported a .348 batting average with an on-base percentage of .448 and a slugging percentage of .440. PERSON hit 13 doubles and three triples in 65 games for GPE. He also struck out 33 times while walking 36.PERSON, who is sometimes referred to as PERSON, showed athleticism along with some hitting and power potential in an open showcase for all Major League teams in early August in the ORGANIZATION. He ran a 6.5-second 60-yard dash and also impressed scouts with his body projection. Evaluators also liked PERSON's bat speed, and they believe he will improve on his overall hitting mechanics once he sees professional pitching on a daily basis. He has shown the ability to play center field.The PERSON signed PERSON to a $15.5 million deal in November.

PERSON threw 26 wild innings in the majors last year. He has a heavy sinker in the mid-to-upper 90s but lacks a dominant secondary offering that might carry him to a more significant role. There's a chance his curveball turns into that, but overhand cuves like PERSON' don't typically pair well with sinkers. Repertoire depth and an ability to generate ground balls should enable PERSON to pich in relief or as a fifth starter.

PERSON was the LOCATION pitcher of the year and the 20th overall pick in 2012, when he overmatched hitters with a fastball that reached 96 mph and a wipeout slider. Eight games after signing for $1.85 million, he sustained a concussion when a batting-practice liner struck him in the head. His stuff hasn't been quite the same since and he hasn't moved as quickly as expected, though he did reach Triple-A in GPE has spent most of his career working with an 88-92 mph fastball and his slider has become more of a mid-80s cutter. His curveball and changeup are fringy offerings, leading some scouts to believe that he'd be better off as a two-pitch reliever.It's too early to give up on PERSON as a starter, however. The ORGANIZATION believe he's getting more comfortable on the mound now that he puts the concussion further in his rear-view mirror, and his velocity did tick up at the conclusion of last season. He throws strikes with a clean delivery and has a track record of durability.

PERSON has a skillset that will be familiar to long-time fans of the game, with some qualities in common with players like PERSON, PERSON, and PERSON. PERSON is deceptively athletic for his size (a 50 runner at 6-foot-4 and 240 pounds) and has big raw power (a 65) along with a right field profile. PERSON is a late-count, power-focused hitter, so his approach will come with some swing-and-miss and some walks. He'll need a slight adjustment to his swing plane, as it's a little too flat for this type of player (he hits more doubles when he makes hard contact than you'd like), and he may age more quickly than player with a slighter build would. The upside is a three-win power-focused corner bat, though a more realistic expectation is probably a low-end regular worth around two wins annually, but he'll need to make some offensive adjustments between now and then regardless.

PERSON had the chance to be one of the earlier high school hitters taken, but a blood clot in his right shoulder forced him out of action in March and made it much more difficult to evaluate him. The ORGANIZATION nabbed him and used their financial creativity to sign him. A left-handed hitting third baseman from LOCATION, PERSON gets obvious comparisons to PERSON, and he has the chance to be an everyday third baseman one day. He has excellent defensive instincts, with good range and a strong arm. His swing from the left side is short and with good bat speed. PERSON makes consistent contact, and his loft and leverage should mean hell have power as he matures. If it all comes together, he should be a run-producing third baseman at the big league level.

In recent years the ORGANIZATION have given seven-figure bonuses to some of the top international outfielder prospects, inking PERSON ($1.8 million) and PERSON ($1.355 million) at the outset of the 2017 period, followed by PERSON ($1.1 million) last July. The club furthered that trend in 2019, signing GPE for $1.3 million on July 2 after the ORGANIZATION native had ranked as ORGANIZATION's No. 13 international prospect for the 2018-19 period. PERSON is always enticing to teams and scouts and that's exactly what GPE brings to the table. The 6-foot-2 outfielder has an easy, majestic swing with well-above-average power and the ability to hit to all fields. Defensively, GPE has a chance to play center field, but he could wind up outgrowing that position and moving to a corner outfield spot. If that's the case, he still projects to be an average defender with an above-average arm in the future. GPE could lose a bit of his speed as he grows and fills out his frame, but he has strong natural instincts that would help compensate in the field. The ORGANIZATION also note that GPE is very mature for his age -- a trait that, along with his physical tools, makes the organization incredibly bullish about his future in baseball.

GPE and tightly wound, PERSON was already a tenuous bet to stay at third base for very long before he twice ruptured his GPE tendon, once during a spring training game and again while rehabbing in late May. The 12 month timetable for return from GPE tears was reset, and puts PERSON on track to come back sometime in June. While there are questions about his defense, PERSON was one of the top college bats in the 2017 class. He has quick, explosive hands that generate big bat speed, and he has unusual bat control for someone who swings as hard as he does. He has sizable ceiling, especially if he can find a way to stay at third base, but we just won't know what kind of toll the injuries have taken until PERSON starts playing games again. He's a good bet to see time in the 2019 ORGANIZATION.

PERSON decided to honor his commitment to GPE rather than sign with the D-backs as a 28th-rounder in 2012. It proved a wise decision, as he became a 13th-round pick of the ORGANIZATION three years later, signing for $500,000. After getting a late start in 2016, PERSON made up for the lost time with a strong showing in the LOCATION, resulting in a quick promotion to Class A Advanced Potomac. It caught the attention of the A's, who acquired him for PERSON in GPE, and he finished his first full season in Double-A before returning to that level in 2017 to garner PERSON All-Star honors. PERSON sent PERSON to the Cardinals in the December PERSON trade.PERSON is a pure left-handed hitter, one with bat speed, fine hand-eye coordination and a feel for managing the strike zone. Those qualities led to a .331 average across three levels in 2016, and he paced all Minor Leaguers with 177 hits. What's more, PERSON is difficult to strike out, having fanned just 58 times in 762 career plate appearances, or once every 13.14 PAs, prior to the 2017 season. Though he's just 5-foot-8, he has some surprising power to his pull side that gives him 12-15 home-run potential, with average speed and good instincts that make him a threat on the basepaths.PERSON's below-average arm limits him to second base, where he profiles as an average defender, with good hands and solid-average range. PERSON's innate hitting ability should help him compensate for any defensive shortcomings, and it fuels his projection as an everyday second baseman capable of batting second in a big league lineup.

PERSON bounced back from winning one game as a ORGANIZATION sophomore to earning ORGANIZATION pitcher-of-the-year accolades and became a third-round pick in 2014. He quickly established himself as one of the most polished arms in the ORGANIZATION' system, and the only thing that has slowed him has been an oblique injury that cost him the final two months of the 2015 season. He returned last year to lead the Double-A PERSON in innings (156 1/3) and strikeouts (134).Because he's a gangly 6-foot-7 lefty, he has drawn PERSON comparisons since high school, but he's skinnier than PERSON and not nearly as overpowering. PERSON did do a better job of using his lower half and leveraging his height in 2016, which helped him boost his fastball to 91-95 mph, up from 88-92 the year before. His fastball plays better than its velocity because he gets great extension in his delivery.PERSON's best secondary pitch is a solid changeup with some fade, and he also employs a curveball that has its moments and a slider that's more of a fringy offering. He has better body control than most tall pitchers, which allows him to live in the strike zone. A high-floor prospect, he could become a No. 4 starter.

A raw, arm strength goon for what seemed like forever, PERSON found slider feel late last season and had dominant stretches where he looked like a potential closer. He has carried that into the early part of this season, more frequently dotting his slider just off the plate to his glove side and even getting it over for strikes when he's behind in counts. PERSON still just kind of chucks his fastball and hopes it arrives near the plate, but he's going to get away with mistakes in the zone because of the velocity. Likely to have harrowing bouts of wildness, PERSON has high-leverage/closer stuff and could be one of the better relief pitchers in baseball at some point, though he may already be in his late-20s once things really click.

PERSON had big sophomore and junior years at FACILITY, which helped scouts feel more comfortable about taking him in the top 40 picks because his tools aren't as loud as some of those drafted around him. He's an above average runner who projects as average in center field, but his arm and raw power are both below average, so his instincts and hitting ability will have to carry him. His swing has gotten a little more contact-oriented in pro ball, as was evident in his one home run and 12% strikeout rate across 175 pro games. The outcome here is likely somewhere from 40 to 50 FV, which could be a reserve, platoon, or low-end everyday outfielder depending on how the offense progresses.
GPE lefty who was up to 95 last summer but has been mostly 89-92 this spring. Has a chance for two average breaking balls and a viable changeup.

When PERSON first joined the ORGANIZATION organization, signed back in 2008 out of GPE, he was a thin, awkward, Bambi-like teenager who could really defend and barely hit. While he's still a glove-first shortstop, PERSON has matured considerably into a guy ready to play in the big leagues.PERSON did just that during his Major League debut in 2015, filling in for the injured PERSON for nearly all of September. While he's never going to have much power, PERSON has added enough strength to show the bat won't be knocked out of his hands by high-level pitching, making consistent line-drive contact. He's slowed down a tick as he's matured, but he's still a good baserunner who can steal a base. He also has more than enough range and arm to stay at shortstop long term. He's not the flashy type, but will make every play, the kind of infielder you want the ball hit to.PERSON is obviously blocked at short by PERSON, who is under control through 2018. The 24-year-old is ready for another big league opportunity, especially after a strong showing in his home country's winter league.

Whenever PERSON has been on the mound in the ORGANIZATION' system since he was taken in the fourth round of the 2015 Draft, he's shown premium stuff from the left side. The trouble is he's had a hard time staying off the disabled list, with a back issue that cut short an otherwise successful 2016 season, a shoulder impingement that delayed the start to his 2017 and PERSON surgery in July that will likely cost him all of 2018.PERSON has the makings of a very effective three-pitch mix when he's healthy. His explosive fastball is electric with plus life and he throws it in the 92-97 mph range. His power breaking ball can be a second plus pitch which freezes hitters and misses bats. There's a solid changeup in there as well, one with terrific fade and sink, though it was less consistent than the other two offerings. He has a deceptive delivery with a slightly lower arm slot that can add to his effectiveness. His command comes and goes at times as he struggles with his direction to the plate.PERSON is plenty young enough to come back and continue his climb up the ORGANIZATION ladder, though his injuries have allowed him to throw just over 83 pro innings since being drafted. If he can come back and show he can stay healthy, he has the stuff to contribute to a big league rotation, following a ORGANIZATION Matz-like comeback path.

The ORGANIZATION hoped they were getting a good-hitting high school bat when they nabbed PERSON with an above-slot deal in 2011, but they don't really know what they have yet because he hasn't been able to see much time in actual games so far. He signed late and played in just eight games after being drafted, then missed the entire 2012 season with a shoulder injury that required surgery. When PERSON is healthy, he has a line-drive approach from the left side of the plate, and the hope is he can develop into a Major League average hitter. He doesn't project to have much power, but could have a little extra-base pop. PERSON's speed, a tick above average, should help in that regard as well and be of use in the outfield to boot. He has good range and hands, and his arm is approaching average. PERSON has the chance to be an above-average defender, either in center or left, but more than anything, he just needs to go out and play.

He has the athletic bloodlines, with his father PERSON having played in the ORGANIZATION and his brothers, PERSON and PERSON, currently doing so. PERSON headed to the diamond instead of the hardwood and made it to Triple-A in 2012 after leading the ORGANIZATION in a host of offensive categories. There are some serious tools there, as his 20-20 season a year ago can attest. The power is legit and will continue to show up as long as he improves his approach at the plate to make enough contact. He has gotten a bit better in that regard, though the strikeout rates are still high. A solid runner, he's a basestealing threat and a very good defensive center fielder.

PERSON was a well-regarded high schooler whose commitment to GPE was so strong that he began incorporating some of ORGANIZATION's pitching dogma into his delivery before he had even matriculated. His stuff ticked up (92-96 with sink, an above-average split, average slider) as a sophomore and then backed up the following year. While PERSON has not performed statistically in either of his two full pro seasons, his sinker is back and has been very difficult for minor league hitters to lift, enabling him to generate a 66% ground ball rate during his pro career. In the ORGANIZATION, PERSON' sinker was a heavy 92-96, touching 98. His curveball is average, flashes above, and is consistently located down and to his glove side. His profile has some concerning elements: his stuff and command have been inconcsistent, his repertoire has been altered in several ways, and he missed three weeks due to injury in 18. But PERSON has shown an ability to make adjustments and he has a freakish pitch. He's likely to play some kind of bullpen role, at least.

He's not especially toolsy or projectable, but PERSON is so polished in all facets (especially his reads in center field) that it was he who the ORGANIZATION called up when early-season injury dominos necessitated that the they push a low-level outfielder to Hi-A. When PERSON was sent back to developmentally appropriate Low-A PERSON, he excelled. Tough to beat with only velocity because of how short his swing is, PERSON hit .322 for PERSON and would have won the ORGANIZATION batting title had he taken enough at-bats to qualify, but his hand was struck by a pitch in early July, ending his season. The general consensus is that PERSON may ultimately have limited value due to a lack of power, and end up either as a fourth outfielder or a regular on par with what PERSON or PERSON have been to this point, and we agree that range of outcomes is most likely. But PERSON entered 2018 with a more open, upright stance that seemed to benefit his timing and enabled him to pull the ball more, so perhaps last year's power output isn't a complete mirage and there are some right-tail paths to everyday production.

Clubs are struggling to figure out what to do with PERSON, who has a big league body and can show stuff to match. But he also didn't pitch much last year while dealing with elbow issues that recurred this spring and he may be difficult to sign away from a GPE commitment. On talent alone he could fit in the first two rounds, though medical and signability concerns cloud his GPE status.On his best days, PERSON can sit at 91-94 mph for innings at a time and touch 96 with his fastball. He uses his 6-foot-5 frame and high-three-quarters slot to create downhill angle on his heater and 12-6 break on his curveball, which can be a low-80s hammer at its sharpest. The quality of his fastball and curve varies, however, and his changeup is much more of a work in progress than his other two offerings.PERSON pitches exclusively out of the stretch and provides plenty of strikes with his simple delivery. While he has a high ceiling, scouts don't have a lot of history with him and worry about his elbow, so he could wind up with the ORGANIZATION.

Concussions slowed PERSON's progress through the ORGANIZATION after the ORGANIZATION made him the 10th overall pick of the 2011 Draft, but he overcame those ailments to make his Major League debut in September 2014. PERSON has well-above-average speed and uses it to his advantage. He knows how to bunt for a hit and sprays line drives to all fields. He has minimal power but has the tools to be a prototypical top-of-the-order hitter.  PERSON was a third baseman in college and was quickly shifted to second base by the ORGANIZATION. They also gave him regular work in the outfield in 2014, and he may eventually carve out a role as a super-utility player in the ORGANIZATION.

PERSON was the second-youngest player in the LOCATION League in 2013, playing much of the season as a 17-year-old. He more than held his own against the older competition, and he continued playing well ahead of the curve in the ORGANIZATION in '14.The son of former All-Star PERSON, PERSON has a good feel for hitting from both sides of the plate. He is an above-average runner, and while PERSON doesn't hit for much power now, scouts expect that to change as he matures. Defensively, PERSON has a strong arm and good infield actions. He is a good bet to stay at shortstop, and he has the potential to be an above-average defender.PERSON's youth and inexperience are understandably exposed at times, but he is already very advanced for his age.

PERSON has a heavy, mid-90s sinker that has enabled him to generate a 78% groundball rate this year. His slider has a 2800 rpm spin rate but visual evaluations of that pitch put it closer to average. His changeup moves and tails, but is often easy to identify out of his hand due to altered release/arm speed. On some level, PERSON is a one-pitch 25-year-old, but on another he has a dominant, grounder-inducing fastball and his secondaries have some characteristics that may just need to be refined for one or both of them to be effective.

PERSON showed exciting stuff during his college career at ORGANIZATION, but was beset by injuries at the outset of his professional career. A hip injury that ultimately required surgery kept him from throwing a professional pitch for nearly a year after he was drafted and he was sidelined for a month in 2014 by shoulder fatigue.PERSON got back on the mound by the end of last year and when he's healthy he has as powerful an arm as ever. His fastball gets up to 96 mph and his slider gives him a second above-average offering. He also throws a curveball and a changeup, but doesn't use either pitch as often. Even before his injuries, scouts were split on whether PERSON was best suited for the rotation or the bullpen. Either way, he'll need to show he can stay healthy for a full season.

Signed out of the ORGANIZATION in August 2012, PERSON has pitched to mixed results in his five professionals seasons but continues to flash tantalizing stuff. That was especially true in 2017, when he ranked among the Class A Advanced PERSON leaders with his 143 1/3 innings pitched (third) and 133 strikeouts (fifth), both far and away his career highs, while posting a 4.33 ORGANIZATION and a 1.43 WHIP in 26 starts. PERSON' stuff arguably is the best among right-handed pitchers in GPE's system. Combining athleticism with a fast arm, PERSON pitches with a 92-94 mph sinking fastball that nets him both whiffs and ground balls. ORGANIZATION officials rave about his high-spin-rate curveball, a potential plus pitch, and PERSON impressed them with his changeup development in 2017. While PERSON' stuff may already be there, his control and command are not, with both grading as below average. Further experience and maturation should aid him on that front, giving PERSON a chance to serve as a Nos. 3 or 4 starter once fully developed.

GPE liked PERSON's power potential and plus speed enough to give him a $1.3 million bonus as a third-round pick in 2010, but inconsistency at the plate and injuries plagued him in his first three full pro seasons. While PERSON missed three weeks in May with hamstring and hand ailments, he has been otherwise healthy and enjoying his most productive year ever, which earned him a trip to the ORGANIZATION Game.Because he's a 5-foot-8 second baseman, PERSON inevitably draws comparisons to PERSON. While he has an aggressive approach and generates surprising pop for his size, PERSON doesn't make contact as consistently as PERSON. PERSON is faster, however, and is an adept basestealer who succeeded on 88 percent of his first 69 pro attempts.PERSON has good hands and enough arm strength to make plays at second base, though he's blocked by PERSON and PERSON at that position. While PERSON saw some action at third base in 2014, his arm doesn't really fit at the hot corner.

ORGANIZATION Premier Event: Jan. 21, 2017 - ORGANIZATION MLB Team: PERSON ORGANIZATION MLB Player: PERSON has a big arm and isn't afraid to show it off. The southpaw, who has committed to GPE, is used to big games, as his performance on the mound and at the plate helped lead LOCATION Place to back-to-back ORGANIZATION World Series titles.Gobillot was selected to the ORGANIZATION Baseball 17U ORGANIZATION Development Program in July 2015. He also boasts a fastball that tops 90 mph.

A stocky, hard-throwing starter with upper-90s heat, GPE's fastball doesn't play as an elite pitch despite his velocity (it has middling movement and he's an extreme short strider who loses two ticks of perceived velo) but it's tough to square up because of how hard it is. Similarly, GPE's short, cuttery slider is effective because of how firm it is. He also has a firm changeup that may be shelved, or at least de-emphasized, if/when GPE moves to the bullpen which, despite his current development, is a more likely future outcome.

The start of PERSON's career began inauspiciously, as he had deals with two other clubs fall apart because of injury and age concerns. After he served a one-year suspension, the ORGANIZATION were able to sign him, albeit not in his teenage years. He made his GPE debut in 2012, putting up gaudy numbers in the ORGANIZATION York-Penn League. The injury concerns manifested themselves in 2013, and PERSON underwent PERSON surgery in June. When healthy, he has the best slider in the system, a future plus breaking ball with good late break. His fastball is above average, and his control, already solid, will continue to get better. Only his changeup is behind, but he's shown enough feel for it to instill confidence that it will be a Major League-average offering.

PERSON was originally on track to finish high school in 2014, and would have been one of the oldest prep players in the GPE class. He was able to speed up his graduation and entered the 2013 GPE, where the ORGANIZATION selected him in the third round. He spent a successful first full professional season with PERSON. PERSON mostly for his power as an amateur, PERSON has shown a more mature approach in the ORGANIZATION. He's a patient hitter, and his feel for the barrel should help him cut down on his strikeouts as he gets more experience against premium pitching.PERSON was a shortstop in high school but quickly moved to third base in the ORGANIZATION. He has the arm strength and hands for the position, but his lack of athleticism limits his range and leads some scouts to believe he'll eventually move to first base.

PERSON ORGANIZATION's male athlete of the year in 2012 after starring in four sports at FACILITY (Calif.) High, PERSON lasted 21 rounds in the Draft that June in part because he had a poor junior season in the diamond. Signed for $50,000, he spent two years in GPE ball and led the ORGANIZATION with 14 homers in 2013 but was overmatched in his first taste of Class A in 2014. He continued to struggle when he returned there in 2015 but surged after a second-half promotion to Class A Advanced, where he hit .308/.376/.568 with 13 homers in 61 games. PERSON's bat speed and leverage give him above-average raw power that he began to translate into game production once he began managing the strike zone better in Class A Advanced. He'll need to prove that he can make consistent contact and continue to exhibit patience against more advanced competition, but the progress he made in 2015 is encouraging. So too were the four homers he drilled in 16 games in the ORGANIZATION. After splitting his time between center and left field in his first three pro seasons, PERSON spent most of 2015 at the latter position. He has average speed once he gets going and has worked diligently to improve his arm strength from well below average to fringy.

PERSON was 21, ancient by international standards, when he signed for $10,000 out of the ORGANIZATION in March 2015. He has advanced quickly, rising from GPE ball to high Class A in less than three months in 2016 and advancing to Double-A two months into last season. He has generated infrequent and weak contact, averaging 9.8 strikeouts per nine innings and a 2.6 groundout/airout ratio in his first three years as a pro.PERSON generates all those strikeouts and groundouts with three pitches that all tend to drop at the plate. His two-seam fastball usually sits at 91-96 mph with heavy life and his low-80s curveball has so much power and depth that it can overmatch both left-handers and right-handers. His changeup isn't as reliable but can be a solid third offering when he keeps it down in the strike zone.Though he has cleaned up his mechanics some since signing, PERSON is still short and stocky and has significant effort in his delivery. His control took a significant step backward in 2017 and he got hit hard for the first time when he didn't locate his pitches well in Double-A, increasing the chances that he'll eventually move to the bullpen. While the ORGANIZATION haven't given up on him as a starter, he could turn into a dynamic reliever with a pair of well above-average pitches.

Louisiana-Lafayette had a storybook regular season, going 49-7 to match the school record for wins and posting the best league mark in ORGANIZATION play at 26-4. Adding to the intrigue is the fact that that coach PERSON's top pitcher is also his son.Austin PERSON fills the strike zone with three average pitches. He throws his sinker at 88-93 mph, his curveball in the mid-70s and his changeup in the low 80s. On any given day, any of his offerings can be his best weapon.Though PERSON has advanced feel for pitching, there are some concerns. He's extremely skinny at 6-foot-6 and 170 pounds, and some scouts don't love his arm action or the effort in his delivery. That leads to concerns about durability, and he did miss two starts this spring with biceps tendinitis.

PERSON has all the catcherly intangibles you can think of and scouts have been wholly unsurprised that GPE has pushed him up the minor league ladder at a speed that might be considered a bit quick since catcher development is typically taken very slowly. He went straight to the ORGANIZATION at age 17, then to a ORGANIZATION packed with 21-year-olds at age 18. PERSON works hard enough that scouts from opposing clubs have taken notice; his leadership qualities have been evident during two postseason runs (circumstances that are helping to drive the 'winning player' narrative here) in two pro seasons. He's a bat-first catcher with some pull power and an above-average arm. He's raw on defense and is already a sturdily built young man who may overthicken and become immobile, but based on the makeup reports it sounds like PERSON will do what is necessary to stay back there. Teen catching prospects are risky. This one seems like a potential everyday backstop if everything breaks right, but it's more likely he becomes a backup.

Coming out of GPE high school powerhouse ORGANIZATION, GPE decided to forego his commitment to ORGANIZATION as a talented two-way player when the ORGANIZATION gave him $440,000 in the 30th round of the Draft to become a hitter only. He had made it to Double-A in 2017 when he was sent to the ORGANIZATION in return for international bonus pool money. Seven games in with his new organization, GPE's left elbow popped, requiring PERSON surgery in mid-July. He returned in 2018 and earned a promotion to Triple-A, only to have a left wrist sprain sideline him in mid-July.GPE had a reputation of being one of the most advanced hitters in GPE's system and he was off to a good start with PERSON before he got hurt. He's hit over power, with a patient approach and an ability to make hard contact to all fields. His swing path doesn't lend itself to a ton of power, but he has the bat speed and strength to drive the ball more than he has, and there was a small uptick in power in 2017. A better athlete than some give him credit for, GPE has seen time at first and an outfield corner, with more at the former of late. It's tough to be a first baseman only in the ORGANIZATION system with PERSON in the big leagues, so the ORGANIZATION will go back to mixing it up more frequently with GPE.
GPE shortstop that can pick it and hits a little, too.

PERSON has had its fair share of big leaguers come from its program, none bigger than ORGANIZATION of ORGANIZATION. PERSON is probably the best right-handed pitcher who is a former PERSON, and while no one is making PERSON an All-Star just yet, the ORGANIZATION-eligible sophomore's name was moving up boards as the ORGANIZATION approached. PERSON redshirted in 2015 and pitched largely out of the bullpen in 2016. He began in a similar role in 2017 but moved into the rotation in March and has solidified himself as PERSON's Saturday starter, pitching behind fellow ORGANIZATION prospect PERSON. The 6-foot-3 right-hander has used a four-pitch arsenal to dominate the Big West Conference this spring. His fastball has been up to 93-94 mph consistently and he backs it up with an above-average slider he throws in the 80-84 mph range. He'll show an upper-80s cutter and has feel for his changeup as well.While he had been a reliever initially, PERSON's arm works well and he throws strikes. With a clean delivery and strong frame, he's showing more and more that he has what it takes to start, a reason why he had some helium as the spring wore on.

PERSON was outstanding as ORGANIZATION's ace and finished his college career with a 23-9 record and 2.80 ERA, racking up 285 strikeouts over three seasons. The A's selected the right-hander in the second round of the 2014 Draft, and he offered a taste of his potential in the ORGANIZATION York-Penn League after signing for $750,000. Although he struggled during his introduction to full-season ball in 2015, PERSON was able to make some adjustments over the course of the season and finished the year on a high note before truly breaking out in '16.PERSON's fastball sits in the low 90s, topping out at 95-96 mph, and has arm-side run and late sinking action. His curveball projects to be above average and is his best secondary offering at the moment, though he also has good feel for a changeup that could be at least PERSON average once developed. His slider was his go-to out pitch at ORGANIZATION, but it's been below average as a pro and requires further refinement.Though pounding the zone has never been an issue for PERSON, his first full season indicated that the quality of his strikes must improve. Some scouts wonder if he'll have the durability to remain in the rotation, although that hasn't been an issue so far. ORGANIZATION officials believe he has what it takes to be a big league starter, and the club's track record of developing undersized right-handers bodes well for his future in the role.

PERSON benefitted from a big draft spring for ORGANIZATION, jumping from two campaigns with a .700-something ORGANIZATION to a 1.023 ORGANIZATION and 33 extra base hits in 58 games. The upside here still isn't huge, with all five tools right around average, but PERSON has the feel to hit and defend such that he could be a good platoon outfielder who can play all three spots and get a bulk of the at-bats. The realistic outcome if the bat plays and the 22-year-old moves relatively quickly through the minors is a 450 plate appearance outfielder with fringy offense who plays above average corner defense.

GPE homered 10 times in his final 16 games at ORGANIZATION, winning LOCATION tournament ORGANIZATION honors after going deep five times in five days, including a three-homer game against GPE. He finished with 20 homers after totaling six in his first two years with the ORGANIZATION, bashing his way into the sixth round of the 2017 Draft. After signing for $260,200, GPE homered in three of his first four games as a pro.As a first baseman with big left-handed power along with swing-and-miss concerns, GPE earns comparisons to a poor man's PERSON. With his bat speed and the size and leverage his 6-foot-3, 235-pound frame provides, he can crush the ball out of any part of the park. While GPE may never hit for a high average, he has shown a greater willingness to use the entire field and has made more contact in 2017.All of GPE's value comes from his bat. A high school catcher who played some right field as an ORGANIZATION sophomore, he'll be limited to first base as a pro because of his well-below-average speed. GPE can become an adequate defender but will need to improve his consistency.

PERSON is a bit of a tweener defensively and his swing is a little unorthodox, but he's done nothing but hit everywhere he's been. His supporters see a center fielder with plus raw power that's the best pure hitter in the draft.

Signed for $400,000 by the ORGANIZATION out of the ORGANIZATION in 2012, PERSON made quite an impression in his professional debut the following summer as he led the ORGANIZATION in batting average (,348) and ORGANIZATION (1.023). An average runner, PERSON fits best at second base but has also played shortstop in the ORGANIZATION. He has good defensive instincts and reliable hands to go with average arm strength and range.

PERSON burst onto the scouting scene in 2018 at FACILITY in GPE after bouncing back from PERSON. Regardless, his present stuff will play in any role and fits where the game is going, so simply staying healthy, getting innings, and maintaining his stuff should keep him on the prospect radar.

An excellent example of why it's important to scout frames/builds, PERSON's physical tools were all 40s and 45s when he signed. But as his body has matured, those tools have all improved, and done so without PERSON losing mobility because his broad, square-shouldered frame had plenty of room for this new mass. At times he still appears to be uncoordinated, still growing into his body, but PERSON is still just the age of some older, draft-eligible high school seniors and he's already having statistical success at Low-A. He's become a sleeper platoon/low-end regular prospect, at least.

PERSON starred in college at ORGANIZATION, leading the ORGANIZATION to the ORGANIZATION World Series in 2015 and 2016 and topping ORGANIZATION Division I with 78 walks in the latter season. He has significantly improved his game-calling since entering pro ball.PERSON' inclination to work counts and take hittable pitches also leads to strikeouts, as does his tendency to get long with his swing and become pull-conscious, resulting in a .234 batting average and a 30 percent whiff rate in his first three pro seasons. While he doesn't have to hit for a high average to be productive, it still remains to be seen if he can make it as a catcher. He lacks soft hands and is a shaky receiver, and his solid arm strength plays down because of a slow transfer and sinking action on his throws.

PERSON has a maxed-out, powerfully built frame, effort to his delivery, command that likely fits best in relief and he's already 19. Those are the minuses that traditionally would send any high school pitcher to college without much of a pro offer. These days, however, velo is king and two power pitches with any idea where they're going could turn into PERSON and be worth a mint, so prep relief types are now acceptable. On the plus side, PERSON may have the best two-pitch combo in the draft and also has a workable changeup. His bulldog mentality is already geared for a relief role, so it will be interesting to see how long the team that signs him uses him anywhere other than the 8th and 9th innings.

Originally signed out of the ORGANIZATION in 2012, PERSON made headlines four years later when he authored a 50-game hitting streak, the longest in the ORGANIZATION since 1963, spanning parts of four months and two levels. The breakout performance earned PERSON a selection as the World team's starting catcher in the 2016 ORGANIZATION All-Star PERSON, and he went on to finish sixth in the Minors with a .342 average. PERSON only built on that success in 2017, as he was named PERSON of the Year, received his first taste of the Majors at age 21 in September and then had a strong showing in the ORGANIZATION while learning a new position. The switch-hitting PERSON has natural hitting ability from both sides of the plate. Though his approach is aggressive, PERSON generates consistently hard contact to all fields thanks to his advanced bat-to-ball skills and outstanding barrel control. His physical strength and bat speed generates sneaky raw power, especially from the left side, and he's tapped into it more regularly as he's climbed the ladder.After catching almost exclusively during his first four seasons, PERSON spent the entire ORGANIZATION working at third base and then split time between the outfield and catcher in 2018 as the GPE explored ways to get his bat into the lineup. That versatility could help him get everyday at-bats with the ORGANIZATION, too, though for now the club appears intent on keeping PERSON behind the plate.

The beefcake PERSON was sent back to the ORGANIZATION to start 2018, thrived for six weeks there, then was promoted to Hi-A for the rest of the year. An improved receiver with a good arm, GPE now projects as a passable catcher after looking kind of rough back there as an amateur and young pro. A more pull-happy approach may unlock dormant game power and the start of GPE's 2019 indicates it might be coming. He projects as a backup for now, with a chance the batted ball profile changes in a relevant way.

PERSON hurt his elbow during his senior year of high school, and though he ultimately underwent PERSON surgery, the ORGANIZATION selected him in the 50th round. That decision is beginning to pay off as PERSON turns his promise into results.PERSON's fastball sits in the low-90s, and he commands it effectively to both sides of the plate. He shows some feel for both his curveball and changeup, giving him two more average offerings.Because PERSON doesn't have overwhelming stuff, he has to command all of his pitches to succeed. He's made strides in that area, and if he continues to do so, he'll have a chance to stick as a middle-of-the-rotation starter.

GPE doesn't have a plus tool, but projects to stick behind the plate, has solid defensive skills, enough athleticism and feel to hit. There's some power, he isn't a base-clogger and he has a track record of hitting, making him one of the safer bets in the class.

Originally selected 10th overall by the ORGANIZATION in 2013, ORGANIZATION opted not to sign and instead began his college career at ORGANIZATION State PERSON. But ORGANIZATION didn't pitch as well upon joining the ORGANIZATION, and then received a 50-game suspension in December following a second positive test for a drug of abuse. ORGANIZATION can hit 95 mph with a four-seam fastball and miss barrels with a low-90s two-seamer that features plenty of sink and should net him more ground balls as he learns to better locate it down in the zone. He made strides with his split-changeup during his first instructional league with the ORGANIZATION and then made even more progress with it in 2016, giving him a third average-or-better pitch. The ORGANIZATION will continue to develop him as a starter once he's returned in earnest from both the suspension and injury, but there are many who think ORGANIZATION is destined for the bullpen, where his stuff stands to play up in shorter bursts.

PERSON is a switch-hitting center fielder with a good approach and a free and easy swing from both sides of the plate. He might be a better overall hitter from the left side of the plate, but he has more power from the right side. Like most teens his age, PERSON is working on improving pitch recognition, but he already has a good feel for the strike zone and shows good rhythm and timing in the batter's box.The teenager is going to hit. PERSON has quick hands and has also shown glimpses of power in games, with the ball jumping off of his bat. More power could come as he develops. Overall, PERSON is viewed as a skilled prospect with emerging tools who has already shown improvement and increased strength in the past several months. On defense, he has shown good defensive actions with a playable arm. He's also been praised for his makeup.PERSON is from GPE, GPE, and trains with PERSON. The ORGANIZATION Sox are the favorite to sign him.

PERSON was one of four prep hitters in the 2018 class -- along with PERSON, PERSON and PERSON -- who played together in the ORGANIZATION USA pipeline for years; all got top-two round money in the draft. PERSON is the best of the group because he offers the best contact skills while also being tied for having the most raw power, speed, and defensive value. His well-rounded skillset enticed the ORGANIZATION to take him sixth overall, but he was then traded by new GM PERSON as the headliner to acquire PERSON and PERSON. PERSON is an intense competitor who works tirelessly, to the point that some teammates and scouts think he should reel it back in a bit at times, though they point out they'd rather have a guy who's too dedicated than one who's not enough. He's a plus straight-line runner but more of a 55 on the field, and thus isn't a slam dunk to stick in center. But he has 55 raw power, so there's enough thump to profile if he ends up sliding over to right field, where his plus arm would also fit.

PERSON University has had just three players taken in the top 10 rounds of the June Draft since it was instituted in 1965. The most successful from that group was catcher PERSON, who spent parts of 10 years in the big leagues after being a third-round pick in 1992. A fellow Patriots backstop, PERSON hopes to follow in GPE's footsteps, though it's unlikely he'll hear his name as early in the Draft.PERSON has a solid track record with the bat at PERSON, hitting well over .300 in each of his three seasons as a starter, though he did appear over-matched against quality pitching in the ORGANIZATION last summer. For most of his college career, he's shown outstanding contact and on-base skills, drawing as many walks as strikeouts. Early on this spring, he was selling out on his swing trying to get to his power, but went back to his contact-first approach from the left side of the plate and got back to staying through the ball more effectively. PERSON also runs very well for a catcher, even stealing some bases along the way. His best defensive tool is his above-average arm and while he is an acceptable receiver, he does need to work on his setup behind the plate.There's a dearth of catching, especially in the college ranks, in this year's class, which will certainly help PERSON's status. He has a floor as a left-handed-hitting backup with solid contact skills but could develop into a solid regular if everything clicks.

The younger brother of former GPE first-rounder PERSON, PERSON stood out mostly for his defense during his first two years at ORGANIZATION before breaking out at the plate as a junior, leading to his selection by the ORGANIZATION in the fifth round of the 2015 ORGANIZATION. After he signed for $335,400, PERSON took the Class A Short PERSON by storm, winning ORGANIZATION honors and leading the league in average (.358), stolen bases (47), on-base percentage (.432) and runs scored (64). As a result of his success, the ORGANIZATION sent PERSON to Class A Advanced Bakersfield to begin his first full season. PERSON hit a collective .184 between his freshman and sophomore seasons with the ORGANIZATION, and his offensive struggles carried over to the 2014 Cape Cod League, where he hit just .196 with his ORGANIZATION stock on the line. But things came together for him as a junior, and he continued to make strides at the plate in his pro debut after he shortened his swing.
