While he'll never offer much in the way of power, PERSON did show more consistent pop to the gaps in the LOCATION League.Defensively, PERSON shouldn't have trouble sticking at shortstop, where he profiles as an above-average defender with soft hands, good range and an absolute cannon for an arm. Though still has quite a bit to prove at the plate in spite of his impressive pro debut, PERSON could turn out to be one of the biggest steals of the 2015 ORGANIZATION with another strong showing in his first full season.

GPE has big time pull-side lift in his swing, has 45 raw power already at age 17, and a fairly projectable 6-foot-2 frame that portends more. He'll reach down and barrel balls near his shoe tops and also crush mistakes. He's too aggressive right now and probably has to move to a corner eventually, so our early assessment of the profile is that it's very risky. But as far as teenage power projection bats go, this is a good one.

A relatively unheralded recruit, PERSON opened his freshman season as PERSON's closer before becoming a rotation mainstay midway through that spring. He looked better than ever this fall after improving his conditioning, making himself a potential first-rounder, and looked so good this spring that he seemed like a lock for the top 10 picks. Then he got suspended for four starts in April for repeated violations of university and athletic department policy, returned in May for three relief appearances and got kicked off the team permanently.PERSON's fastball works at 92-95 mph and peaks at 97 with little effort in his delivery. His low-80s slider has good bite and has been unhittable for much of his junior season. His changeup has significantly improved, showing flashes of becoming a plus pitch as he has used it more often.PERSON's indifferent approach to conditioning led to him going undrafted out of high school and getting suspended for a couple of weeks at the start of his sophomore season. Scouts were impressed at how much better he looked physically this year, but makeup concerns have dogged him for a while. Some clubs have said they wouldn't touch him in the first round, though he'll still be PERSON's highest pick since PERSON went fourth overall in 2006.

PERSON felt forearm tightness while throwing live batting practice to PERSON in late February, and five days later Dr. PERSON was reconstructing his ORGANIZATION. It was the first of several season-ending injuries Rays prospects would sustain early in the year, and it delayed PERSON's run at a potential Rookie of the Year award. A creative sequencer, PERSON's deep, unique repertoire is unlike any other pitcher in the minors. Though his fastball touches 98, his stuff is so diverse that he never has to pitch off of it. He can lob his curveball in for strikes, induce weak contact early in counts by throwing a cutter when hitters are sitting fastball, and he'll double and triple up on the changeup. What you see listed in PERSON's tool grades as a splitter is actually a screwball. It wobbles home in the 79-82 mph range, while his true changeup is usually a little harder than that. The screwgie is more than a gimmick and can miss bats, though its best in moderation because it's a little easier to identify out of his hand, and hitters are able to recognize it after seeing it multiple times in the same at-bat. PERSON's delivery is pretty violent and his TJ was not his first injury, but he's ready and has No. 2 or 3 starter stuff if it comes back after the surgery. He has been throwing off a mound since early December and should be pitching in games before April is through.

PERSON signed for $1 million as one of several over-slot players in GPE's terrific 2014 draft class and was tracking through the minors at an even pace before he blew out his elbow in August of 2017. He returned from PERSON just eleven months after his injury and by the end of his six-week ORGANIZATION run, looked as though he might contribute to the ORGANIZATION in 2019. He was touching 95 in the fall and living in the low-90s with less life than his spin rate would indicate. He has an above-average curveball and will flash an average change and a pitch that looks like a cutter, but it may just be a variation of his changeup. He projects as a no. 4 or 5 starter.

Since being selected in the Rule 5 Draft by the ORGANIZATION at last year's Winter Meetings, PERSON has passed through GPE, PERSON and PERSON, but he's now back where he started, with the Astros.PERSON has lightning-fast arm speed that made him attractive to teams in the Rule 5 Draft despite the fact he hadn't pitched above the ORGANIZATION. He throws his fastball in the mid to upper 90s with late life. He also throws an exceptionally hard slider, though it stands out much more for its velocity than its bite. His mechanics get out of sync, causing him to lose direction to the plate and have trouble maintaining his arm slot. He may never be able to command his pitches well enough to succeed as a starter, but if he can throw more strikes, he could be an asset as a reliever.

Coming into the 2014 season, scouts were split on whether PERSON was a better prospect as a pitcher or a third baseman. By the end of the spring, he stood out more on the mound, and he became the third first-round pitcher out of the Harvard-Westlake School in GPE, GPE, in the past three Drafts -- following PERSON (ORGANIZATION) and PERSON (ORGANIZATION). He projects to add more velocity as he fills out and he focuses on pitching, so he could have three plus offerings down the road. PERSON's changeup is his best pitch. He also has a fastball that reaches 93 mph, an improving slider and a get-me-over curveball.As a third baseman, PERSON projected as a quality defender with gap power. He has a ceiling as a No. 2 or 3 starter on the mound, and he could move quickly given his advanced feel for pitching.

PERSON is an athletic, catch-and-throw guy with bat control and gap power. He hit .301 in the FACILITY as a 19-year-old and now has three straight years of strikeout rates well below league average. He struggles to squeeze good breaking balls but is otherwise a promising receiver and ball blocker. So long as PERSON's little frame can withstand the physical grind of the position, he could be a well-rounded every day catcher.

At the start of the 2012 international signing period, the ORGANIZATION signed PERSON, a ORGANIZATION shortstop who was ranked No. 2 in the class by MLBPipeline.com. But PERSON was traded to the A's during the offseason, a move that could help PERSON start moving toward GPE a little quicker. PERSON stands out for his defense thanks to his soft hands and good footwork. He has good range and a strong enough arm to make all the throws required of a shortstop with ease. He's not an all-glove, no-bat shortstop, however. He has opened eyes with his bat in 2015, getting more aggressive and showing previously unrevealed power that could result in 15-20 homers annually in his prime.

PERSON was named the 2013 Panhandle Conference Pitcher of the Year as a freshman after going 8-3 with a 3.19 ERA. Though he wasn't honored for a second year in a row, scouts say his stuff has improved this spring.  PERSON has added some velocity to his fastball, which tops out at 95 mph. More typically it sits in the low 90s with tailing action. His breaking ball has the most potential of his secondary offerings. At its best, it looks like a biting curveball, but it can get slurvy. There is some effort in his delivery, and he struggled with his control at times.  PERSON was expected to be drafted last year, but he told teams he preferred to return for another season at ORGANIZATION and ultimately wasn't selected. Should he decide to return to school again, he is committed to PERSON.

Originally drafted as a third baseman with power potential, PERSON moved behind the plate after his first full season. His development hasn't taken a typical path, as he's become more of a defensive-minded backstop with the bat lagging behind.Watching PERSON behind the plate, he no longer looks like a conversion case. His arm that fired 92-mph fastballs as a high school pitcher works very well at catcher, throwing out 34 percent of would-be basestealers over his first two years behind the plate. He's a natural leader who works with pitchers and frames well. Offensively, it's been a struggle, though he started to come around in the second half of 2015, with the cavernous confines of GPE Beach not doing him any favors. He's likely never going to hit for a high average, but the raw power that enamored scouts in high school is definitely still there.Some consider PERSON to be big for a catcher, but the fact that PERSON manager PERSON fit that description as well could work in his favor. If he can find some offensive consistency, something that started to show up in 2016, PERSON still has the chance to be a power-hitting regular.

An interesting potential swiss-army knife utility man who can also catch, GPE has quality bat-to-ball skills and has a chance to make more of an impact than the typical bench player because of his multi-positional versatility.

PERSON was a first round pick out of a GPE high school in 2013 based on the strength of his arm and power, with his hitting and catching skills closer to average.  That's still largely the report 5.5 years later, with the gap being that PERSON isn't quite offensively talented enough (a combination of plate coverage, loft and bat control) to hit for both leagues' average contact and power. The lesser offensive upside makes him more of a potential backup. He got a cup of coffee in 2018 and is currently the third catcher for the ORGANIZATION, so he'll almost certainly get more big league time when there's a catcher injury or prolonged slump next season.

PERSON was a highly regarded prep pitcher and the ORGANIZATION made him their fourth-round pick in 2012. His fastball sits in the low-90s, but he touched 96 mph in high school. PERSON gets a good downward plane on his fastball from a three-quarters arm slot. He pairs his fastball with a knuckle-curve and a changeup. PERSON is known for working quickly and has a clean, polished delivery. He looks the part of a right-handed starter, checking in at 6-foot-5, 210 pounds. PERSON made his professional debut in the ORGANIZATION in 2012.

Signed as an international free agent out of GPE in 2014, PERSON produced mixed results early in his career, but still made steady progress through GPE's system. He put it all together during his 2017 full-season debut, beginning the year with PERSON before advancing to the ORGANIZATION State League in GPE. Altogether, the toolsy outfielder led all Blue Jays farmhands in both runs scored (93) and triples (10) while finishing second in home runs (17) and third in GPE (72). PERSON' performance caught the attention of the ORGANIZATION, and they acquired him and reliever PERSON for ORGANIZATION in January.Wiry and athletic, PERSON stands out as much for his remaining physical projection as he does for his present athleticism and tools. He combines bat speed with a short right-handed swing to produce lots of hard contact, generating good extension through the ball and driving it to all fields. He began to tap into his above-average raw power and cleared fences more regularly in 2017, and scouts believe there'll be more power to come once he adds strength to his lean frame and better learns to leverage his swing. PERSON knows how to use his well above-average speed on the basepaths as well as in the outfield, where he possesses the necessary range for all three positions and a strong enough arm to play right. Despite his capacity to contribute in all phases of the game, PERSON' power-speed combo is his true calling card and could make him a regular at maturity.

PERSON was pilfered from GPE as the ORGANIZATION in the 2018 Keone Kela trade. Though he is a big-framed guy who has already begun to see time at first base, he's athletic for his size and should remain at third -- for a while, at least. The likelihood of this is bolstered by the polished nature of PERSON's bat. His feel for the strike zone and his timing are both impressive for his age, and he is adept at attacking early-count pitches he can drive, while taking tough strikes. It helps him run deep counts and walk as well as hit for power. These traits are conducive to quick development, which means PERSON has a better chance of reaching the majors while he's still limber enough to play third for much of his first six big league seasons. 
He could end up with a 50 bat, 60 power, high ORGANIZATION, and fine third base defense, which would make him a solid-average regular.

A college reliever until midway through his junior year at ORGANIZATION, GPE repertoire has developed quickly and he now has four above-average pitches. Both of his breaking balls (a slider in the mid-80s and an upper-70s curve) work because he has terrific command of both, almost always locating them down and to his glove side in places that are enticing but unhittable. This wanes when hes pitching from the stretch. His fastball command is below average but he throws hard enough to get away with mistakes, sitting 92-95 and touching 97. His changeup came on late in the year and will flash plus. Its firm, 85-88mph, but some of them have a lot of arm side movement and will still miss bats. PERSON finished 2018 at ORGANIZATION and has a shot to debut next year, but more likely sees Safeco in 2020.

PERSON struggled early in his career, posting a combined 4.63 ERA during his first two seasons in GPE ball after signing with PERSON out of the ORGANIZATION in 2014. His elite arm strength caught the attention of the ORGANIZATION, however, and they acquired him and PERSON for PERSON in November 2016. PERSON was on the move again the following offseason, this time going to the ORGANIZATION with PERSON and PERSON in the ORGANIZATION blockbuster.PERSON's lightning-quick arm and relatively easy delivery produces exceptional velocity in a fastball that sits 97-103 mph as a starter. He showed better control of the pitch in 2017 after improving his mechanics, but regressed as a strike-thrower in '18 while pitching in the ORGANIZATION State League. PERSON's power slider is an above-average pitch and complements his heater nicely, and together they help him to rack up strikeouts. He also has changeup that's in its nascent stages. PERSON demonstrated the capacity to make adjustments during his time in the ORGANIZATION system, and he'll need to make even more in the coming years to reach his ceiling of a No. 3 starter or a dominant closer. Throwing strikes consistently is PERSON's biggest hurdle right now, but the power-armed righty could move quickly if it clicks.

Of all the players signed during the 2017 July 2 span, PERSON had the most promising feel to hit. He's a lefty infield bat with natural feel for lift, a projectable frame, and a good chance of staying at second base, though he'll probably only be okay there.

PERSON is the poster child in this year's class for the benefits (from the club side) of identifying, scouting and locking up prospects early. PERSON to some governmental issues, it's been harder recently for foreign scouts (i.e. decision makers in most cases) to get in the country, so some of those players that don't come to showcases or move outright to the GPE are at a disadvantage. The ORGANIZATION locked onto PERSON early in the process, got a good price in the low 7 figures and he's developed nicely since then to be one of the top players in the class. One scout said he a less electric version of A's shortstop PERSON, in that he has an uncanny ability to square up the ball, can run and play shortstop but doesn't have much power. PERSON has a couple notches more speed, more arm strength and more electricity in his bat (and is even smaller), but ORGANIZATION has all the indicators at a young age that he'll be the next savvy and toolsy PERSON shortstop to become a top prospect.

Typically guys who convert from a position to the mound are hard throwers who don't know how to pitch and are best suited for short relief. PERSON, initially signed out of GPE as a shortstop, bucks that trend, profiling more as a starter who really knows how to command the baseball. That profile interested the ORGANIZATION, who acquired PERSON along with PERSON from the ORGANIZATION in return for PERSON. His time with PERSON was short-lived, as he was sent to the ORGANIZATION in a Winter ORGANIZATION deal for PERSON Wilson.As a former middle infielder, PERSON brings excellent athleticism to the mound. He also brings a solid three-pitch mix. His fastball will sit at 93 mph, and he'll touch 95 mph on occasion. His breaking ball is a bit slurvy but has shown improvement, and he has the makings of a Major League average changeup. More than anything, he throws a ton of strikes, proof of which comes in his career 1.8 walks-per-nine ratio heading into 2015. While PERSON doesn't have the ceiling of some of the high-end arms that have come out of the ORGANIZATION system lately, he could fit into the back of a big league rotation.

PERSON has been traded twice: first from GPE to GPE for PERSON, then to GPE in the ORGANIZATION deal. His control regressed pretty badly in 2018 and this, combined with his addition to the 40-man, make it more likely that he ends up in a relief role. Both the quality of his breaking ball and his fastball velocity vary pretty dramatically, but when they're both dialed in, PERSON can dominate without throwing a lot of strikes, mostly by bullying hitters with his heater. He is stiff, oddly postured, and may not have the necessary athleticism to repeat his delivery. The ORGANIZATION should continue developing him as a starter so he gets more reps with both his change (which got better in 2018 and has a chance to miss bats one day) and breaking ball, but we think they'll pull the ripcord eventually and let PERSON breath fire in late innings.

PERSON spent most of his first two years at ORGANIZATION as a pitcher and didn't become a full-time starter at first base until his senior year in 2016, when he set a school record and finished second in ORGANIZATION Division I with 27 doubles. After signing for $2,500 in the 19th round that June, he didn't stand out until he swatted 18 homers between Double-A and Triple-A in 2018. He has posted the best numbers of his career this year in Triple-A.PERSON creates a lot of leverage with his 6-foot-7 frame, but he didn't start hitting for power as pro until he stopped diving too much at the plate and did a better job of staying back on pitches. There could be more pop to come if he can add more strength to his lanky build. He has done a better job this season of using the entire field and driving more balls in the air, and he doesn't swing and miss excessively despite his long limbs leading to a naturally long right-handed swing.Part of a GPE state 4-A basketball championship team at ORGANIZATION High -- where his baseball teammates included future big leaguers PERSON and PERSON -- PERSON is a good athlete for his size. PERSON spent his first two years of high school at a GPE prep school, then transferred back home to PERSON and reclassified as a senior for the 2019 Draft. The burly PERSON offered huge raw power as a GPE high schooler, but teams preferred him on the mound. PERSON was dealt before the 2018 season from GPE to GPE in the ORGANIZATION trade. PERSON had an outstanding amateur career, earning ORGANIZATION honors at the 2013 Perfect Game All-America Classic and then starring for the 18U GPE national team in the World Cup in GPE. ORGANIZATION was making a beeline up ORGANIZATION boards from the ORGANIZATION with a ton of arm strength, albeit from a smaller frame, intriguing many teams.While ORGANIZATION is only six feet tall, the ORGANIZATION State commit has more than enough fastball. PERSON is trying to join PERSON as the only Honduran-born players to reach the big leagues. Everything you say about PERSON, you can say about PERSON, except for one thing: his size. PERSON is as projectable as any high school pitcher in this year's draft, with a good body, delivery and feel for both a curveball and changeup. PERSON' older brother ORGANIZATION signed for $1.1 million with the ORGANIZATION last year out of the same high school, ORGANIZATION went in the 3rd round to the D'Backs and, next year, ORGANIZATION is looking like a top two round caliber arm from the same school. The ORGANIZATION USA Player of the Year as a junior in 2015 after hitting .377 for PERSON, the ORGANIZATION made PERSON their fourth-round selection in the June Draft. After appearing in 12 games out of the bullpen at FACILITY as a true freshman, PERSON transferred to PERSON & PERSON and sat out all of 2016. PERSON signed for $140,000 in 2017. His swing has a good foundation, he's an athletic middle infield defender, and his frame has some room for mass as he matures. He had a good fall instructional league showing.

With a very strong GPE debut in 2013 and more than holding his own as an 18-year-old in the ORGANIZATION League the following season, PERSON appeared on his way to developing into one of the better GPE pitchers in baseball. PERSON has shown impressive feel for a deep arsenal since signing with the ORGANIZATION out of GPE for $220,000 in 2012. PERSON was unheralded as an amateur, but that has quickly changed since he signed with PERSON. Though his numbers in the LOCATION didn't stand out in 2013, his stuff got the attention of scouts. It helps him get the job done in center field despite fringy range, though he'll fit better on the corners in the big leagues. His average arm allows him to play all three outfield positions.

PERSON's father PERSON was a second-round pick in the 1984 Draft and pitched part of three seasons in the ORGANIZATION. PERSON made a name for himself when he won the home run derby at the 2013 Perfect Game All-American Classic, beating out note prep sluggers such as PERSON and PERSON. Some scouts believe he's quick enough to play second base, while his strong arm and power potential would profile well at third base.

PERSON was one of the top pitchers in the 2018 July 2nd market, receiving the second-highest bonus and ranking third in the class for us when he signed. The nephew of former big leaguer PERSON, PERSON went to PERSON as a middle infielder and left as a catcher. PERSON is the son of PERSON, one of four big league pitchers on GPE' 1983 College World Series championship club. While he isn't tall and projectable, he is fairly physical and athletic. As a starter, he'll throw his fastball anywhere in the 89-95 mph range, sitting comfortably in the 91-92 mph range. When he closed games for the ORGANIZATION as a freshman, he touched 96-97 mph in those shorter stints. His changeup is his best secondary offering and he has a really good feel for it, though he does throw it too frequently at times. He mixes in a slider as well.A team could send PERSON out as a starter to allow him to build up his feel for his three-pitch mix, but he could move quickly, with an up-tick in his stuff, in a relief role.

Signed out of the ORGANIZATION in 2009, PERSON had his best pro season in 2015, finishing second in the Double-A LOCATION in strikeouts (140) and strikeouts per nine innings (9.7). The ORGANIZATION gambled and left him unprotected in the Rule 5 draft, then made him a full-time reliever when he went unselected at the ORGANIZATION. He's missing even more bats while working shorter stints, putting him in position for a callup in the near future.PERSON relies primarily on a four-seam fastball that sits at 93-95 mph and touches 97. Its velocity and riding life generate a lot of swings and misses. He also has a slider that gives him a solid second pitch at times and can mix in a changeup that flashes average.Though PERSON lacks sharp control, he delivers enough strikes and keeps the ball down in the zone. After eight seasons in pro, he's on the verge of finally making it to PERSON.

PERSON was the best position player prospect on the ORGANIZATION' Gulf Coast League team that went 49-9 in 2013. The GPE native moved up to Class A Hagerstown in 2014 and earned a spot on the LOCATION postseason All-Star team. He missed most of the first three months of the 2015 season after breaking a finger on a slide during the opening week. PERSON's speed is his best tool and he uses it well on the bases and in the outfield. He stole 69 bases in 2014, the second most in full-season ball. But he doesn't just run indiscriminately. He has good instincts on the bases and will bunt for a hit. Defensively, he takes good routes and tracks down an impressive amount of fly balls in center field. While PERSON's speed and defense give him two plus tools, he'll have to prove himself offensively as he advances in the ORGANIZATION. He has some on-base skills and has a good approach at the plate, albeit without much power.

A tiny speedster, PERSON's build is relatively unprojectable, but one can still project on most of his skills because he was only taught baseball's basics while growing up in GPE, and hasn't been switch-hitting for very long. His game has some coherent small-ball elements already, as he took  quickly to bunting and putting awkward contact into play, which, because of his speed, enables him to reach against bad low-level defenses. 
There's so little power here that PERSON likely projects as a fourth outfielder, but his feel for contact is impressive for someone of his background and seemingly insufficient physicality, and if he ends up with a 6 or 7 bat, we might be talking about a regular.

PERSON first attracted the attention of scouts when he hit 93 mph as a GPE (Mo.) JC freshman. He helped his cause by performing well against better competition as a reliever and a starter in two years at ORGANIZATION, earning a $150,000 bonus as a 12th-rounder in 2014. He has been a steady performer as a pro and moved up to Double-A by mid-2016.PERSON owns a pair of solid offerings in his fastball, which sits in the low 90s and tops out at 95, and his changeup, which features some tumble. His slider gives him a decent breaking ball, and he also employs a curveball at times. PERSON' delivery features effort and deception but doesn't prevent him from throwing strikes.His long-term role is unclear. PERSON doesn't miss a ton of bats or maintain his velocity in the late innings, which may mean he's better suited for the bullpen. He also is around the plate with four pitches and doesn't have a breaking ball that will neutralize left-handers in a relief role, so he might have a brighter future as a back-of-the-rotation starter.

Strong-armed Texas high schoolers don't usually attend college in the LOCATION. PERSON took that path, however, in part because his brother attended graduate school at ORGANIZATION, and his family was moving to GPE. Now he's a good bet to become the first pitcher from the ORGANIZATION State to go in the first three rounds since PERSON and PERSON were first-rounders in 1998.A ORGANIZATION 26th-round pick in 2011, PERSON struggled as a freshman before becoming the ORGANIZATION' No. 1 starter and starring in the ORGANIZATION last year. He built on that momentum this spring, maintaining his 90-96 mph fastball deep into games. His slider generates swing and misses but still lacks consistency.PERSON's changeup features some deception and sink, but his nascent splitter could be an even more effective third pitch. His strong build should give him the durability required of a starter, though his high arm slot allows hitters to pick up his pitches more easily than scouts would like. He throws strikes but still is refining his command.

PERSON was a pop-up small school pitcher in the 2014 draft, but issues stemming from his size and arm speed limited him in various ways until 2018, when he velocity took the step forward that many foresaw in 2014. PERSON now hits 100 mph and mixes in a slider that's a 55 at times. His command will never be great since he has a slightly stiff, 6-foot-7 frame, but his stuff doesn't need pinpoint control to be effective in a middle relief role. After contributing out of the big league bullpen down the stretch and in the playoffs in 2018, PERSON is a useful middle reliever with options for the ORGANIZATION to use and develop further.

PERSON remains known as a glove-first shortstop, just as he was before the ORGANIZATION picked him in the ninth round out of GPE in 2010. In his first four Minor League seasons, PERSON has not done much offensively. He has a big swing but did a better job putting the bat on the ball in Class A Advanced PERSON in 2013. PERSON has some power and is a below-average runner. Defensively, however, he stands out. PERSON has smooth actions and good instincts. He has good range at shortstop, and the ORGANIZATION will be patient as he tries to figure it out at the plate.

In a year where college bats with a track record of performance were hard to come by, PERSON's offensive potential had many teams interested as the GPE approached.PERSON has shown an ability to have quality at-bats and make consistent hard contact with outstanding bat speed. He has a bat that should provide both average and some power as he progresses. A slightly above-average runner, PERSON has played left field as a junior at GPE, but could have the goods to play center field, one who takes good routes and has enough arm for a corner if needed. PERSON plays with confidence in all aspects of his game.PERSON hasn't set the world on fire as a junior, though he's shown more power than he had previously. That, plus the dearth of advanced bats, could see him come off the board in the top three rounds.

PERSON had an illustrious career at ORGANIZATION, earning LOCATION Freshman of the Year honors in 2011 and ORGANIZATION of the Year honors in '13, making him the third player in conference history to win both awards. Despite his success, questions remained about PERSON's upside as a professional because of his size.PERSON has done his best to put those questions to rest since the ORGANIZATION picked him in the fifth round in 2013. While showing the kind of offensive skill set that makes him well suited for the top of the order, he reached Triple-A two months into his first second full professional season. With PERSON rapidly advancing in the ORGANIZATION, and PERSON manning second base in GPE, the ORGANIZATION are reintroducing PERSON to the outfield, where he began his college career. His speed, makeup and versatility should help him as he tries to break through to the ORGANIZATION in coming years.

A starter in college, GPE has worked exclusively as a reliever since joining the ORGANIZATION organization. The lefty has moved quickly up the ladder, putting up ridiculous strikeout per nine ratios along the way. He misses bats with a good combination of stuff and deception. His fastball sits in the low 90s with excellent movement that generates groundballs as well as strikeouts. He complements it with a very good curve. He has a changeup, though it lags behind the other two pitches. ORGANIZATION has been an issue at times, but when he has good control, he can be virtually unhittable.

After signing for $1.3 million as a fourth-round pick in 2012, PERSON developed more slowly than expected. He didn't reach full-season ball until 2014 and struggled when he got there, posting a 6.85 ERA in 11 starts in low Class A. This year he has looked more like the pitcher the ORGANIZATION thought they were signing, earning a promotion to high Class A after a month.PERSON has reclaimed the fastball velocity he displayed in high school, working at 92-93 mph and topping out at 96 repeatedly this year. His heater can be very tough to hit when he uses his 6-foot-6 frame to drive it down in the strike zone. His hard knuckle-curve can generate swings-and-misses as well.Though PERSON still has work to do with his changeup, it shows signs of becoming a usable third option. He's doing a better job of throwing strikes this year, which bodes well for his chances of remaining a starter at higher levels.

We're mindful of the need to identify pitchers whose fastballs play like impact pitches despite mediocre velocity, and PERSON appears to be one. He only throws in the low-90s but competes for swinging strikes in the zone, we think, due to big extension and effectual plane. He also has fantastic slider command, perhaps because his front foot lands so open, enabling PERSON to clear his front side consistently and preventing him from hanging sliders in the zone. He throws a lot of strikes and keeps the ball on the ground. We've warmed to the upper-level viability of his stuff and think he could be up at some point this year and become a No. 4 or 5 starter long-term.

GPE does not miss many bats because he has limited fastball velocity, but he's a high-volume strike thrower with excellent secondary stuff, including one of the best curveball spin rates in the minors. He draws from a spacious bag of tricks to get hitters out, and has now had success at the upper levels of the minors with limited velo, so we're buying that he can make things work as a fifth starter.

In July 2016, PERSON was struggling to keep his average above .200 while playing shortstop for PERSON in the Class A Advanced PERSON. The 2013 second-round pick was on the cusp of being a forgotten prospect when the decision was made to move him to center field. In 2017, he was a different player completely, leading the organization in steals, raising his batting average more than 60 points, playing well in the ORGANIZATION and earning a spot on the 40-man roster. After a strong showing in Triple-A in 2018, the ORGANIZATION dealt PERSON to GPE for ORGANIZATION and PERSON at the July Trade Deadline.The move seemed to free his mind as he re-worked his swing and was able to focus on his offense. It came together rather quickly, with him making more consistent contact as a result of improved bat speed and much more extra-base authority than he'd ever shown previously. He does need to continue to refine his approach and get into hitter's counts more consistently, which would give him more opportunities to tap into that raw power. A plus runner with a plus arm, he has transitioned to center field seamlessly and is a plus defender who looks like he was meant to roam the outfield.PERSON's renaissance was one of the best storylines in the ORGANIZATION' farm system. He's knocking on the big league door after his bounceback season, with the chance to be an everyday center fielder if his approach continues to improve.

When PERSON has been on the field, he's shown what all the fuss was about and why he was worthy of a top 10 selection in the 2013 Draft. Unfortunately, he missed all but 45 total games of the 2014 season because of a hamstring issue he had difficulty shaking. Once he did, though, he performed the way everyone expected him to.PERSON has a smooth swing from the left side of the plate with an advanced approach, especially for someone of his age and experience level. He's more of a line-drive type right now, using all fields, but the bat speed is there to project more power as he matures. PERSON has excellent speed that helps him cover a lot of ground in center field, though it hasn't translated to stolen base success. He should be able to stick in center long-term, albeit with a slightly below-average arm. He should fit the profile of a left fielder offensively should he have to move.PERSON missed a considerable amount of development time in 2014 and there certainly is no pressing need in the ORGANIZATION outfield. Still, PERSON' offensive ability should allow him to start moving more quickly now that he's healthy.

PERSON was eligible to sign during the 2012-13 international signing period but found no takers, so he waited until the following summer to land a $125,000 bonus from the LOCATION. If his 2015 GPE debut was any indication, he could be a bargain.PERSON has one of the stronger arms in the ORGANIZATION system. He works at 92-96 mph with his fastball and can reach the upper 90s. There could be more velocity in his tank because he has plenty of room to add strength to his skinny 6-foot-4 frame.He also possesses a pair of promising secondary pitches that could become solid offerings. PERSON has advanced feel for his changeup, which presently grades ahead of his curveball. He does a decent job of finding the strike zone, though like most young pitchers he'll need to refine his command.

PERSON was under the scouting radar until a breakout campaign on Cape Cod, during which both he and teammate PERSON (a second round pick by the ORGANIZATION) emerged as top tier bats in the 2018 draft. During the spring, PERSON steadily worked his way up from the late first round to the third overall pick by hitting more than scouts expected a long-limbed power threat to hit. PERSON pulls this off by keeping his arms tucked in during his swing and having a flatter plane; as a result he's both quicker into the zone and in the zone longer than most power hitters. Ideally, hitters with PERSON's plus-plus power have more loft in their swing plane and extend their arms to generate the most power, with PERSON an example of a hitter with a similar frame and this more power-focused approach. We're projecting PERSON as a 50 bat with 60 game power and split the difference a bit--he could go even more extreme for power at the expense of contact--but there are a number of ways this offensive skillset could turn out, particularly with new and more progressive hitting instruction this year for the ORGANIZATION. PERSON's defense also could go a few different ways, depending how much weight he adds to his lean frame and how his lateral quickness ages. Defensively, PERSON looks major league average at times and clearly below average at others, but he'll get plenty of chances to make things work at third base.

GPE has not shied away from drafting young high school arms and then being patient in their development. PERSON might take longer than some due to his previous lack of mound experience.A PERSON high school product who was a reliever until his senior year, PERSON does have a fresh arm, one that sat at 92-93 mph with his fastball in 2013. His slider has the chance to be average or better. PERSON still throws his changeup too hard, something he'll need to improve to remain in a rotation. He's very competitive with an edge on the mound.If PERSON can get past the growing pains and learn how to bring the same stuff to the mound every fifth day, he has the chance to start, but he has the power stuff and the mean streak to succeed in short relief, as well.

GPE ORGANIZATION hasn't had a player selected in the first three rounds since PERSON (ORGANIZATION) and PERSON (ORGANIZATION) in 1995, but PERSON should end that drought this June. He matched potential first-rounder PERSON pitch for pitch in an April matchup in front of several scouts and obliterated big leaguer PERSON's school strikeout record, fanning 129 in 105 innings heading into the ORGANIZATION tournament. He pitched the ORGANIZATION to their first Mid-American Conference tournament championship by winning two games in five days (and ORGANIZATION honors) while permitting just one unearned run in 13 2/3 innings.One of the hardest-throwing lefty starters in the college ranks, PERSON usually pitches at 91-94 mph and peaks at 96 with late life on his fastball. Though he's not a big guy, he maintains his velocity deep into games and generates it without much effort in his delivery. There's some debate as to which is better, his low-80s slider or his tumbling changeup, but both should be at least average offerings.PERSON has three pitches and fills the strike zone, so he'll definitely be a starter going forward. He fared well against quality competition in the ORGANIZATION last summer, another point in his favor.
GPE is one of the more unique high school pitchers in the class, a plus athlete with a funky cross-body delivery, and a dynamic two-pitch mix.

An 18th-round pick in 2015 who signed for $150,000, PERSON first put himself on the map in '16, when he was among the leaders in the rookie-level GPE League in a host of pitching categories. He further raised his profile in his first full season, posting a 10-1 record and 1.42 ERA over 11 starts at ORGANIZATION A Columbia to earn a promotion to the ORGANIZATION State League. That lasted only two starts, however, as PERSON was shut down in late June with an elbow injury that required PERSON surgery in GPE, costing him all of 2018.A strong and physical right-hander, PERSON will impress with his combination of present stuff and plus control when healthy. His fastball will sit in the 90-94 mph range with riding life to it, and he commands it so well that the pitch usually plays above its velocity grade. He has feel for spinning a breaking ball, throwing a curve that will flash above average at times and a slider he'll mix in occasionally, while his changeup, already an effective weapon against lefties, could become his best secondary pitch with more refinement. He's missed plenty of bats and is an extreme strike-thrower, with career rates of 9.4 K/9 and 1.6 BB/9.PERSON' recovery and rehab was going as planned during Spring Training, and he was expected to open 2019 in the ORGANIZATION State League before he required a procedure to address an ulnar nerve issue in his reconstructed right elbow. It pushed back his return until late June, when he finally took the mound in a Gulf Coast League game, only to land back on the injured list shortly thereafter. The good news is PERSON will be 22 for most of the season, underscoring how he has plenty of time to get back on track and reach his ceiling as a No. 4-type starter.

GPE (Tenn.) PERSON produced PERSON, the ORGANIZATION. 5 overall pick in the 1967 Draft, and PERSON, who pitched 19 years in the Majors. Weathers' son PERSON has the potential to be better than both of them as a lefty with the pitches and polish to work in the front half of a big league rotation. He set a ORGANIZATION high school tournament record with 28 strikeouts last spring, including 12 in a shutout in the Class A championship game, and turned in two scoreless outings for PERSON as it won the 18-and-under World Cup in September.While Weathers lacks a true out pitch, he has three solid offerings and mixes them well. His fastball sits at 90-93 mph and tops out at 95, playing above its velocity with a high spin rate that gives it deceptive riding life. His upper-70s curveball usually features good depth and he possesses an advanced changeup for a teenager.Weathers has a sound delivery and repeats it well, throwing strikes with ease. He's a good athlete who does the little things well and could contribute as a two-way player at ORGANIZATION if he doesn't turn pro. He gets his athleticism from both sides of his family, as his mother, PERSON, was an All-America basketball player at ORGANIZATION.

PERSON pitched five shutout innings to win the deciding game of the ORGANIZATION playoffs last September, and his promising stuff inspires thoughts that more postseason heroics are in the future. He has one of the highest ceilings among ORGANIZATION pitching prospects.PERSON's fastball stands out both for its 93-95 mph velocity and its heavy sink. His hard curveball is becoming a solid offering, and his changeup should improve once he starts using it more often.PERSON threw strikes from the moment he set foot in pro ball. If his pitches develop as hoped, he could be a No. 3 starter.

PERSON drew PERSON comparisons at ORGANIZATION, where he stood out as a star athlete with obvious leadership skills and a strong GPE faith. The ORGANIZATION nominee turned down a chance to sign with the Twins in 2011 and then went 23rd overall to the ORGANIZATION as a senior the following June. They traded him to the Indians in July 2014 for PERSON. Coming out of college, PERSON projected as a solid hitter, but there were mixed opinions on how much power he would have. In his first full pro season, PERSON hit for less average (.265) and more home run power (16) than might have been expected, while spending most of the year in Double-A. He's doing a better job of finding a happy medium this season. PERSON draws a healthy number of walks and has plus speed, though he's not a big baserunning threat. He puts his wheels to good use in center field, and he also has enough arm strength to handle right field.

In 2017, PERSON turned a corner in his draft spring for GPE and looked likely to land in the middle of the first round, flashing four above average pitches and starter command for a No. 3 to 4 starter profile. His elbow blew out before the draft, and he had PERSON surgery a month before the ORGANIZATION eventually took him in the middle of the first round, though for nearly $1.5 million below slot. PERSON came back in 2018 from his surgery and essentially picked right up where he left off, hitting 96 mph and showing the same stuff as before, though it understandably was not quite as consistent. PERSON was almost sent to the ORGANIZATION league to rack up innings but instead will make his full season debut in 2019, likely starting in Hi-A and probably getting some time at Double-A, with a chance for a big league debut in 2020 if all goes to plan.

After getting dealt by the ORGANIZATION in December 2013 as a part of the ORGANIZATION Fister trade, PERSON made his Major ORGANIZATION debut for the ORGANIZATION less than six months later. He beat the ORGANIZATION in his first big league start and then shut out the Twins for six innings in his second. He wasn't able to carve out a full-time role in GPE's crowded rotation, however, and, almost exactly a year after being traded to the ORGANIZATION he was included in a three-team deal that sent him to the D-backs. PERSON throws his fastball in the low 90s and can reach back for a tick more velocity when he needs it. His slider can look slurvy at times, but the best ones have good depth. He has a good feel for his changeup, which is a more consistent offering. His command has improved, but he would benefit from further refinement. PERSON is a good athlete and has proven to be durable, throwing more than 100 innings in each of the last three years. He has the potential to be a middle-of-the-rotation starter and should soon be ready for an extended look in the big leagues.

The D-backs had interest in PERSON, a catcher at the ORGANIZATION of GPE, in 2016, but a hand injury that cost him most of the year clouded things a bit. The ORGANIZATION took a flier on him in the 16th round, but the backstop returned to GPE for another year. PERSON didn't miss on him in 2017, nabbing him in the 20th round. PERSON was sent straight to the Class A Advanced California League for his full-season debut, where he turned in an All-Star season.PERSON was initially coveted, and drafted, for his ability behind the plate. He is a very good receiver with outstanding leadership skills, always a desirable trait in a catcher. His average arm plays up because he has a very quick release, and he's done a nice job controlling the running game as a pro. His offensive ability has been a very pleasant surprise. He's shown the ability to barrel up the baseball consistently, with a good feel for the strike zone. While he may never be a huge home-run guy, he does have some sneaky pop that should keep pitchers honest. He's a below-average runner, but he's not a clogger on the basepaths.The organization may have thought they were taking a shot on a college catcher who might be a solid big league backup in the future. That might be his long-term role when all is said and done, but the start of his pro career has some D-backs brass thinking he might develop into an everyday big league backstop.

PERSON was projected to be PERSON's top starter in 2014 before undergoing PERSON surgery, sidelining him for a part of the '15 season as well. However, he pitched well enough after his return to convince the FACILITY to select him in the fifth round of last year's Draft. PERSON healthy, PERSON impressed during his professional debut between the ORGANIZATION and GPE leagues and then followed it with a strong instructional league, showing a 93-96 mph fastball and a plus curveball. He also features a slider with average potential and has feel for a changeup. PERSON' 6-foot-1, 190-pound frame raises questions about his durability, though he hasn't had problems holding his velocity as a professional.While the FACILITY expect to deploy PERSON as a starter at ORGANIZATION A Advanced Winston-Salem in 2016, his two plus pitches also give him potential as a late-inning reliever, one who could move up the ladder quickly with a shift to the bullpen.

GPE has produced some very good Draft talent on the mound, with first-rounders PERSON and PERSON in 2002 and, more recently, PERSON in 2015. As a big right-hander like GPE, PERSON gets compared to him frequently and while he's not quite as advanced as his predecessor, there is still a lot to like about him.The 6-foot-4 hurler with a commitment to GPE has the chance to have a very solid three-pitch mix. He'll touch 94 mph with his fastball and sits comfortably around 92 mph, throwing it with good sink and without a ton of effort. His 78-80 mph curveball is an average breaking ball now and he has a good feel for his 79-81 mph changeup. He's around the zone with all three offerings and he's a decent athlete, so he should continue to repeat his delivery well. There is some drop and drive in his mechanics at times, but nothing that can't be corrected. He did throw well during PERSON's annual trip to GPE this spring.PERSON's room to add strength combined with coming from a colder climate add up to a good amount of projection. He's not likely to join his brethren in the first round, but he has opened up enough eyes to potentially be taken in the top three.

PERSON emerged late in the 2018 draft, first getting national scouting attention in the spring at a high school in the GPE suburbs. He's a prototypical projection prospect, with a great frame, solid average present power, and athletic actions. Scouts who are optimistic see the components of a 45 or 50 hit tool and 60 or more future raw power in an everyday right field profile. Since PERSON is somewhat raw and hasn't faced a lot of high level pitching, there are concerns that the hit tool never materializes enough to get to the rest of his tools.

ORGANIZATION Premier Event: Jan. 21, 2017 - ORGANIZATION MLB Team: PERSON ORGANIZATION MLB Player: PERSON is a left-handed pitcher who posted an outstanding 6-1 record with an 0.98 ERA and struck out 76 batters over 46 innings in his 2016 junior campaign.Waller was a member of the ORGANIZATION All-Tournament Team in both 2015 and '16, and was also ranked as a top 10 pitcher by PERSON. In addition to those accolades, the ORGANIZATION commit was selected to the GPE scout team.

PERSON was the second catcher to be selected in the 2013 Draft, going to the ORGANIZATION with the ORGANIZATION. 21 overall pick. He stood out most for his offensive potential as an amateur, but his bat has come along slowly as a professional and now lags behind his defense. He began the 2016 season at ORGANIZATION A Advanced ORGANIZATION and was in the midst of a breakout offensive campaign when a hand injury sent him to the disabled list in early June. He still made plenty of progress, especially behind the plate, and then made up for lost time in the ORGANIZATION before spending all of 2017 in Double-A. Left off the ORGANIZATION' 40-man roster after the season, PERSON received a 50-game suspension in February after his second positive test for a drug of abuse. PERSON has made considerable strides in improving his blocking and receiving since signing. His plus arm strength and sound catch-and-throw skills help him control the running game, and he's thrown out exactly 50 percent of attempted basestealers in his career after posting a career-best 59-percent clip at ORGANIZATION in 2016. Meanwhile, club officials are quick to praise PERSON's leadership qualities and feel for handling a staff. PERSON is less advanced from the left side of the plate, where he employs an up-the-middle approach and produces good bat speed, but needs to do a better job controlling the strike zone. Even if PERSON's bat fails to develop as hoped, the defense alone could make him a quality backup at the highest level.

The top pitcher in GPE's 2016 recruiting class, ORGANIZATION was carving out a role as a freshman when he blew out his elbow in April. He returned to the mound a year later following PERSON surgery and has emerged as the ORGANIZATION' closer this spring. He offers additional intrigue because of the college relievers projected to go in the first five or six rounds, he might have the best chance to transition to starting in pro ball.Coming out of the bullpen, ORGANIZATION sits at 93-95 mph and can reach 96 with riding life on his four-seam fastball. He's doing a better job of generating velocity without overthrowing this spring, helping his ability to pound the bottom of the strike zone. He backs it up with a low-80s breaking ball that combines slider power with curveball depth.Both of ORGANIZATION's pitches grade as plus at their best, and he's throwing more strikes than ever. To succeed in a pro rotation, he'll need to develop a changeup after having little use for one to this point of his career. His strong 6-foot-3 frame is built for durability and his dramatically improved command bodes well for his future.

A reliever for his first two years at FACILITY in GPE, PERSON moved into the rotation as a junior. The right-hander saw his stock rise considerably as he put up tremendous numbers as a Friday night starter in the ORGANIZATION, going 9-3 with a 1.73 ORGANIZATION and a 121-15 strikeout-to-walk ratio in 114 1/3 innings. The GPE made PERSON its third-round pick in June and signed him for a slightly less than pick value.PERSON fills up the strike zone with four different pitches. He lacks velocity, pitching mostly with an average fastball, though he was up to 93-94 mph in relief stints last summer in the ORGANIZATION. His best pitch is his slider/cutter. It's a plus pitch thrown around 88 mph, but with slider action. Without it, he'd be a fairly pedestrian right-hander, given that his curve is fringy and he doesn't use his changeup much.While PERSON's pitchability and command could allow for him to develop into a back-end starter, he also could move quickly through the GPE' system as a reliever based on the strength of his fastball-cutter combination.

Hailing from the same GPE high school as GPE right-hander PERSON, PERSON took an over-pick-value deal to sign rather than attend the ORGANIZATION of GPE, where his uncle had been an All-American pitcher.PERSON's solid stuff, projectability, makeup and bloodlines, make him an intriguing prospect. He already throws 88-92 mph, and there's room for growth in his 6-foot-5 frame -- with more angle than life currently on his fastball. PERSON has a feel for spinning the ball, but needs to add more power to his curve. He also could use more deceptive arm speed with his changeup, though it has some promising fade.PERSON has a loose arm that works well, and he could have three solid or better pitches once he gets stronger and maintains a consistent arm slot. With a former All-American uncle and a father who starred collegiately as well, the upside is clearly there.

PERSON is one of the two pitchers the ORGANIZATION got from the ORGANIZATION, along with shortstop PERSON, in the ORGANIZATION deal. The 2012 season was the first full one in which PERSON was a full-time starter and he has pitched well in that role, making his Major League debut in June. He has a good three-pitch mix, starting with a plus fastball that can be up to 97 mph, and he maintains his velocity deep into starts. His breaking ball sometimes features late bite and it can be an above-average pitch. His changeup is below average right now, and he does have trouble commanding his pitches. That, and a tendency to fall off to the first-base side, has some thinking he might end up going back to a bullpen role, but the pure stuff and stamina make it worth keeping him going as a starter for as long as possible.

In terms of pure raw tools, no one stands ahead of PERSON in the ORGANIZATION' organization. ORGANIZATION Premier Event: Feb. 5, 2017 - ORGANIZATION MLB Team: PERSON ORGANIZATION MLB Player: PERSON, a commit to PERSON, hit over .400, drilled 33 ORGANIZATION and knocked four long balls in his last high school season. PERSON was a bit of a sleeper at ORGANIZATION, overshadowed by more famous underclassmen. But he's a great defender, he has an advanced lefty stick, potentially and perhaps emerging power. The starter at third base as a freshman on PERSON's 2017 College World Series runner-up team, PERSON was slated to move to shortstop as a sophomore. The ORGANIZATION landed two of the most polished pitchers in the 2015 PERSON, pairing collegian PERSON in the first round with PERSON in the third. After logging 39 innings as a true freshman in 2016, PERSON garnered Mid-American Conference pitcher of the year honors as both as sophomore and junior, going a combined 15-3 in 30 starts with 251 strikeouts in 170 2/3 innings between the two years. PERSON doesn't fit into a neat box as a right-hander who lacks physical projection, pitches with below-average velocity and lacks a put-away secondary pitch, but there's something to be said for the effectiveness of his fastball and the sustained success he's had as a result. PERSON entered pro ball with limited pedigree as a 17th rounder from a smaller ORGANIZATION junior college and walked a batter per inning in his pro debut. 2018 was a different story, as PERSON breezed through both A-ball levels, then finally ran into some trouble in Double-A as more advanced hitters didn't just chase every pitch he threw out of the zone. So prodigious is PERSON's laser arm that some amateur scouts wanted to see him on the mound in pro ball. PERSON batted just .229 in his first two pro seasons while trying to adjust to catching at the pro level, though he did hit 10 homers in 56 games at ORGANIZATION PERSON in 2013. PERSON by the Cards in '12. His strong arm fits just as well in right field, where he can become an average defender.

Recruited as a middle infielder by PERSON, PERSON wound up starting up behind the plate for the ORGANIZATION and has seen extensive action at both spots since signing for $95,000 as a ninth-round pick. Though he doesn't have PERSON's power or offensive upside, PERSON has better catch-and-throw skills. At 5-foot-11 and 174 pounds, GPE is a strong and athletic middle infielder with the potential be a special hitter.First of all, scouts like GPE's balanced hitting approach at the plate, quick hands and short swing. He's also a decent runner and will not clog up the bases.GPE, who is from GPE, GPE, is represented by PERSON. The Indians are the favorite to sign the teenager.

Drafted in the 35th round out of a ORGANIZATION high school by the ORGANIZATION in 2010, PERSON headed south for college, and he became the first first-round pick in GPE history. PERSON was the ace starter for one of the most prospect-laden prep teams in the country in 2015, PERSON, which was led by 11th overall pick catcher PERSON (Reds) and center fielder PERSON (ORGANIZATION), who got a $500,000 bonus in the 24th round. PERSON signed for $500,000 (late third, early fourth round money) as a fifth round high schooler in 2017. PERSON, a GPE recruit, entered the spring with a chance to follow in the footsteps of PERSON, PERSON and PERSON as a GPE high school outfielder selected in the top 10 picks. If one was to base PERSON's Draft status on his summer showcase performance, he'd be approaching the top group of high school right-handers in the country. And he's lost sharpness in his breaking ball as well, a pitch that flashed plus at times and was up into the mid-80s but this spring has come in closer to 80 mph. A 10th-round pick of the ORGANIZATION out of the GPE high school ranks in 2013, PERSON was actually born in GPE but came to the GPE for high school. PERSON was unheralded as an amateur in the ORGANIZATION, signing for just $20,000 in 2011. A high school shortstop who received an above-pick-value deal to sign in 2012, PERSON has moved to the right side of the diamond, and he has the makings of an offensive-minded second baseman.PERSON made strides with his defense at second, improving his footwork around the bag considerably.
