GPE burst onto the national scene last summer hitting 100 mph at multiple events and flashing two plus breaking balls. That alone is enough to go on the first day if the health checks out, which GPE's does. The neutral aspect is that he's a maxed-out 6-foot-2, 200 pounds. The negative aspect is a very long arm stroke and as you might guess, a power approach rather than fine command. No prep prospect can be everything as an 18-year-old but GPE's velocity was 95-98, touching 100 this spring in early starts with lots of rest and was more 92-96 touching 97 when on normal rest. Pitchers lose velocity as they age, so many teams prefer a more conventional delivery and arm stroke, and a pitcher with average stuff and good feel who can grow into power stuff, rather than a power pitcher who has to learn feel only when his stuff declines. The recent track record of prep pitchers who hit 98-100 before the draft is riddled with injuries and command regression. With prep pitching being so subject to specific team tastes to try to avoid busts and attrition, many teams are out on GPE on Day 1 and others, particularly the more progressive clubs that value velo, spin rate, high octane stuff in shorter stints, and area control with that stuff, are interested in the 20s and 30s.

PERSON had the highest ceiling among prep pitchers in the 2015 Draft, but he lasted 27 picks because he was inconsistent at FACILITY (Pa.) High and the industry is skittish about taking high school right-handers in the first round. After PERSON signed him for $2.3 million, he recorded an 11.72 ERA with 32 walks in 17 2/3 innings in GPE ball. The Rockies view his rocky pro debut as growing pains rather than a cause for concern, and he didn't look nearly as overmatched when he returned to GPE Junction this summer.When PERSON has his mechanics in sync, he can deliver ace-caliber stuff. He can sit in the low 90s with sink on his two-seam fastball and hit 97 with running life on his four-seamer. He also can show a hammer curveball in the low 80s and even flash a plus changeup.PERSON is still growing into his 6-foot-5 frame and leaning to repeat his delivery and maintain a consistent arm slot. He also needs to get stronger to hold his stuff deeper into games. Youth is on his side because he's only 19, and so is the athleticism that made him an all-conference quarterback in high school before he opted to focus on baseball.

An 18-year-old leviathan, PERSON is much more physical than his listed 180 pounds, and it's shocking to watch him use his instincts and first step to close on balls in center field, even though he likely won't play there for very long. He has exceptional hand-eye coordination and finds all sorts of ways to put the bat head on the ball but too often, he offers at pitcher's pitches and settles for sub-optimal contact. He has a gorgeous, low-ball left-handed swing that could produce power if PERSON learned to attack the right pitches. The near bottom-of-the-scale walk rates each of his first two years are certainly a red flag, but PERSON' size and hitting ability make him an intriguing, high-ceiling flier.

The first high school position player taken in the 2014 Draft, PERSON is the son of former big league pitcher PERSON and PERSON's younger brother. He more than held his own as one of the youngest regulars in the ORGANIZATION in his first full season of pro ball, showing why the PERSON took him No. 5 overall.Not known to have a ridiculously high ceiling, PERSON can do a lot of things well, with a higher floor than most high school draftees. He should hit for average, with a line-drive approach from the left side of the plate, and there should be a little extra-base pop as he adds strength. While he's just an average runner, he's an excellent baserunner who has showed some base-stealing ability. That speed gives him just average range, but he has terrific instincts, good hands and a very strong arm, leaving no question he can stay at shortstop long-term.The PERSON never had much doubt PERSON would be a big leaguer one day. How he's begun his career has the organization more enthused about just how good of a player he'll be once he gets there.

PERSON is physical for his age and has some of the class' best present raw power. His wrists whip through the baseball and he extends and rotates beautifully through contact. PERSON's swing has some length and his already strong build raises questions about his physical projection and ultimate defensive home.

PERSON GPE, a ORGANIZATION III school in GPE, GPE, has had a grand total of four players drafted from its baseball program, the most recent coming back in 2001. PERSON not only is poised to become the first draftee since then, but also the first one ever with the potential to go in the top 10 rounds.The first thing that stands out about PERSON is his size, and it's something that came late to him. The right-hander was reportedly 6-foot-3 and throwing in the low-80s at the end of high school. Now he's 6-foot-10 and has added a lot of velocity, throwing his fastball up to 97 mph consistently. Because he hasn't always thrown that hard, PERSON has an idea of how to pitch, mixing in his secondary offerings effectively, flashing average sliders and changeups. While he comes across his body with his short-strided delivery, the ball comes out of his hand clean and easy, and he's thrown strikes this year.PERSON has become one of the most intriguing Draft prospects in the ORGANIZATION, if not the country. It's hard to know exactly what he'll become, but he's moved himself firmly into Day 2 Draft status, with teams likely to want to give PERSON the chance to figure it out in their system.

In many ways, the first half of PERSON's 2018 season was just like that of GPE righty PERSON, who's now in the overall top 100 picture because his stuff exploded late in the year. Like PERSON, PERSON mostly pitched out of the bullpen at a second tier GPE college and only began starting full time in 2018. He was probably slightly underscouted as an amateur, and definitely underdeveloped. For a month and a half of 2018, he showed mid-rotation stuff, then blew out his elbow and needed PERSON. He may not be back in affiliated ball until late next summer, but he was quite young for a college draftee (another trait he shares with PERSON) and has more developmental wiggle room for a setback like this than most of his peers would. He's a 2019 ORGANIZATION breakout candidate.

PERSON pitched sparingly as a GPE freshman in 2013 before transferring to GPE, where he led the LOCATION Conference with 11 wins as a redshirt junior in 2016. Signed for $180,000 as an 11th-rounder that summer, he didn't allow an earned run during his brief pro debut and has exceeded expectations in his first full pro season. He earned a promotion to high Class A in mid-May and forced his way into PERSON's rotation three weeks later. PERSON's best trait is his command of a 91-94 mph fastball that tops out at 96. He backs it up with an improving curveball that shows signs of becoming a consistently solid second offering. His changeup lags behinds his other two pitches, though he has handled left-handed hitters well so far.After looking like he might move quickly as a reliever, PERSON will remain a starter for now. He's not the most physical pitcher, but he's so efficient that he can work deep into games without running up high pitch counts. He projects as a possible innings-eater toward the back of a big league rotation.

PERSON looked like a sure 1st rounder early in the spring when he hit 98 mph with a plus slider and enough feel to pitch, but he started thinking too much, tinkered with his delivery and everything backed up later in the spring. A team buying into the early spring performance could take him in the top 40-50 picks.

PERSON didn't sign as the #1 overall pick last year of GPE due to a failed physical because of his elbow. His medicals are out now and how teams interpret them will dicate if he goes mid-1st round or slides to the 2nd.

PERSON took full-season ball by storm in 2012, earning a late promotion from the ORGANIZATION to the GPE League while finishing fifth in the organization in saves and striking out better than 14 batters per nine innings. With an unorthodox delivery, PERSON adds deception to an already live fastball that tails and sinks. He can reach back for extra when he needs to and is particularly effective when he keeps it down in the zone. His slider can be slurvy at times, but it has good bite to it when he throws it hard enough. Those two pitches along, along with average command, should be enough to get him to a big league bullpen in the near future.

PERSON struck out 133 batters as a LOCATION junior to establish a single-season record, surpassing former big leaguer PERSON on the school's all-time list. The PERSON took him in the second round that June, then assigned him directly to Class A Advanced Frederick for his first full season. PERSON pitched to mixed results early before settling in during the second half, and he built upon that success during a breakout Double-A campaign in 2018. He was named PERSON's ORGANIZATION pitcher of the year and garnered similar honors in the LOCATION after he led the circuit in wins (14), strikeouts (142), and batting average against (.225), and posted the third-best ORGANIZATION (3.27).PERSON's repeatable delivery and clean arm action allow him to paint both sides of the plate with a fastball that sits at 91-94 mph and touches 95. An above-average slider in the low 80s is PERSON's best secondary pitch, and he also demonstrates feel for a changeup that's at least average. He throws each of his three pitches for strikes and is comfortable pitching inside against right-handed hitters with his fastball. While he doesn't generate many ground balls and at times is prone to the long ball, PERSON does induce a healthy number of whiffs and induces weak contact by effectively changing speeds.The PERSON changed PERSON's heel placement on the rubber back in 2017, and that adjustment has helped him stay on line to the plate and better execute his pitches. He still has gains to make both with his control and command, but all the ingredients are there for PERSON to serve as a No. 4 starter, perhaps more, if he continues down his current developmental path.

PERSON hit several balls in excess of 110 mph during PERSON's opening weekend of his draft season, and he ended up slugging .652 that year. We were all-in despite scout concerns about his lack of range in the outfield and fear that he might just be a DH. The gap between where we had PERSON on our pre-draft board (12) and where he went (20) was large enough that we wondered if we were too high. Then PERSON hit .303/.390/.500 in pro ball during the rest of the summer, and we could sleep again. He has huge raw power and doesn't swing with violence or effort to generate it; it's just there. We're very optimistic about him hitting enough to profile in an outfield corner.

PERSON helped his cause in the 2016 ORGANIZATION by displaying some of the best spin rates at the World Wood Bat Association World Championship in the fall before his senior year, and then getting off to a fast start last spring. Though his velocity dipped as the ORGANIZATION approached, he still went in the third round. The first player ever selected out of GPE (ORGANIZATION, GPE), the alma mater of big leaguer PERSON (who was drafted out of junior college), he signed for an above-slot $1 million. PERSON had a low-80s fastball as a sophomore but now works at 90-93 mph and hits 95 after he began to mature physically. There's still considerable projection remaining in his lanky 6-foot-6 frame, so he could continue to add more velocity. The high spin rate on his heater gives it riding life that makes it difficult to barrel. Though he also generates high spin rates on his curveball, PERSON has had more success with a harder slider that he began throwing during his senior season. He has just begun to work in earnest on his changeup, which is too firm at this point. His slingy delivery gives him deception and didn't prevent him from filling the strike zone during his pro debut.

It's taken a little while, but the lefty drafted out of the GPE junior college ranks in 2008 is getting closer to being ready to contribute to a big league bullpen. He throws a heavy, sinking fastball along with a solid late-breaking slurvy type of breaking ball. He'll even mix in an average changeup at times. PERSON reached Double-A for the first time in 2012 and was following that up with a strong full season in the LOCATION, where he continues to miss a lot of bats and cause lefties fits. At the very least, he's a specialist, but he has the chance to be a solid middle or setup man in the future.
PERSON slings from a 3/4 slot with above average stuff and some feel and benefitted from scouts coming to see PERSON and GPE this spring, with PERSON likely going second of that group.

PERSON's broad, square, muscular shoulders look like they belong to a D1 high school football prospect. He has one of the better frames of all the 17-year-old hitters in pro ball, and plenty of room to add power to a body that already produces a lot of it. PERSON has explosive hands and a natural uppercut swing. He hits many more balls out during BP than is typical for a hitter this age, and has taken his peers deep in games, too. 
PERSON's feet and actions are workable on the infield but he struggles with throwing velocity and accuracy when he's forced to throw from a lower arm slot, as shortstops often are. If he can't correct that, he'll need to move to the outfield. If he can, this is a shortstop with 80 bat speed. PERSON is a potential superstar. Much of his profile (the plate discipline, ultimate defensive home) is still not in focus, but this young man has rare physical talent.

Few college players in the 2018 Draft can match PERSON's youth (he won't turn 21 until September) and track record. He cracked PERSON's LOCATION rotation as a freshman, became its No. 1 starter as a sophomore and performed well in the ORGANIZATION and with PERSON during his two summers. Though his velocity has been down this spring, he still should fit somewhere in the first two rounds.PERSON could have three solid or better pitches when all is said and done. After touching 96 mph in the past, he's working more at 88-91 and topping out at 93, but his fastball is still effective because he uses his 6-foot-3 frame and a high three-quarters arm slot to deliver it on a steep downhill plane. He trusts his advanced changeup more than his slider, which can get slurvy at ORGANIZATION's stuff, strong frame and competitiveness could make him an innings-eating No. 3 or 4 starter. Prone to occasional lapses of control in previous years, he has pounded the strike zone better than ever this spring. He'll need to watch his conditioning to reach his potential.

In less than one baseball season, PERSON went from pitching in a low-level independent league to getting meaningful outs in the ORGANIZATION' second consecutive run to the postseason in 2014. ORGANIZATION issues and shoulder fatigue created a stumbling block at the outset of his 2015 season and just as he was getting his groove back, another shoulder problem forced him to the disabled list in July.At age 27, PERSON isn't your typical prospect, but after years of struggling, he's figured some things out, both physically and mentally. The big right-hander has always been able to throw hard and miss bats, with a fastball that hits triple-digits at times. He throws a slider and an uncommon palmball, but during his big league debut, hitters mostly saw the plus velocity and movement of his fastball. In the past, PERSON had difficulty finding the strike zone with any consistency and that returned in 2015 at times. He was throwing more strikes before landing on the DL.His days of indy ball hopefully behind him, if PERSON can stay healthy, he has the opportunity to pitch a lot more meaningful innings in a big league bullpen.

The athletic PERSON is small compared some of the other prospects in this year's class, but his tools have big potential.The center fielder has a chance to be a plus hitter, a plus runner and a plus center fielder. He has been compared to a young Ender Inciarte and a teenage PERSON with better tools at the same age. He projects to have an average arm.At the plate, PERSON has a nice and easy swing with good bat speed. He can drive the ball to all fields with hard contact and has shown enough pop to make some believe he will develop future power potential. He is expected to hit for average.Evaluators like that PERSON is polished for his age and has track record of success in games, a history that includes participation in national and international tournaments for Venezuela.The teenager is trained and represented by PERSON and PERSON of O.L. PERSON in GPE. The ORGANIZATION are the favorite to sign him.

PERSON was among the players the ORGANIZATION considered selecting with the first overall pick in the 2013 Draft. They ultimately chose PERSON and PERSON landed with the ORGANIZATION at ORGANIZATION. 6 overall. A little more than a year later, the ORGANIZATION added PERSON as well, acquiring him from the ORGANIZATION as a part of the trade that sent PERSON to GPE. PERSON comes from a baseball family (his brother, PERSON, and his uncle, B.J. PERSON, have both played professionally) and he has a good understanding of the game. His advanced approach at the plate and ability to put the barrel on the ball translate into high batting averages. Though he has raw power, his swing consistently produces line drives than home runs.PERSON doesn't contribute a lot beyond his offensive production. His lack of speed limits him on the bases and restricts hisrange at third base. He does have sure hands and a solid arm at the hot corner.
GPE is one of the youngest players in the draft class and flashes five tools that are average or better, including a long track record of making hard contact.

PERSON was a two-way player at ORGANIZATION, but thanks to a quick arm and power stuff, scouts liked him more as a pitcher than a hitter. PERSON's fastball sits in the low-90s, and he touches 96 mph. He combines it with a solid changeup and a slider. PERSON has a cross-fire delivery that adds deception but may affect his command. He has been used as both a reliever and a starter in the ORGANIZATION and could still end up in either role in the ORGANIZATION. He spent most of the 2013 season as part of a crowded rotation at ORGANIZATION before making his big league debut in September. He allowed just one run on 11 hits and a walk with 14 strikeouts over 11 innings in two starts for GPE.

PERSON had a legendary college career at ORGANIZATION, where he always performed despite some year-to-year fluctuations in his velocity. He carved up the ORGANIZATION with just two pitches, and repertoire depth, the velo issues, and the violence in PERSON's delivery all contributed to the amateur scouting world's opinion that he would be a reliever in pro ball. PERSON's changeup usage increased dramatically in 2018 and the pitch improved. His curevball doesn't have big raw spin but it's still really effective and remains his best pitch. His delivery is deceptive and enables his fastball to play despite below-average velocity. It appears there's a starter's arsenal here and PERSON threw plenty of strikes in 2018. If he's living off of deception, perhaps his future role will be limited to a one time through the order type of guy, but that's still more than a generic 40 FV reliever.

After having five right-handers selected in the top five rounds of the last four GPE, PERSON produced two more viable candidates for the 2017 Draft in relievers PERSON and PERSON. The ORGANIZATION' career saves leader with 27, PERSON was the first of the pair to be selected, going to the ORGANIZATION in the fourth round and then signing for $400,000.PERSON has a quick arm that consistently produces 93-95 mph fastballs with heavy sink that he can command to either side of the plate. He usually throws his low-80s slider for strikes and can turn it into more of a cutter, though it also gets slurvy at times. He shows some feel for a changeup but doesn't need it much in a relief role.PERSON has a strong, durable frame and three pitches, so a team could be tempted to try him in the rotation. He doesn't have a classic starter's delivery, but he does repeat it well. If he stays in the bullpen, he could become a seventh-inning reliever and perhaps more if he can refine his slider.

PERSON was playing in the ORGANIZATION last year when rumors of the big ORGANIZATION-Marlins trade began spreading. The toolsy outfielder finished the ORGANIZATION season in a ORGANIZATION uniform then was officially dealt two days after the season's completion as part of the package that netted ORGANIZATION, PERSON, PERSON and company. When he's locked in, PERSON oozes with tools. He has a lot more raw power to grow into, more than he's shown in games so far. His above-average speed plays up even more because of his outstanding baserunning instincts. He's an excellent defender in center field, with more than enough range to stay there, though his solid arm would work from right. Perhaps the only thing holding PERSON back might be some holes in his swing, and he's shown the ability at times to make adjustments to lessen them, something that will help him become a complete hitter. PERSON bounced back from a breaking his left hand in GPE Training to make his Major League debut in July.Bernie Pleskoff's scouting report

Long known to area scouts in LOCATION for his multiple tools, PERSON jumped onto bigger radar screens with a strong performance in this year's PERSON. He's not a slam-dunk early-round choice, as some don't necessarily see him translating those tools into consistent production, but he's shown enough to warrant some top six round consideration.PERSON's best now tool is his speed and he's been recorded with 4.1-second times out of the left-handed batter's box to first base this spring. That speed should allow him to be a threat on the bases as well as cover a ground in the outfield. He has some skills at the plate and makes hard contact when he stays behind the ball. There is a ton of raw power which shows up in GPE, but not yet consistently in games. With enough arm and instincts, he has the chance to stay in center long-term, unless he fills out his 6-foot-5 frame too much, in which case he could fit a corner outfield profile from a power perspective just fine.While opinions of PERSON varied, there are some who feel he's the type of player who could exceed projections. A LOCATION commit, some see an PERSON body type, with production to potentially follow.Prospect ORGANIZATION - PERSON, GPE.

A fifth-round pick out of ORGANIZATION State in 2014, PERSON did nothing but hit during his first full season of pro ball. The first baseman raked across two levels of Class A ball, leading the organization in a host of offensive categories. He continued that trend with a jump to Double-A in 2016.PERSON has shown an advanced approach at the plate, with solid average hit and power tools. A leg kick that he added to his right-handed swing helped him reach that power more consistently, and he continued to be a run-producer during his stint in the GPE ORGANIZATION over the winter. His feel to hit should allow him to continue to produce as he reaches the upper levels.PERSON is a capable defender at first base, but he is limited to that corner infield position only. Right-handed hitters who can only play first are somewhat limited and often have to fight against that stigma. PERSON' start is encouraging, though Phillies fans should be reminded they were equally enthused about a similar player in GPE, who also has the versatility of being able to man left field. PERSON has proven he can crush left-handed pitching. Whether PERSON can be more than a similar platoon partner remains to be seen.

One of the better two-way talents in the 2018 Draft class, GPE has a fastball that peaks in the low 90s and a promising breaking ball. He shows even more promise as a hitter, enough to get selected as early as the third round. Whether that will be high enough to lure him away from a ORGANIZATION commitment remains to be seen.GPE's quick right-handed swing with loft and his strength combine to generate impressive raw power, which he showed off by finishing second in the home run derby at the ORGANIZATION All-American Classic last August. He lets his pop come naturally and uses the entire field, showing the potential to hit for average as well. He has a track record of performing well against top competition on the showcase circuit, starring on the loaded PERSON travel team.While GPE is a well below-average runner, he moves well enough to make plays at third base. His hands and arm strength are assets, and he could become a solid defender if he can improve his agility. He'll have to maintain the conditioning of his thick frame to remain at the hot corner.
Converted infielder is up to 99 mph at times with a plus-flashing slider, but an arm action and feel likely more suited to relief.

The younger brother of ORGANIZATION prospect D.J., PERSON came to the ORGANIZATION in December 2014 as part of the package from the ORGANIZATION in the ORGANIZATION deal. He was off to a solid start in his first season in the organization when he was involved in the ORGANIZATION bus accident. He missed a few weeks right when he was red-hot, struggled after his return, but righted the ship some in the season's final month.While his 2015 campaign was definitely up and down, he showed some of the offensive prowess that made him a second-round pick of the ORGANIZATION in 2013. He's one of the better right-handed power bats in the system. With that power is going to come a fair share of strikeouts, but PERSON offsets that with improved discipline at the plate and a willingness to draw walks. The ORGANIZATION felt he looked too stiff and forced at third, the position he played early in his pro career, so they moved him to the outfield and he made a fairly seamless transition to left.The upper levels of the ORGANIZATION will be a good test for PERSON to see if he can iron out his inconsistencies at the plate. If he can, he has the chance to develop into a run-producing corner outfielder in the big leagues.

PERSON was an upside, cold-weather hitter to watch in the 2018 draft class but he exceeded expectations in the spring, rising into discussions for the middle of the first round. He landed near the top of a group of top-tier toolsy outfielders, flashing plus raw power, speed, and arm strength. He also went on a tear down the stretch in the ORGANIZATION state playoffs when high-level scouts were coming in for looks, hitting homer after homer. Some scouts were still uncertain about PERSON's ultimate upside, arguing that his style of hitting indicates a swing flaw. To possess premium bat speed and face pitching in the 80s and still hit opposite field homers indicates PERSON was late on subpar stuff, and his deep hand load (which helps create the power) means this approach and his ultimate upside might not work in pro ball. While it's too early to pass judgment on that opinion, PERSON struggled against good pitching in his pro debut and in instructional league, often exhibiting poor timing and ending up late on good fastballs. The Rays aren't worried -- expectations for cold-weather hitters are close to nil in their pro debut, not only because of the big jump in competition but also because they're playing the longest season of their lives. PERSON may start 2019 in extended spring training so the org can keep a close eye on his habits and challenges in a controlled environment, but his upside is still among the best in his draft class.

Drafted by the ORGANIZATION in 2010, PERSON was traded to the ORGANIZATION as a part of the two teams' 10-player deal in July 2012. His progress was slowed in 2014 by a strained lat that sidelined him for much of the first half, but he has been healthy this year and made his big league debut in April. PERSON throws his fastball in the low 90s, using both sides of the plate effectively. He mixes in a slider and changeup, but lacks a true out pitch. He works around the zone with his whole arsenal and does a lot of little things well, helping him to succeed without premium stuff. PERSON has been a starter throughout his career, but might end up fitting better in the bullpen in the long run. He appeared to be on the cusp of reaching the big leagues before his injury in 2014 and could soon be ready for his shot.
A soft-tossing, funky lefty with a plus slider and plus-plus command, PERSON's bag of tricks has garnered strikeouts at elite rates through the mid-minors. He might pitch his way into a bullpen role.

GPE has not developed as expected to this point. We anticipated he'd move quickly to third base in pro ball, but hit for enough power to overcome it. Instead, he has held serve a shortstop and only just begun to see time at third, but has struggled to get to his considerable raw power in games. His lower half usage has improved, but GPE's bat still has downward entry into the hitting zone and he doesn't extend well through contact. He has a nearly 50% groundball rate as a pro and ends up pushing a lot of contact the other way. There's ceiling here because of GPE's shot to stay at short and adjust his way into game power, but there's a low floor if he moves to third and can't make tweaks.

6/12: PERSON makes 2019 debutAt the start of his junior season at GPE in 2016, PERSON was viewed as a possible No. 1 pick for that June's Draft. An inconsistent junior year dropped him from the top spot, but the A's were happy to take him with the sixth overall selection and gave him just over $4 million to sign him. He made it to Double-A in his first full season and pitched in the ORGANIZATION and seemed poised to make the leap to GPE in 2018. He was derailed from the fast track when he needed PERSON surgery last April.In 2017, PERSON led the Minors with his 13.2 strikeouts-per-nine, a testament to a full repertoire of outstanding stuff. He'll throw his fastball up to 96-97 mph and he uses one of the best sliders in the Minors, to miss a ton of bats. He mixes in a curveball and his changeup, once a distant fourth pitch, has become a devastating out pitch as well, flashing plus at times. He uses his 6-foot-7 frame very well, with excellent extension.PERSON had improved his ability to find the strike zone as his first full season wore on, though there might be a learning curve command-wise as he returns from elbow surgery. Assuming he can get back to where he was in terms of that and his feel for all of his pitches, he should still be able to reach his ceiling as a No. 2 type starter.

Though PERSON was the hardest thrower in their system, he was so raw that the ORGANIZATION declined to protect him on their 40-man roster after the 2014 season. The ORGANIZATION picked him in the Rule 5 Draft and immediately sold him to the GPE, who couldn't keep him and lost him on waivers to the ORGANIZATION. Returned to GPE right before the start of last season, he skipped a level to Double-A and had his most consistent year as a pro to earn a spot on the 40-man this time around.PERSON has a lightning-fast arm that has regularly produced upper-90s fastballs since he became a full-time reliever toward the end of 2014. He can reach 102 mph with his heater, though it gets straight toward the upper limits of its velocity. He pairs his fastball with a slider than can creep into the low 90s and runs the gamut between a wipeout pitch and a below-average slurve.PERSON has the pure stuff to become a closer but still has a lot of work to do to reach his ceiling. He has spotty control and command, in part because he falls in love with radar-gun readings, overthrows and has trouble repeating his mechanics. He also allowed more hits than he had strikeouts in his first two years in full-season ball, which may be a sign that he lacks deception.

PERSON got better and better last summer, taking a step forward at the ORGANIZATION in GPE and then another at ORGANIZATION's World Wood Bat Association World Championship two months later. That trajectory had him working his way up the list of high-school right-handers in this Draft class. PERSON 6-foot-6 and 210 pounds, PERSON has the look of a big leaguer. He uses his size to throw his fastball on a step downhill plane, and he worked at 91-94 mph and touched 96 early in his start at the ORGANIZATION event. He still needs to add strength to show that velocity more consistently and deeper into ballgames.PERSON's curveball and command were unreliable at times earlier in the summer, but he did a better job throwing tight mid-70s breaking balls and filling the strike zone at later events on the showcase circuit. He'll also flash a decent changeup. A St. PERSON's recruit, he has a loose arm and a sound delivery for someone with his youth and size.

A two-way talent coming out of the GPE high school ranks, PERSON played the outfield and pitched briefly in relief for Stanford as a freshman. He left the mound behind for good as a sophomore and has been a mainstay in the lineup the last two seasons, putting up solid, albeit unspectacular numbers along the way.PERSON entered the spring as a college performer who had the chance to move up boards, maybe even into Day 1 territory, with a strong junior season, especially after an All-Star performance in the ORGANIZATION. He didn't produce quite as well as he did over the summer, though he did show off some offensive skills that made him intriguing in the first place. He is capable of barreling up the baseball, with an improved approach at the plate that saw him increase his walk rate considerably as a junior. That should enable him tap into his power more consistently, important for him to profile at an outfield corner. Because of his fringy speed and arm, PERSON is destined for left field, so the bat will have to play enough for him to be a regular.Even if his star faded a bit from summer to spring, PERSON is still very much on teams' radars. He could be a good fit for a team that puts weight on a Cape League performance in particular in the top six rounds.

GPE has a strong three-pitch mix. He sits in the 91-94 range, he has a sweeping, mid-80s slider, and his change has arm side movement. His delivery is atypical. It's low and long-armed, generating lots of relief projection despite the mix to start.

Acquired from GPE for catcher PERSON, PERSON was throwing very hard late in the year, sitting 96-99 during fall instructional league. His fastball has nasty natural cut action, especially when he's working to his glove side, and at times his upper-80s slider has bat-missing vertical action. It often does not, and he throws a lot of 40-grade sliders. PERSON dominated for years with a naturally cutting fastball. It's often said that adversity can be the best teacher. GPE enrolled in a master class during the first half of 2015 in Double-A. GPE lefty with a curveball. Up to 94.

He can add and subtract from his heater, sitting most comfortably in the low-90s. PERSON throws his slider across his body, and it serves as more of a chase pitch right now. He doesn't use his changeup that much, but it has good sink and has been effective against left-handed hitters at times. A former shortstop, PERSON fields his position very well and is extremely competitive on the mound.PERSON did return at the end of May to throw eight scoreless innings over two outings, giving him some late traction up draft boards. For now, the A's are having him work out at the team's complex in GPE as he continues to recover from the shoulder injury. So long as he remains healthy, PERSON could develop into a PERSON or PERSON Hellickson-like undersized right-handed starter in the big leagues.

PERSON hit 93 mph with his fastball as a freshman at GPE (Mo.) JC in 2012, but he went undrafted because he's small and was committed to GPE. After he proved himself as a reliever and a starter against tougher LOCATION competition, he signed for $150,000 as a 12th-rounder in 2014. He reached Double-A midway through 2016 and has established himself as one of the better lefty starting pitching prospects in a GPE system thin in that department.PERSON lacks a plus pitch, relying instead on mixing four offerings and deception to succeed. His fastball sits in the low 90s and peaks at 95 with some run on it. His changeup regressed a bit in 2016 but is solid once again, and his slider improved when he had to use it more often a year ago. He also uses a slow curveball to give batters a different look.His delivery isn't the smoothest and features some effort, though it also makes PERSON' pitches tougher to pick up and doesn't prevent him from throwing strikes. He doesn't miss a lot of bats and his velocity tails off in the later innings, so he might be better suited for middle relief than for the back of a rotation. He lacks the dynamic breaking ball to profile as a lefty specialist.

That the ORGANIZATION were unable to sign 2013 first-rounder PERSON is more and more looking like a blessing in disguise, as it gave the club the financial freedom to give ORGANIZATION an $850,000 bonus as a 30th-round pick. He has established himself as one of the best all-around hitters in the system in 2015 and made a smooth transition to Double-A last year, hitting a career-high 23 home runs and finishing second and third in the LOCATION in on-base percentage (.387) and slugging (.530), respectively.ORGANIZATION's robust raw power has been on display since his days at ORGANIZATION (Calif.) High, but it wasn't until 2015 that he began tapping into it in games with consistency. A physically strong left-handed hitter, ORGANIZATION possesses the requisite bat speed to turn on premium velocity as well as the barrel control to drive the ball out of the park the other way. A more consistent and confident approach resulted in vastly improved strikeout and walk rates in his first Double-A exposure, and he also showed more utility against same-side hurlers. Though a fringy defender at first base, ORGANIZATION has worked hard to upgrade his defense to where it should at least be serviceable. Meanwhile, ORGANIZATION officials rave about ORGANIZATION's work ethic and makeup, citing his determination to improve his body and defense as examples.While the emergence of All-Star first baseman PERSON doesn't bode well for ORGANIZATION cracking the ORGANIZATION' lineup anytime soon, it will provide him with as much time as needed to develop in the ORGANIZATION. The first-base-only profile is a notoriously difficult one to achieve, but he has the hitting ability and power to make it happen.

Once thought to be among the best in a very deep high school catching crop coming out of the GPE class of 2013, PERSON's up-and-down senior season resulted in a slide to the third round. He could end up being a steal for the ORGANIZATION, who went just over $200,000 above pick value to sign PERSON. He's shown glimpses of a complete package behind and at the plate. He has some definite pop and has the potential to hit for average and power. He has a plus arm behind the plate and while will have to continue to hone his craft, he should develop decent all-around receiving skills. If that part of his game continues to come, he has the chance to be an everyday catcher at the highest level.

PERSON was on the scouting radar very early as a prep underclassman who was old for his year but had tools, performed, and was a decorated swimmer. Instead of reclassifying and enter the 2015 draft as an 18-year-old, PERSON skipped his high school senior year completely and early-enrolled in January at ORGANIZATION. He wasn't on the radar for the top couple rounds, so scouts weren't sure he'd perform well, but PERSON went on to have one of the best freshman years in college baseball history: .369/.535/.700 with 18 homers, 62 walks, and 27 strikeouts. 
The pessimistic view is that PERSON is a player with old skills that peaked that season, as his stats regressed a bit from historic to merely among the best. The optimistic view is that PERSON has impact plus-plus raw power, a long track record of production and will fit as an everyday 1B/ORGANIZATION type. We're a bit on the pessimistic side, as PERSON is a 20 runner whose athleticism has backed up. He may only fit at ORGANIZATION now and we worried his swing was grooved enough that the hit tool may only be a 40, but with plenty of walks and power. The slippery slope to platoon ORGANIZATION is in sight, so we'd like to see some higher minors performance before we adjust our projections. 
His pro debut was strong and he'll likely spend this year at Hi- and/or Double-A at age 22, age-appropriate for prospects, which will show us where he is on the spectrum of expected performance from PERSON to ORGANIZATION, or maybe PERSON at the very high end.
Fuentes is a 3B/1B with plus power and some swing and miss issues, problems that will likely relegate him to bench/platoon duty in the big leagues.
PERSON popped up at the same event as PERSON late in the summer, with an even louder performance, but his swing has gotten a little stiffer and some scouts think he's a left fielder.

The hope, especially for the Phillies with the ORGANIZATION. 1 overall pick, was that PERSON would use his frontline rotation stuff and separate himself from the rest of the class, making him the slam-dunk choice for being taken 1-1. PERSON, which has plagued him for much of his career at GPE, not to mention some time on the shelf with back spasms, made PERSON more of a wild card than hoped.Big and strong, PERSON arguably has the best raw stuff of any arm in the class, with the chance to have three plus pitches. He's capable of touching 96-97 mph with his fastball regulary. Ironically, he might have been at his best in the one inning he threw before his back acted up, showing a 96-99 mph fastball and a plus slider at 88-90 mph. He can maintain his velocity deep into starts and while his changeup is his third pitch, it should be PERSON average in the future.PERSON's biggest stumbling block has been his control and command, something that has kept him from dominating college competition consistently. PERSON only missed one start with those back spasms and a huge start at the ORGANIZATION tournament cemented his place at, or near, the top of the GPE.

The ORGANIZATION area is known mostly in baseball circles for it being the Spring Training home of the GPE. PERSON, a rapidly rising right-hander from nearby PERSON, could help put that part of the east coast of GPE on the map for more than that.Known primarily as an outfielder for much of his high school career, the 6-foot-2 PERSON has taken off on the mound this spring. He's been seen up to 96-to-97 mph with his fastball at times, sitting comfortably in the 93-to-94 range. His breaking ball can be inconsistent; some scouts have seen two distinct pitches, others have seen them blurring into one slurvy offering. But he's shown enough glimpses of an above-average 78-to-83 mph breaker to think he'll get there consistently with more reps. He'll show a usable changeup in the bullpen, but doesn't throw it much in games.PERSON's athleticism should allow him to continue to throw strikes and repeat his delivery. He's still learning to pitch, and the GPE commit's upside potential could interest teams in the top two or three rounds.

The recipient of a $500,000 signing bonus in June 2013 after a decorated amateur career in GPE, PERSON has since blossomed into one of the top power-hitting shortstops in the Minors while making steady progress through GPE's system. He was a mid- and postseason All-Star with PERSON at age 20, built on that performance that offseason in the ORGANIZATION and then finished fourth in the LOCATION in home runs last season while garnering midseason All-Star honors in his first Double-A campaign.PERSON's knack for back-spinning the baseball to all fields using a quick, leveraged swing has long suggested that he would eventually tap into his above-average raw power. He did just that in 2017, hitting a career-high 24 home runs, up from 13 the previous year, to pace all Minor League shortstops, while also posting an extra-base hit rate of nearly 55 percent. PERSON's game will always feature some swing-and-miss, and he struck out at a career-high 26 percent clip in Double-A, but the overall approach is solid. He'll never be much of a basestealing threat despite possessing speed that's slightly above average.A shortstop exclusively since the start of 2014, PERSON has the athleticism and requisite tools to stay there. The presence of superstar PERSON in GPE means he won't, however, and PERSON is expected to see increased reps at other positions going forward. One possibility is a move to third base, where PERSON's strong arm and right-handed power would be clean fits.

PERSON is the top catcher in the 2019 class and one of the best prospects from GPE this year. For starters, he's a left-handed hitter with easy power and lots of upside offensively. He has a polished approach at the plate and has a chance to hit for average. What's more, PERSON has the potential to establish himself as a middle-of-the-lineup type of bat and as one of the best run-producing catchers on the international market in recent years.In the best-case scenario, he hits 25 home runs a year with a batting average near .280. On the other side of the ball, PERSON is a solid defender with a quick transfer and plus arm potential. His receiving skills are improving, and he already shows leadership skills. He will never be a threat as a runner, but he's smart and won't clog up the bases.Excluding the run tool, he is expected to be average or plus across the board as he grows and develops. PERSON is from GPE, but he has been training in the ORGANIZATION with PERSON, who is part of ORGANIZATION's PERSON. The Cubs are the favorites to sign the teen catcher.

PERSON struck out just 12 times as a college junior and had 25 more walks than strikeouts during his entire ORGANIZATION tenure. Pre-draft questions about his ability to hit for power in games have proven pertinent. But PERSON hits and he walks, so a relevant swing change, even one that sacrifices some contact, could lead to a breakout here. After some early-season statistical indicators that one might be occurring, PERSON's groundball rate has regressed to the mean. He's a speculative low-end regular at first base.
90-94, above-average curveball and slider, fringe change. When slider command is on, he's nails. When it's not, he looks like a 6th starter.

As a high school third baseman at ORGANIZATION in GPE, PERSON went undrafted. After three years at the ORGANIZATION of GPE, that won't happen again, as he was swinging a hot bat at the right time as the GPE approached.PERSON was making consistent, hard contact for the ORGANIZATION as his junior season progressed. He's always had raw power, but didn't always look like he could tap into it consistently. Lately, however, he's shortened his swing and begun to use the whole field more effectively, showing extra-base pop to the opposite field. Much of his success stems from a more open stance which has helped him get his hips through more consistently. He's a first baseman only with well below-average speed, though his hands and footwork at the corner infield position should be adequate. As a right-right first baseman, the bat is really going to have to play. Offensive college performers tend to do well in the GPE, and PERSON's raw natural power was giving him some helium as the spring progressed.

For the first time in 2018, the ORGANIZATION deployed scouts dedicated to the lowest levels of the minor leagues and it netted them one of the more explosive physical specimens on last year's desert backfields. Traded in a prospect-for-prospect deadline deal that sent one of the ORGANIZATION' many upper-level outfielders, PERSON, to GPE, PERSON dominated rookie ball on either side of the deal and slashed .321/.409/.525 combined in the ORGANIZATION and ORGANIZATION. PERSON like a Division I tight end, PERSON' body is a baseball rarity, and he still has growth potential from both a physical and mechanical perspective. PERSON doesn't always transfer his weight effectively and his swing can be bottom hand-heavy, but it has a workable foundation and he has the requisite bat speed, strength and hand-eye coordination to hit and hit for power. At maturity, he could be a 6-foot-5, 230 pound power-hitting force in the middle of a lineup.

For the past five Drafts, there has been a high school hitter from GPE taken in the top two rounds, two being the first-round ORGANIZATION brothers. FACILITY, a super-athletic and a bit raw outfielder from GPE of the GPE, may not go quite that early in June, but he is the best GPE prospect in this class by far.Most evaluations on FACILITY are projections for far off in the future, with interested teams knowing they will have to be patient. He does have solid contact skills from the right side of the plate and he should grow into some raw power. He needs to add strength and has trouble impacting the ball at times as a result, though some scouts point out that FACILITY was most heavily scouted while facing pro competition this spring. The ORGANIZATION A&M commit has close to top-of-the-scale speed, which makes him a threat on the basepaths and helps him cover a ton of ground in center field, where he should be a plus defender down the road. PERSON that love players with premium athleticism and a ton of ceiling are likely going to look at FACILITY in the first three or four rounds. It might take some time, but the payoff could be huge.

PERSON had more offensive upside than most of the high school catchers in the 2017 Draft, but the ORGANIZATION product resisted seven-figure overtures from big league clubs in order to stay home and attend ORGANIZATION. He still is known more for his bat, though he has gotten better behind the plate this spring after spending most of his freshman season at ORGANIZATION. Whether he'll be signable this time around as a sophomore-eligible remains to be seen.PERSON stands out as a lefty-hitting catcher with the ability to handle the bat. He regularly puts the barrel on the ball, uses the entire field and manages the strike zone well. He has more strength than bat speed and possesses solid raw power, though he's more concerned with making quality contact than swinging for the fences.If PERSON can continue to improve his defense, he has a chance to become a big league regular. He looks quicker and more agile than he did in high school, though his receiving skills are fringy and need more work. He has similar arm strength but his quick release helps him keep the running game in check.

A 40th-round pick of the ORGANIZATION in 2014, PERSON passed on launching his pro career in favor of attending PERSON. He made strides in each of his three seasons there and was one of the top performers in the LOCATION as a junior, showing improved hitting ability and power as well as second-base defense. PERSON's breakout campaign in college baseball's best league stood out in a thin crop of college hitters, and the ORGANIZATION were thrilled to find him still on the board in the third round. PERSON has a nice left-handed swing, shows good feel for the barrel and drives the ball across the entire field. After totaling six homers across his first two collegiate seasons, PERSON added some loft to his stroke and finally tapped into his raw power in 2017 to finish with 41 extra-base hits, including a team-high 15 home runs. An above-average runner, he moves well once underway but doesn't figure to be a stolen-base threat. Defensively, PERSON has looked comfortable at second base after previously struggling as a shortstop. He profiles as a passable defender there, one who can also play the outfield corners as well as first base. However, any future moves down the defensive spectrum will come with increased offensive demands.

A GPE native who stayed home to pitch out of the ORGANIZATION's bullpen, PERSON turned down the ORGANIZATION after being drafted in the 15th round a year ago to return to the ORGANIZATION for his senior year. The school's career saves leader put up video game numbers this spring, making the decision seem like a good one.PERSON dominated college hitters with two pitches delivered from a funky sidearm slot that adds deception to every delivery. His fastball is just about average velocity-wise, thrown 88-91 mph, but it plays up because it has plus plus life and he can throw it effectively to both sides of the plate. Right-handed hitters have no chance and when his slider is effective, he can get lefties out as well.If he can continue to show he can get hitters on both sides out, he has the ceiling of a setup man. If not, he could find a niche as a right-handed specialist.

GPE's top pitching prospect often has the two-way talent to pull double duty at the college level, as was the case with PERSON (2012), who blossomed into an Athletics second-rounder after three years at GPE, and PERSON (2017), who signed with the ORGANIZATION for $2 million as a second-rounder last June. It's true again this spring with PERSON, which may make him follow through on a commitment to GPE. He wants to play shortstop and pro teams clearly prefer him on the mound.PERSON throws harder than most high schoolers, hitting 96 mph while earning a save in the ORGANIZATION All-American Classic last August and pumping the second-quickest fastball (95.4 mph) at the World Wood Bat Assocation World Championship last October. Though horrible weather this spring delayed his senior season until mid-April, he regularly threw 92-95 once he took the mound. He generates his velocity with arm speed rather than effort and has some armside run on his heater. PERSON has decent feel for his curveball and changeup but both are works in progress because he has spent more time on his development as a position player. He threw a slider last summer, which some scouts preferred to his curve. He has the raw power, arm strength and athleticism to profile as a college third baseman but won't get the opportunity to hit if he does turn pro.

The ORGANIZATION gave $4 million bonuses to two high school outfielders with baseball bloodlines in the 2015 Draft, and PERSON massively outperformed PERSON in their first full pro seasons. A No. 5 overall pick and the younger brother of ORGANIZATION outfielder PERSON, PERSON batted .285/.360/.438 with 41 extra-base hits and 32 steals while advancing to high Class A. He has continued to rake in 2017, earning a promotion to Double-A by the end of May.Some scouts considered him the top hitter in the 2015 prep class, and he has done nothing to dispel that notion. A product of the same Plant High (PERSON, Fla.) program that spawned ORGANIZATION of ORGANIZATION, PERSON has a smooth left-handed swing, quick hands, advanced pitch recognition and a patient approach. He has good leverage in his swing and likes to pull the ball, so he should grow into at least 20-homer power as he gets stronger.A more well-rounded player than his brother, PERSON has spent most of his first two years as a pro in center field. He'll probably lose a step and become more of an average runner once he fills out, but he should fit nicely in right field with his solid arm and instincts. He runs the bases well, though he won't be a big threat to steal at higher levels.

Opinions very on PERSON based on how open minded scouts are about what a 16-year-old kid getting a premium bonus should look like. PERSON looks like he'll make a lot of contact and play shortstop, but with little to no power or physical projection and without elite footspeed, the upside is very limited. This type of player is getting more attention in recent years, as the same thing is happening in the draft and in the majors. If PERSON hits his upside, he's a potential low-end everyday shortstop, and he's a surer bet to do that than most in this class, but there's very little margin for error.

The ORGANIZATION may have gotten a steal by taking PERSON, the ORGANIZATION II Pitcher of the Year in 2014 out of ORGANIZATION in GPE, in the fifth round of that June's Draft.With his relatively short and stocky build, along with his power stuff, PERSON may be best suited to a bullpen role, but the ORGANIZATION think he has the chance to start. It begins with a fastball that sits in the 93-94 mph range, with the right-hander being able to reach back for more, touching as high as 97 mph. His hard slider gives him a second potential swing-and-miss pitch. His changeup is effective at times, with some splitter-like action, but it's inconsistent. PERSON and physical, PERSON does have some effort in his delivery, and his command needs improvement -- more reasons why some see a future in the bullpen.A move to the pen could speed PERSON's progress to the big leagues, but the ORGANIZATION will let him start for the time being to see just what they have.

Back in ORGANIZATION after three seasons in GPE, PERSON has a swing and miss fastball (just over 20% swinging strike rate in the minors) and viable slider and changeup. He's 31 and could decline at any moment, but he could be a good middle reliever in the short term.

Signed for $1.5 million in 2017, PERSON is a physical power/speed center field prospect who showed proclivity for pull-side lift as an amateur. PERSON like an M-80 at 5-foot-9, 210 pounds, PERSON lacks body-based power projection, but he already has some pop, and his frame is so compact that it'd be surprising if he thickened enough to necessitate a move out of center field. He had a pull-heavy, somewhat limited approach to contact as an amateur, but his first pro summer was free of statistical red flags. How his bat-to-ball skills and plate discipline develop will dictate his future role, and it's hard to have great feel for either of those variables. He's here largely because we like the defensive profile and raw power.

GPE does not miss many bats because he has limited fastball velocity, but he's a high-volume strike thrower with excellent secondary stuff, including one of the best curveball spin rates in the minors. He draws from a spacious bag of tricks to get hitters out, and has now had success at the upper levels of the minors with limited velo, so we're buying that he can make things work as a fifth starter.

The ace of a 2012 ORGANIZATION (Calif.) JC juggernaut that also included outfield prospects PERSON (now with the GPE) and PERSON (GPE), PERSON went in the fourth round of the 2012 Draft. He needed PERSON surgery midway through his first full pro season but returned last June and quickly regained his stuff. He missed the first two months of 2015 with a neck injury before returning in mid-June.PERSON's arm strength has been evident since he was a star quarterback in high school. He operates at 92-94 mph with his fastball, tops out at 96 and has heavy sink that elicits a lot of groundballs. His second option is a low-80s slider that's solid at times but flat at others.Refining his changeup will be crucial to PERSON remaining a starter, and he also needs better control. If he can't add enough polish, he could move to the bullpen and possibly turn into a set-up man.

2017 Lolo PERSON was a speedster with advanced bat-to-ball ability and defensive instincts. 2018 Lolo PERSON was a mechanical mess whose strikeout rate doubled. PERSON's hands began loading even lower than they had before, way down near the bottom of his abdomen, presumably to introduce more lift to his swing. Indeed, PERSON's ground ball percent dropped nine percentage points, but the changes compromised the quality of his contact in other ways, and made it hard for him to connect with pitches in some parts of the zone at all. His hands were stiff and loading late; they didn't seem as quick and twitchy as they had the previous year. These issues were exacerbated by PERSON's already pull-heavy approach. 
Take solace in the fact that he is only 19 and doesn't turn 20 until April, and that his assignment to full season ball in 2018 was very aggressive. He also remains fast and quite good in center field. He looked much more like a fourth outfielder in 2018 than a table-setting center fielder, but there's lots of time to bounce back.

One of two former ORGANIZATION (Calif.) supplemental first-rounders to make his big league debut in 2013 -- Mariners right-hander PERSON is the other -- PERSON joined the FACILITY in a December trade for PERSON.  PERSON's calling card in his above-average right-handed power, which he showed off by winning the home run derby at the Triple-A All-Star Game in July. That came on the heels of an ORGANIZATION performance at the ORGANIZATION. He can drive the ball out of the park to all fields and also shows the willingness to take a walk when pitchers won't challenge him.  PERSON has a long swing and a propensity for striking out, so he doesn't project to hit for a high average. He has a solid arm and has worked hard on his play at third base, though he'll probably be an average defender at best. While he has well below-average speed, he has decent instincts on the basepaths.
Has a low-90's sinker and sharp breaker. Has some surface-level projection, but was drafted at age 19 so we're not as bullish on the velo progressing.

There were high hopes for PERSON as he made the jump from PERSON Short-Season ball to the PERSON Advanced PERSON. But similarly to pitcher PERSON, that aggressive push was derailed by injuries.PERSON broke both hamate bones during the 2015 season, and when he was on the field, he never really got himself going, leading to what amounted to a lost year. The tools, however, are still there. He has the potential to be a solid hitter with average power from both sides of the plate. That should give PERSON the offensive profile desired from someone at a corner infield position. The jury is still out whether that will ultimately be third. He's a fringy defender right now, but the ORGANIZATION feel he'll be good enough to stay there, with a strong arm to help make up for other inefficiencies.Before his injury-riddled campaign, PERSON appeared headed toward the list of top third-base prospects in the game. Just 21 for nearly all of the 2016 season, there's more than enough time for him to hit the reset button.

PERSON was a left-hander with a fastball that topped out at 94 mph in high school, but the ORGANIZATION liked him more as a hitter and signed him for $800,000 as a sixth-rounder in 2011. He fractured his right kneecap in his first pro game and missed all of 2012 when it didn't heal properly, but he has made steady progress since. GPE lost him to the ORGANIZATION as the second overall pick in the Rule 5 Draft at the 2015 Winter Meetings, then got him back when he couldn't stick on PERSON's big league roster.PERSON doesn't have a plus tool, but he does have four that grade as average or better. He has hit for average at every Minor League stop, repeatedly barreling balls and using the entire field. He has some strength and the ORGANIZATION believe he's capable of double-digit home run totals, and he's starting to show that power this season after incorporating his legs more in his swing. With solid speed and average arm strength, PERSON is capable of playing all three outfield positions. After playing mostly center field earlier in his career, he has seen most of his time in left field this season. He earns praise for his constant hustle, but unless he starts hitting for more power, his ceiling will be as a fourth outfielder.

PERSON seemingly drew lots of trade interest while with PERSON. PERSON, lean, and wielding premium stuff, his name was rumored to be on some PTBNL lists before he was ultimately traded to GPE as part of the ORGANIZATION deal in 2018. During his first few pro seasons, PERSON's velocity yo-yo'd a bit; he was at times in the upper-90s, while more 91-95 at others. He was also demoted from the LOCATION back to the ORGANIZATION in 2017 for reasons seemingly unrelated to performance. The following spring, not only was PERSON's velocity more stable -- in the 93-96 range -- but he was throwing strikes and had more consistent secondary stuff. 
While he can spin a good breaking ball, PERSON's best secondary pitch is his changeup, which he sells with electric arm speed. He worked with better angle after the ORGANIZATION acquired him last summer, a change that improved the playability of his breaking ball without taking away from his changeup's movement. Now a physically mature, 230-pound 21-year-old, PERSON seems poised to take a bit of a leap and perhaps reach the ORGANIZATION State League later in the year. He may end up with three impact pitches if his secondaries have yet another gear of quality left to claim, which makes him a threat for the top 100 list either later this year or next.

A two-way college player, PERSON was a ninth round senior sign whose velocity spiked in pro ball when he focused on pitching, moved to the bullpen (he has since moved back into the rotation, after he was yo-yo'd back and forth in college), and was touched by the ORGANIZATION excellent player dev group. At times his fastball has been in the upper-90s, cresting 100, but it was in the low-90s this spring and he was placed on he injured list thereafter with an oblique issue. 
PERSON's four-pitch mix looks like it was designed in a lab and considering the way his stuff works together, it may have been. He's an extreme overhand, backspinning four-seam guy, and he works up at the letters with it. It's complemented by a deep-diving, 12-6 curveball. He'll also work a slider to his glove side and it has shocking, horizontal length considering PERSON's arm slot. But the headline offering here is the changeup, a split-action cambio that bottoms out as it reaches the plate. PERSON uses it against both left and right-handed hitters and it's one of the best changeups in the minors. It's a non-traditional style of pitching for a starter, so some eyeball scouts think he ends up in the bullpen. If so, it's probably in a valuable multi-inning role. Age and some relief risk just barely kept him off our top 100.

In 2008, PERSON became the first black LOCATION to sign a professional baseball contract. He has steadily progressed through the ORGANIZATION and developed into a prospect. PERSON is an excellent defender at shortstop with soft hands and a strong arm. His bat, however, is still a work in progress. PERSON has quick hands and a good approach at the plate, but still struck out 131 times at high Class A ORGANIZATION last year. He is a plus runner and is a threat on the base paths. PERSON's defense will allow the ORGANIZATION to be patient as he develops offensively.

PERSON began his post high-school career at ORGANIZATION State ORGANIZATION before transferring to GPE Tennessee State, following in the footsteps of his older brother PERSON. The starting shortstop for the ORGANIZATION, PERSON hit .369 over two years there, leading to the ORGANIZATION drafting him as a senior sign in the ninth round of the 2017 Draft. While he signed for just $1,000, the infielder has continued to hit as a pro as well, posting a .315 average in his first full season of pro ball in 2018.The 5-foot-10 PERSON continues to show a knack for making a lot of contact that has carried over to the 2019 season. He is capable of spraying line drives to all fields and while he doesn't walk a ton, he also rarely swings and misses, keeping his strikeout rate at or below 10 percent for his career, though that comes without any power. A shortstop only at GPE Tennessee State, PERSON played the premium position almost exclusively during his first year-plus in the ORGANIZATION system. He's added more second and third base to his resume, with the ability to play solid defense at all three spots, in 2019.At 24-years old for the 2019 season, PERSON is a little old for his level. But as a money-saving senior sign, he's in many ways way ahead of where expectations were. He'll have to prove himself at every level, but he could carve out a career as a steady utilityman who can hit for average at the highest level.
