Assuming his shoulder does bounce back, there's no reason to think PERSON can't get back to profiling well as a future right fielder. He is still just 22, with time to put it all together.

After a big full-season debut in 2012, PERSON looked poised to have an unforgettable '13 season. Instead, he had one he'd rather forget, then he had trouble bouncing back in 2014.The 2010 first-rounder really pressed in 2013, trying to right the ship in one at-bat. PERSON's swing mechanics got all out of whack as a result. His plus makeup has helped him continue his strong work at the hot corner, where he continued to be an above-average defender. Trying to wipe the slate clean, PERSON worked out with a number of big leaguers in GPE this past offseason, as he tried to tighten up what has been a long and sweepy left-handed swing.PERSON is still young enough to turn things around and re-emerge as one of the better third-base prospects in the game, but the clock is ticking.

PERSON's GPE debut in 2013 didn't look so good on paper, but he made some strides that have the ORGANIZATION hopeful he's headed in the right direction.Armed with a fastball that can touch the upper-90s, flashing a slider with good shape and late break, and even showing a feel for a changeup on occasion, PERSON has the stuff to get hitters out. His delivery, on the other hand, is another story. PERSON's herky-jerky mechanics had him a bit directionally challenged, but he's worked to stay under control, repeat his delivery and locate his pitches more consistently. He showed improvement in the instructional league last fall and then in GPE instructional league following that.It's possible PERSON will end up as a reliever, but the progress he's shown has some thinking he still has a chance to start, something he continued to do in 2014.

PERSON was a potential second-round pick last year as a sophomore-eligible at ORGANIZATION but went unpicked after a shoulder injury sidelined him for the entire season. He didn't require surgery and has bounced back so well this spring that he's a likely second-rounder and figures to be the first college choice from the state of GPE. The 2016 Conference USA pitcher of the year, he led Division I with 143 strikeouts in 106 innings entering the ORGANIZATION tournament.PERSON has regained his 91-96 mph fastball and maintains it deep into games. His heater is tough not only because of its velocity, but also because his extension in the front of his delivery makes it appear faster and it features run and sink. His power curveball can be a plus pitch when he stays on top of it but gets slurvy at times, and he has aptitude for throwing a sinking changeup.Though PERSON has an athletic, physical frame that should lend itself to starting, there are questions about his long-term durability because of his shoulder issues and the track record of top Owls pitching prospects getting hurt. His layoff didn't help his control and command, but he has a sound delivery and they should be at least average in the long run.

The ORGANIZATION drafted PERSON out of their own backyard, taking the Bahaman-born player, who was going to high school just north of PERSON, in the seventh round of the 2014 Draft. While he may have been perhaps the fastest player in the ORGANIZATION' system, his progress up the ladder had gone relatively slowly when he was sent to the ORGANIZATION last August in the ORGANIZATION trade.PERSON's carrying tool is his speed, which gets an 80 on the 20-to-80 scouting scale, and he can use it on both sides of the ball. He stole more than 40 bases in 2016 in his full-season debut, and there could be more to come as he learns the nuances of basestealing and improves his on-base skills. PERSON has a short, quick swing from both sides of the plate that can lead to contact, though his strikeout rate was high and walk rate low for someone who has the potential to be a table-setter. A shortstop in high school, PERSON played some center field during his pro debut back in 2014, but he worked on developing his infield skills the next two seasons with PERSON. The ORGANIZATION have moved him back to the outfield, giving him time in all three spots as prospect and organization truly get to know each other in 2017.

PERSON originally agreed to terms with the ORGANIZATION, but that contract was never approved as the deal was voided as part of the sanctions for PERSON's international indiscretions. PERSON hit the market anew and signed for $1.25 million with the ORGANIZATION. Last month, PERSON was found guilty of assaulting his former girlfriend in GPE in an incident that occurred on GPE's Eve 2017; it's unknown whether or not ORGANIZATION will suspend him now that the case has concluded. 
PERSON in the ORGANIZATION rim likened PERSON's skills to those of Hak-Ju PERSON, as PERSON was also a speedy, contact-oriented shortstop at this age. PERSON posts 60 and sometimes 70- grade run times from home to first and has advanced contact skills, with a swing familiar to many in GPE's ORGANIZATION. There isn't much strength or power to his offensive game. An interesting aspect of PERSON's development will be his transition from largely turf infields in GPE to grass and dirt in GPE. His arm appears to be below-average at times due to a quick-flip throwing motion. It was fine for first basemen in GPE to field balls on a clean hop of the turf, but it's not ideal for pro ball here in the ORGANIZATION. Most scouts think there's the ability to stick at short, it just isn't always evident to scouts without this context.
GPE hasn't developed the control typical of a starter, so while he does has a fairly deep repertoire, he projects in middle relief, where his fastball might tick up beyond where we have it projected.

PERSON hit .319 and .290 as a freshman and sophomore, respectively, and then grew into a grade of power in his junior year while maintaining his contact skills and taking advantage of pitchers' newfound hesitancy to attack him in the zone. None of his tools are especially loud, but PERSON does several things fairly well and he has a slight chance to play a passable center field. He's one of the more stable college bats in the second/third round range.

Since coming out of the junior college ranks in 2010, GPE hasnt really been able to get going. Injuries havent helped, as he missed most of the 2012 season following hip surgery. Some of the raw tools are there, particularly his speed, but he hasnt shown a consistent approach at the plate to get on base enough to use that speed. Hes willing to work counts and take a walk, but hes also struck out too much in the early stages of his career. More of a slap and run type, theres still hope he can develop into an average hitter who can play a good center field. Hes young enough, but he needs to stay on the field and start making adjustments.

A teenage leviathan, PERSON has present arm strength (he'll bump 96) and spins the occasional plus curveball. His arm slot creates movement on his fastball, which should pair well with his sinking change once it becomes more consistent. PERSON threw a lot of strikes last year and only walked three hitters in 42 innings. His body, even at 6-foot-7, is already maxed out and he may not grow into more velocity, but his secondary stuff and control are already fairly well in place. The fastball plane doesn't pair well with PERSON's breaking ball, but he otherwise has pretty safe starter traits.

PERSON began his post-high school career on the junior college circuit, at ORGANIZATION State College in GPE. He transferred to PERSON and pitched in relief as a junior, albeit not with good results. The ORGANIZATION liked his stuff enough to take a flier on him in the 30th round of the 2017 Draft. After being sent out as a reliever during his pro debut, PERSON got a chance to start and ran with it, pitching his way across three levels and finishing the year in Double-A.PERSON relies heavily on a fastball-splitter-changeup trio to get hitters out. He'll throw his fastball in the low-90s with occasional life. His split-finger changeup is his out pitch, and it's a good one, thrown in the low-80s with tumble that can miss bats and get weak contact. He mixes in a breaking ball as well and has shown the ability to throw strikes, with all three pitches coming from a quick and repeatable delivery.In all likelihood, PERSON ends up back in the bullpen, where his fastball-split combination could play up. His success as a starter has opened some eyes, and at the very least, he has shown he could be a multi-inning reliever.

Scouting Grades: Hit: 50 | Power: 40 | Run: 30 | Arm: 55 | Field: 50 | Overall: 45Taken a year ago by the ORGANIZATION as a Draft-eligible sophomore in the 30th round, PERSON returned to GPE for his junior year and has cemented himself as one of the more highly regarded college two-way players.As a left-handed starter, PERSON was terrific in GPE's weekend rotation this season, using a three-pitch mix well. He'll throw his fastball in the 90-92 mph range with some sink when he can keep it down in the zone. His slider will flash above-average, and he has the makings of a potentially Major League-average changeup. All of these pitches might play up if he focuses on the mound, but some teams also like him as an outfielder, one who might even have the athleticism to play center field. He has some legitimate raw power from the left side of the plate, as well.

GPE spent 2018 in the ORGANIZATION and should come stateside in 2019. Short but good-framed, he has plus hands, good infield footwork, and will probably grow into enough arm for the left side of the infield. His swing is a little long right now but he's athletic, wings harder than is typical for a teenager this size, and has plenty of time for mechanical tweaks. He's an interesting, long-term shortstop prospect.

ORGANIZATION Premier Event: Jan. 28, 2017 - PERSON, Fla.Favorite MLB Team: GPE ORGANIZATION MLB Player: PERSON right-handed pitcher PERSON has made 11 All-Tournament Teams since 2014, is labeled as a top 100 prospect and has been included on two Showcase Top Prospect Lists. PERSON participated in the 2015 ORGANIZATION and the 2016 ORGANIZATION, and earned a 2015 ORGANIZATION and was honored with a slot on the 2016 ORGANIZATION Team.The right-handed pitcher has good size and arm strength with a feel for his secondary pitches. His fastball hovers around 90-92 mph and his curveball sits at 76-77.

With a father and uncle who both played pro ball, PERSON has baseball in his ORGANIZATION. Until the spring of his redshirt junior season at ORGANIZATION, though, his performance didn't help attract scouts who might let him continue in the family business. But after going undrafted in 2016, his performance in 2017 landed him in the seventh round of that June's Draft. A solid pro debut in the short-season ORGANIZATION York-Penn PERSON allowed him to catapult to the Class A Advanced PERSON for his first full season.PERSON has always been athletic, with speed that can work on both sides of the ball. In his final season at ORGANIZATION, he started squaring up balls more consistently, resulting in extra-base pop, and he started to tap into his raw power for home run distance in his first full season. He can groove his swing at times, though he's managed to limit his swing and miss better, and he's willing to draw walks. His speed has worked for him well on the basepaths and he continues to work on the consistency of his reads and routes in the outfield.Long and lean, he's drawn some comparisons to a ORGANIZATION type of outfielder. He's played center field exclusively in 2018 and has the chance to stay there, but has shown the ability to play all three spots if a fourth-outfield kind of role makes more sense.

So young is PERSON that he had to wait almost two months after the July 2 signing day to turn 16 and become eligible to put pen to paper on his pro contract, which included a $1 million bonus. He's a typical, frame-based projection outfield prospect at a lean, high-waisted, broad-shouldered 6-foot-2. His upright swing is currently suited for high-ball contact but, based on the GPE propensity for enacting swing changes, that will likely change pretty quickly. As he grows into his body and better incorporates his lower half into his swing, he could have serious in-game power at maturity. Likely a long-term developmental project, PERSON may not be stateside for actual games until the 2020 AZL.

Like several Cubs prospects who were handed aggressive assignments for their age, PERSON struggled at Low-A and was eventually demoted. He performed after being sent back down to GPE (.250/.322/.458) but was still plagued by the plate discipline issues that were his undoing in the spring at GPE. PERSON has big power, and there's ceiling here if he can hit, though he'll need to be more selective if he's going to. He'll also have to develop on defense.

PERSON hit .402/.531/.819 as a sophomore and won the ORGANIZATION. A repeat performance as a junior would have made him one of, if not the greatest statistical performer in college history. After an early-season surge, PERSON started seeing a lot of breaking balls, about 15% fewer fastballs in PAC-12 play than he had during non-conference bouts. He was pitched around, and unable to make as much impact contact. But all the tools remain present. PERSON has a very selective approach, letting strikes he can't drive pass him by unless he has to protect. He has a very athletic swing despite being decidedly unathletic in every other way, enabling all fields power and high rates of contact. There's no margin for error for right-handed hitting first baseman, but if there's one prospect to be confident in hitting as much as is necessary to profile at first base, it's someone with this combination of visual evaluation and statistical track record. He's a longshot possibility at the first pick, but probably goes between three and five.

Developing high school catchers can be a slow business. The ORGANIZATION went above pick value to sign PERSON back in 2012 knowing just that. The backstop broke out with the bat when he led the ORGANIZATION State League in hitting and while he regressed offensively with the move to Double-A, he did make his big league debut in 2017.PERSON does have some tools to hit. He doesn't strike out much, though his strikeout rate did uptick in 2017, and he can make hard contact to all fields, but his overall strike zone control and decision-making at the plate hold him back. Some refinement would allow him to tap into his raw power, which will show up as plus at times, more consistently. PERSON's greatest strides have come behind the plate. He'll flash a plus arm and his release and accuracy have improved, allowing him to throw out 41.6 percent of would-be basestealers over the last three years. Pitchers in the ORGANIZATION loved throwing to him, with solid game-calling and receiving ability.PERSON may never be a great hitter for average, but he should be able to run into the ball occasionally. That, plus his strong catch and throw skills, all point to a long career in the big leagues. If the bat comes around, it could be as a regular.

PERSON was an intriguing two-way athlete on the showcase circuit, then hit 97 mph repeatedly early in his draft spring and moved into top two round contention. His stuff backed up a bit down the stretch. PERSON had not thrown as much as many of his peers and lacked their stamina, though this could be spun into a positive, namely PERSON's arm being relatively fresh. Late in the spring, he was working more in the low-90's rather than 93-96 mph, and his shorter stature and stride length led his fastball to be hittable. The Reds are gambling on the plus fastball returning as he builds strength, experience, and stamina in his arm in a starting role, and he has no. 3/4 starter potential with good, clear checkpoints to watch that will indicate improvement, including fastball rebound and maintaining his stuff into the summer.

As a sophomore, PERSON couldn't crack the ORGANIZATION varsity squad. Using that as motivation, he worked hard to get stronger and make the team as a junior, which led to him getting invited to several summer showcase circuit events. While he showed off a smooth left-handed swing at times, he also fell into the habit of trying to hit for power too much. This spring, a bout with mono slowed him, but also may have enabled him to get back to being a better all-around hitter.When at his best, PERSON shows the ability to barrel up the baseball consistently. When he first was returning from mono, he shortened up his swing and got to more pitches. He can drive the ball and there is going to be power to tap into as he fills out his 6-foot-3 frame, just so long as he doesn't get out of swing to get to it. An above-average athlete, PERSON runs decently for his size and has shown the ability to play both first base and a corner outfield spot capably, with left a likely home should a team want to try him out there.Players who can hit have the chance to get to their raw power. That's what teams considering signing PERSON away from his GPE Diego State commitment will be banking on in the hopes he can develop into a ORGANIZATION Freeman-type hitter.

GPE is considered one of the most powerful players on the international market. He's also one of the most intriguing.The teenager has been described as already having "a cannon for arm," and some scouts think he has the potential to have plus-plus power in the future. For now, he's a strong-bodied athlete with lots of offensive upside. He makes hard contact to all fields and has the potential to hit the middle of the order as a run-producer in future.GPE puts on a show during batting practice. He does, however, struggle with off-speed pitches and breaking balls, like most international prospects his age.He's improving as a defender and is expected to get better on defense once he receives daily instruction in a team's academy.GPE played in the ORGANIZATION in GPE, GPE, and is trained by ORGANIZATION. The ORGANIZATION are the favorite to sign him.

PERSON was the ORGANIZATION's most elegant defender. PERSON and smooth, sure-handed and graceful, he has room to add a few pounds as he ages while still remaining above-average at short. A torn labrum in 2015 cast doubt on PERSON's ability to stay there if his arm strength weren't to return but, though it took quite a while, it is not only back but has improved, and he now has a 70 arm. 
With such an excellent defensive foundation in place, it's very likely that PERSON becomes an everyday player. What happens with his bat will determine how much of an impact he makes, and that forecast is blurry. Right now, PERSON has surprising contact skills for someone as lanky as he is and he's adept at identifying balls and strikes. His size and currrent swing both have significant room for growth. PERSON's bat path enters the hitting zone in such a way that it causes him to pound the ball into the ground. If that gets tweaked, and he also adds strength into his mid-20s, he might suddenly start hitting for power. This is a rare, high-variance prospect who also has a high floor. If the power comes, PERSON will be an All Star; if it doesn't he'll just be a solid everyday player.

PERSON became the highest drafted pitcher out of PERSON when the ORGANIZATION took him 32nd overall in 2012. Less than a year later, he was pitching for PERSON in the World Baseball Classic and making his full-season debut in the ORGANIZATION as an 18-year-old.PERSON proved to be up to any challenge in 2013, showing the polish that attracted PERSON. He throws his fastball in the low-to-mid 90s, adding or subtracting velocity as needed. He mixes in a solid changeup and a hard curveball, which has the makings of an out pitch.PERSON has better command than most young pitchers and isn't afraid to come right after hitters. He shows a good feel for pitching, which will serve him well as he advances toward the ORGANIZATION.

PERSON was a known high school prospect in the GPE suburbs and, though a few teams nearly met it, his price tag pushed him to Tech where he's grown into one of this draft's top talents. He has elite feel for the position, projecting as an impact defender with a 65-grade arm despite being bigger than most good defensive ctachers. He also does advance work for every game, calls area scouts for gameplan input, and is possibly the only catcher at a major program that calls his own games. Scouts rave about his makeup.

Offensively, PERSON has huge power and has hit some tape measure shots, including a ball that went over the football facility roof in left field at ORGANIZATION and still hasnt been found. He isnt the most selective hitter and doesnt have the loosest swing in the class, but he has some feel for the bat head and doesnt have trouble with velocity. His power and fly-ball based approach along with these issues mean he could be a 40 or 45 bat with about an average walk rate and anywhere from 50 to 60 game power. Some of his strikeouts this year were a result of getting pitched around. He's seen a lot of off-speed pitches and has altered his approach to hit what he was facing, which likely wont be a big issue in pro ball.

Since PERSON is so advanced defensively, some scouts have speculated that hell go straight to High-A and could debut in the big leagues in late 2019. This could make him one of those prospects that gets to the big leagues before the holes to his offensive game have been closed because he's so good at everything else. The ORGANIZATION have been all over PERSON all spring and are expected to take him 2nd overall, but he's also a candidate to go 1st if PERSON's medical or bonus demands become problematic.

The ORGANIZATION landed PERSON at the outset of the 2014-15 international period, signing him for $1.6 million one day after they had inked phenom PERSON. The GPE right-hander flashed promise early in his career but also produced uneven results as he struggled to throw strikes. While he still has gains to make with regards to his control, PERSON's stuff has steadily ticked up each year as he's added strength and logged experience. It all started to click for him in 2018, as PERSON pitched his way up to the ORGANIZATION State League as part of a breakout campaign. PERSON's athleticism and quick arm help him generate easy velocity. He sits in the mid-90s with a lively fastball that he pairs with an above-average breaking ball. He misses bats with both pitches, while the crossfire in PERSON's delivery gives him natural deception and makes him especially tough on right-handed hitters. His changeup remains a work in progress, though PERSON has made strides in developing in the past year to the point where it's at least usable against left-handed hitters. His control, though still below-average, was markedly better last season as he trimmed his walk rate to 3.2 BB/9 from 4.8 in 2017. After wearing down physically early in his career, PERSON has worked hard to add strength and improve his durability. His efforts showed in 2018 in the form of 147 1/3 innings, nearly double his workload from the previous year. PERSON's all-around progress continues to give him life as a starter, though many scouts believe he's ticketed for the bullpen, where his fastball-curveball combo could play up in short bursts. PERSON could very well debut in that role in 2019 after the ORGANIZATION added him to their 40-man roster during the offseason.

The ORGANIZATION have taken a bat-first catcher with power in the fifth round each of the last two years. And much like PERSON the year before, PERSON was in the third round mix entering the spring but had a down junior year and slid a few rounds. A bounce back and defensive improvements are necessary parts of PERSON's future, but we like him as a fifth round, buy low flier.

One of the best all-around athletes in the class, certainly among college hitters, GPE has the chance to be a dynamic performer on both sides of the ball. Just how much teams think he'll hit at the next level will determine when he comes off the board.The switch-hitter has a tall, athletic build with the potential to do a lot of things well on the baseball field. A multisport standout in the ORGANIZATION high school ranks, GPE has plus speed that works on both sides of the ball. He should be a basestealing threat and can definitely stay in center field long-term. It's GPE's bat that needs the most work. He can make contact from both sides of the plate, but his setup and approach are inconsistent. GPE has strength, and he should grow into more, though his lack of extension from the left side could keep him from showing any power that way. A tendency to be tentative at the plate has plagued him, and while he had some good stretches, he didn't drive the ball consistently this spring.Refining of GPE's approach should help him reach his offensive ceiling. Even with the questions regarding his bat, he could go in the first round because of his tools, athleticism and lack of impact college hitters in the class.

It seemed like the runway was clear for ORGANIZATION to begin a pro career after graduating from FACILITY. But about a month before he walked, the ORGANIZATION of ORGANIZATION began once again requiring at least two years of active duty before graduates could apply to serve out their time in reserve status for the purpose of playing pro sports. Then baseball was reinstated as an Olympic sport, and ORGANIZATION found an avenue to pro ball through the World Class PERSON, a military unit focused on training for the Games in the two years leading up to competition. So ORGANIZATION, having sorted out some arcane rules about FACILITY personnel being unable to have second streams of income, is technically an FACILITY lieutenant training for the 2020 Olympics, while the ORGANIZATION pay for his development, but don't pay him.
ORGANIZATION was 89-94 throughout the 2018 Fall League, with his secondary stuff about average, flashing above (especially the change). He could be a fifth starter, but if his fastball ticks up in short relief, he'll fit in a mid-inning bullpen role. It's unclear what happens to ORGANIZATION and his military commitment after the 2020 games conclude.

GPE fall into one of three groups when evaluating PERSON. There are teams that think, despite his size and atypical throwing stroke, that he'll stay at shortstop and hit for some power. Those teams are highest on him. Then there are teams that think he'll just do one of those and, finally, those who think he'll do neither. His swing is geared for low ball contact, and he hits pitches near his shoetops to all fields, with power. But the swing's length and bat path creates doubt that PERSON will get to velocity up and/or in. Lefty-hitting shortstops with power are rare, and PERSON has a shot to be one, but he's riskier than is typical for a college bat who has two years of strong numbers.

A $250,000 11th rounder from a high school east of GPE, PERSON is a diminutive infielder with excellent secondary skills and sneaky power for his size. Though not especially rangy at shortstop, PERSON has plus hands and actions and enough arm strength to stay on the left side of the infield. A lack of power and physical projection makes him appear, on the surface, like he'll max out as a utility guy, but he makes up some offensive ground because his eye for the strike zone is so good. Instinctive and fundamentally sound, even if PERSON is only a utility type, his chances of getting there are high, and if his secondary skills hold water into the upper levels of the minors perhaps he'll be more than that.

PERSON' older brother, PERSON, was a 2014 fourth-round pick of the ORGANIZATION out of high school. PERSON opted to head to PERSON rather than sign in 2015 as a 22nd-round pick of the ORGANIZATION. He's been a three-year member of the ORGANIZATION' rotation and stepped into the Friday night role when PERSON went down with an injury, though he missed some time with biceps tendinitis.Assuming health, and PERSON was back on the mound in May, the right-hander has a solid three-pitch mix coming from a high three-quarter delivery and easy arm action. He'll throw his fastball in the 92-95 mph range with good sink. His 80-83 mph slider is inconsistent, but it has sharp break and he can land it for strikes when it's on. His changeup should be a third average offering, a solid offspeed pitch with good sink to it as well.PERSON doesn't miss a ton of bats, but goes right after hitters. He did pitch well on the Cape in brief performances for two summers, which certainly won't hurt his chances of getting drafted in the top five rounds.

Even though PERSON' frame hasn't filled out very much since he teenage days, his velocity has climbed. PERSON and spindly, the low-slot lefty now sports a fastball that sits in the low-to-mid 90s. PERSON uses his curveball to attack both left and right-handed hitters, and his lack of changeup development to this point is the chief reason why he may project to the bullpen, where he may throw even harder and turn into something resembling PERSON. We like lanky, athletic pitchers with feel for spin. Though there are clear things to work on, PERSON is one of those. He should spend 2019 at Hi-A.

A two-sport star in high school who turned down the chance to play quarterback at ORGANIZATION, PERSON has the chance to be a solid outfielder at the highest level.The former football star will need some time to find himself as a baseball-only athlete, but PERSON showed glimpses of loosening up at the plate and started to stay through the ball more consistently while spending a month at the ORGANIZATION' PERSON. If he can continue to do that, he'll be able to start tapping into his raw power from the left side more consistently. PERSON runs well enough, but he will likely settle into a corner spot in the future.PERSON, who is not related to GPE manager PERSON, brings a football mentality to the diamond, and his makeup and work ethic should allow him to maximize his ability as he develops.

Acquired from GPE for PERSON, PERSON has basically lost the last two years to poor arm health. He had intermittent injury issues throughout 2017 -- flexor mass discomfort, a lat strain, elbow tendinitis -- and needed PERSON during 2018 Spring Training. He's been throwing bullpens and is on track to return sometime in the middle of 2019. It's unclear if the drop in velocity PERSON exhibited betwixt his DL stints was due to injury or if that's just how hard he throws now. At his prospect peak in GPE, when PERSON struck out no fewer than 32% of opposing hitters over a three-season stretch, he was sitting 92-94, and touching 96. Though there's less stigma surrounding drop-and-drive deliveries now, there was concern about PERSON's fastball being liftable even at that velocity due to it's plane. At his more recent 89-91, it's more worrisome. But if the velocity comes back, PERSON will have two plus pitches in his fastball and a goofy changeup, which has weird, horizontal action. He throws a ton of strikes and has two viable breaking balls. He could be a No. 3 or 4 starter if everything comes back, but is more like a No. 5 if it doesn't.

If things had gone differently for the son of former big leaguer PERSON, he might be hearing his name in conversations at the very top of the GPE. But after just three starts in his sophomore year, the ORGANIZATION right-hander was shut down with an elbow injury that required PERSON surgery. PERSON were hoping he would return to the mound this spring, but it didn't happen, though PERSON did work out for a number of teams leading up to the GPE.PERSON is one of the biggest first-round wild cards. When healthy, the Canadian-born standout has an outstanding four-pitch mix, with a chance for all of them to be at least PERSON average. PERSON will throw his fastball in the low-to-mid 90s, and he can locate it well. He has both a curve and slider, with the former ahead of the latter, and his changeup has good fade and sink. He has an outstanding feel for pitching and a plus mound presence.Given how teams haven't shied away from ORGANIZATION surgery recipients of late, PERSON could still hear his name called fairly early on Day 1 of the GPE, especially if he impressed in those workouts.

Because he needed to add strength to his very projectable frame, the ORGANIZATION handled PERSON with care after signing him for $1.1 million as a second-rounder in 2014. He didn't work more than five innings in a game until August of his first full pro season. When they turned him loose last year, he led the Class A Advanced California League in innings (167 2/3) and strikeouts (142).PERSON's fastball added velocity in 2016 and now sits at 92-95 mph and reaches 97 with armside run and heavy sink that should work well at ORGANIZATION and still has some projection remaining. Both his slider and changeup have the potential to become plus pitches. He can throw his low-80s slider for strikes or back-foot it against left-handers, and he does a nice job of maintaining his arm slot and speed on his fading changeup.Multiple club officials compare his mechanics to PERSON's -- which isn't the smoothest -- and PERSON makes it work with his fast arm. He repeats his delivery well, fills the strike zone and likes to challenge hitters. He's on course to reach the big leagues at age 22 and eventually become a No. 3 starter.

PERSON had a seven-figure asking price coming out of high school, which was just out of reach of what clubs were willing to commit from their spending pools. He was set to head to PERSON until a late coaching change caused him to reconsider his commitment, and the ORGANIZATION ultimately lost him to GPE (and PERSON to PERSON). PERSON's velocity ticked up before he even played in an official game for the GPE, sitting 93-95 and hitting 97 mph in preseason scrimmages before his freshman year. He kept that velocity throughout his college career and developed a plus changeup. 
The two issues for PERSON are his very short stride, which causes his velocity to play down, and his breaking ball, which is not great. It's still most often a below average pitch, with curveball velocity and three-quarters slider shape. Cogent pitch design may help the pitch, or indicate the ORGANIZATION should just scrap it altogether and try something like a cutter or slider. These issues are almost identical to PERSON's coming out of PERSON; he's appeared to have solved those at times, though not at others.

In his bio on the ORGANIZATION State website, PERSON lists former GPE infielder PERSON as his favorite athlete. As a three-year starter at ORGANIZATION who has the chance to stay up the middle, seeing PERSON follow a PERSON-like career path isn't out of the question.PERSON is a fairly athletic middle infielder who has performed well at a major college program, all things that should serve him well in the GPE. Some feel he'll hit enough to be an everyday player, with a worst-case scenario being a future as a super-utility type, one who has already shown the ability to play the outfield. With good footwork and a decent arm, it would pay to send him out as a shortstop and let him show if he can't stay there. PERSON is lumped in with other college performer middle infield types, with his left-handedness at the plate something that sets him apart. PERSON was taken in the fourth round of the 2007 GPE; PERSON could hear his name called by then as well.

GPE was a pleasant, toolsy, post-draft surprise whose combination of speed and crude bat control was too much for ORGANIZATION defenses to deal with. A ORGANIZATION draftee would only turned 20 in September, GPE has some catalytic offensive qualities and a chance to play somewhere favorable on defense. He saw time at shortstop and third base during the summer and fall, but PERSON and several scouts think he ends up in center field. PERSON development will play a sizeable role in GPE's future, especially as far as his bat is concerned. He will be the age of a college sophomore in 2019.

Manning was a two-sport high schooler who could have gone to PERSON to play hoops. He was behind, developmentally, when he was drafted but is starting to take off now that his fastball and rainbow curveball have been tightened. He's a high risk arm due to his present command, but huge athletes like this take a little while to gain full control of their limbs so there's a good chance that's going to come, eventually.

After hitting just two home runs as a ORGANIZATION sophomore, PERSON smacked 18 as a junior to rank fourth in ORGANIZATION Division I in 2015. His power surge got him drafted in the sixth round and has continued in pro ball, as he delivered four multi-homer games in a 16-day span shortly after his promotion to high Class A midway through his first full season.If PERSON makes it to the big leagues, his left-handed pop will be what gets him there. He generates power to all fields, albeit more with strength and loft than bat speed, and some scouts wonder how it will play against better pitching at upper levels. His long swing and aggressive approach are not conducive to posting high batting averages or on-base percentages.Mostly a first baseman as a ORGANIZATION junior, PERSON played all over the infield and has gotten the majority of his pro action at third base. He has the arm strength for the hot corner, but he lacks quickness and range and has been error-prone early in his pro career. He likely will become a full-time first baseman in the future.

PERSON was markedly better after the ORGANIZATION acquired him from GSP for PERSON ahead of the deadline. In seven starts with PERSON, PERSON halved his walk rate (his strike % was up six percentage points), flashed a better changeup than he had earlier in the year, and turned in his best performance of the season, striking out 10 former Reading teammates on August 3rd. After things had plateaued for so long with PERSON, he seemed to be improving. Then he broke, and at an unfortunate time. PERSON in late October means PERSON, who's already relatively raw for a prospect his age, may not throw another professional pitch until mid-2020, when he's 25. We think this makes it significantly more likely that PERSON ends up in relief and while we think he could be a dominant three-pitch reliever, it has also delayed his timeline to the big leagues by perhaps two years, putting him in line to debut near the same time as similar talents who just wrapped a season in A-ball.

GPE, like PERSON, created quite a buzz in the ORGANIZATION during his GPE debut in 2015 with his triple-digit fastball and dominant outings. He threw well with a jump to full-season ball in 2016, but struggled when he was bumped up to the ORGANIZATION State League. A return to that level in 2017 was much better for the right-hander.GPE was 19 for all of the '16 season and he is still learning how to pitch with his high-octane stuff. At the lower levels, he could get away with just blowing it by hitters, but as he starts to get challenged more to make pitches, he'll have to set up his pitches better and have a plan of attack. He has the weapons to do so. His fastball touches 99-100 mph at times, but his slider -- which eventually should be an average breaking ball -- isn't currently good enough to keep guys off of his fastball, and he got hit more than he should. His changeup is currently his best secondary offering.GPE has much to work on in terms of his command, getting ahead in the count early and his overall pitchability, but he'll also be just 20 for all of the 2017 season, with more than enough time to figure things out.

Heading into the 2012 Draft, PERSON drew plenty of interest coming out of the LOCATION high school ranks. The ORGANIZATION took a shot in the 14th round and were able to sign him away from his ORGANIZATION State commitment with a well-above-slot bonus. PERSON surgery in 2014 derailed PERSON temporarily, but if his performance in '15 is any indication, the ORGANIZATION could get a solid return on their investment.PERSON's repertoire registers as average across the board, but he has a good idea of what he's doing with his three-pitch mix. He'll sit in the 90-91 mph range and can occasionally reach back for a little more, throwing his fastball with some decent movement. PERSON can spin a breaking ball -- a mid-70s curve -- and has a feel for a changeup, with both pitches having the chance to be PERSON average. He can throw strikes with all three, and while overall command has been a concern, he filled up the zone when he hit full-season Savannah in 2015.PERSON has limited ceiling, but even with the time missed, he's still very young. With his feel for pitching, he has a chance to be a back-end starting pitcher when all is said and done.

An elbow injury that forced him out of action at GPE in 2012 may have worked in the FACILITY's favor, as they feel they may have gotten a very good steal in PERSON. An athletic second baseman, PERSON tore up the LOCATION League and was named the All-Star Game MVP before being moved up a level during his first full season. He has been a hitting, on base, and stolen base machine during his pro career, using his plus speed to wreak havoc on the basepaths. It helps him have decent range at second as well, though the rest of his defensive game is a bit of a work in progress. His bat and his legs, though, could get him to the big leagues fairly quickly.Bernie PERSON's scouting report

The ORGANIZATION made PERSON the second catcher selected in the 2013 Draft, taking him with the 21st overall pick. He stood out most for his offensive potential as an amateur, but his bat has come along slowly as a professional and now lags behind his defense. After two seasons in GPE ball, PERSON made his full-season debut at ORGANIZATION A Bowling Green in 2015. He began the 2016 season at ORGANIZATION A Advanced Charlotte and was in the midst of a breakout offensive campaign when a hand injury sent him to the disabled list in early June.Behind the plate, PERSON has made strides with his blocking and receiving. His above-average arm strength is his best defensive tool, and it helped him throw out 41 percent of would-be basestealers in the ORGANIZATION in 2015. Meanwhile, club officials praise his leadership qualities and feel for handling a staff.Offensively, PERSON employs an up-the-middle approach, and he produces good bat speed from the left side of the plate. That, plus his size and strength, give him a good chance to develop more power, though he's hit just a handful of home runs across his first four seasons. If he is to reach his offensive potential, he'll need to do a better job controlling the strike zone and trim some of the swing-and-miss from his game.

PERSON was a projection prep arm from GPE whose price was just high enough to get him to GPE. He had a big freshman year there and then had a national coming-out party as the ace of ORGANIZATION USA that summer. PERSON continued at about that level for the next two seasons, slinging in a heavy, 91-96 mph sinker from a low slot with a deceptive, crossfire delivery. He threw strikes and had a plus slider. Scouts who weren't as enthusiastic about PERSON's changeup, or arm slot, or the length of his arm action saw a reliever. His stuff would flatten out and his command would back up as he fatigued into the late stages of some starts. The ORGANIZATION had PERSON change his delivery and arm action for the first half-dozen or so starts in 2018, focusing on a more traditional four-seam fastball approach. It didn't work, and GPE let PERSON go back to what he had been doing later in the year, and his dominant final two months of 2018 reflect his comfort with this approach. We think the likely outcome here is a multi-inning power reliever who dominates righties with strikeouts and groundballs, though some see a starter in the mold of PERSON. Either way, PERSON should move quickly, especially if he's only asked to face a lineup once or twice per outing.

Only six Wisconsin high schoolers were selected in the top two rounds of the first 51 Drafts, but the ORGANIZATION State may have two this year in shortstop PERSON and GPE. The latter is the best offensive catcher in the 2016 prep ranks and could be the first high school backstop picked in June.GPE has a smooth left-handed swing that generates a lot of bat speed. He's strong and barrels a lot of balls, producing power without swinging for the fences. He has the upside of a .270 hitter with 20 homers per season, though the demands of catching may knock those numbers down.GPE has work to do behind the plate, though he has the tools to make it at catcher and scouts believe he'll figure it out. The ORGANIZATION recruit has solid arm strength and makes accurate throws. He sets a good target and moves well behind the plate, though his receiving and blocking skills will have to improve.

PERSON has extensive athletic bloodlines, though he's the first member of his family to go the baseball route. His father PERSON was the ORGANIZATION. 1 overall pick in the 1978 ORGANIZATION draft, and his brother PERSON is a superstar with the ORGANIZATION State Warriors. Another brother, GPE, had a brief ORGANIZATION stint in 2012. It's easy to dream on PERSON's size and athleticism, but he has yet to take a significant step forward in seven pro seasons. His bat speed and long levers give him plenty of raw power, and he has the patience to work counts and look for a pitch he can drive. But he alternately gets pull-conscious and passive at the plate, and he swings and misses too much, averaging a strikeout every 3.85 plate appearances in his ORGANIZATION career. In the 2015 offseason, PERSON was traded to the ORGANIZATION -- along with PERSON and PERSON -- in the three-team deal that yielded the FACILITY from GPE. PERSON has solid speed and uses it well on the bases and in the outfield. An average center fielder with an average arm, he's capable of playing all three outfield positions. If everything comes together, he could be a 20-20 center fielder, but it's starting to look like he might not be more than a fourth outfielder at best.

The Friday night starter for the ORGANIZATION of GPE as a sophomore and junior, PERSON helped lead the Cavaliers to their first ORGANIZATION title in his first year in that role, then followed it up with a strong junior campaign. Seen as a rather safe college performer who was more high floor than high ceiling, he lasted until the end of the second round, where the ORGANIZATION gave him an above-pick value bonus of $1.1 million.PERSON features a heavy fastball up to 93-94 mph, sitting more in the 90-92 mph range. It's more about the plus sink than the velocity and the right-hander gets a ton of groundball outs. He'll throw two breaking balls -- a curve he uses to get strike one and a better slider with good, late bite that often serves as his out pitch. He can mix in a solid changeup with good movement.Starting pitchers from GPE haven't fared well in the pro game, but PERSON seems a good bet to reach his ceiling, even if it's not as high as some others. After a heavy workload this spring, he'll be used sparingly this summer, really getting his pro career started in earnest in 2017.

PERSON didn't sign as a 2nd rounder last year for unclear reasons and has had an up-and-down senior year, but his stuff was a little better down the stretch, likely allowing PERSON to go in the 2nd round again but now with less leverage and at nearly 23 years old.

PERSON had the offensive ability to go in the top 10 rounds of the 2014 Draft, but he fell to the 26th round because teams worried about his signability. He decided to prove his worth in the ORGANIZATION and posted a .971 ORGANIZATION (which would have led the league if he had enough plate appearances to qualify) in the first half before the ORGANIZATION signed him for $150,000. He hit his way to Double-A in his first full pro season while also seeing his first extensive action at second base.PERSON has the bat speed and strength to produce for both average and power. To do so, he'll need to guard against his right-handed swing becoming too long and improve his strike-zone discipline and his ability to handle quality breaking pitches. He tends to hit the ball up the middle and to right-center, and the ORGANIZATION would like to see him pull more pitches so he can turn his plus raw power into more home runs.An outfielder in his first two years at ORGANIZATION and a third baseman as a junior, PERSON began 2015 playing second base full-time in low Class A and continued to work there in high Class A. He only played right field in Double-A and while he could fill in as an infielder if he gets to the big leagues, he's going to be more of a corner outfielder than a super-utilityman. He has the arm to play a variety of positions but lacks quickness and smooth infield actions, so PERSON has had him continue to focus on right field in 2016.

PERSON went three picks after PERSON, and both spent 2012, their first full seasons, in the ORGANIZATION State League. While PERSON turned in a decent debut season, PERSON struggled for most of the year and returned to PERSON in 2013. He pitched better, but a shoulder season ended his season early. PERSON's fastball touched the mid-90s, with good arm-side movement at ORGANIZATION, but his velocity has been down a tick in the ORGANIZATION. His changeup is the better of his two secondary pitches and could be above average in time. His breaking ball was inconsistent, and he had trouble commanding it. ORGANIZATION and control have been PERSON's biggest issues as a professional. If he can refine that, there's no reason why he can't be one of the better left-handed prospects in the game.

GPE is one of the older players in the prep class, but showed an athletic, projectable frame with above average raw power back when he was an underclassman and is more signable than the average Stanford recruit

PERSON looked like an elite international prospect when he dominated the 18-and-under World Championships in September 2012, but his stuff and delivery regressed significantly by the time he pitched for GPE as an 18-year-old in the World Baseball Classic the following spring. Undaunted, GPE signed PERSON for $1.625 million last July.The early returns on that investment have the ORGANIZATION optimistic that they could have a future No. 3 starter on their hands. PERSON was so impressive in Spring Training this year that GPE sent him to Class A for his pro debut, and he got off to a terrific start at ORGANIZATION County.PERSON's stuff has bounced back to where he's pitching with a consistent 90-95 mph fastball. He also can get swings and misses with his curveball. PERSON has advanced feel for his changeup and for finding the strike zone with all three of his offerings.

PERSON is a bowling ball-shaped left fielder that hits from an extreme crouch and has just enough power (55) to profile, but he's hit everywhere he's been and always had a good sense of the strike zone, which endears him to analytically-driven teams.

One look at PERSON, a 6-foot-6 right-hander, and you think "durable starting pitcher." His inconsistencies on the mound, however, make some wonder if that's ultimately his best role, though he did make his big league debut as a starter in 2015.PERSON did shake off a slow start in his first taste of Triple-A in 2014 to finish the season well, but it left some question marks. PERSON's fastball has enough velocity, sitting in the low 90s and touching more than that at times. He throws it with good downward angle and sink when he's on, though he's up in the zone more than he should be. His changeup is his best secondary offering, with his slider coming in a close third. Both have the chance to be PERSON average, but again, he struggles to throw them consistently well. PERSON doesn't hurt himself with walks, but his command within the strike zone has hurt him. He'll continue to get work as a starter, but his fastball might play better in short relief, long-term.

PERSON was a buzzy prospect in high school, coveted for his rare power/spede combo and overall athleticism, becoming more intriguing due to his limited baseball reps as he pursued a football career at ORGANIZATION and LOCATION. The ORGANIZATION signed him out of high school to own his rights if football didn't work out and were happy when he hit the ground running in 2015 as a full-time baseball player at age 20 in full season ball with a surprising amount of polish, especially for pitch selection, for a kid who had never fully committed himself to baseball before. The tools are still flashy and profile as an well-rounded everyday center fielder that likely gets an extended big league look at some point in 2018.

PERSON started his professional career quickly, reaching Double-A Binghamton in his first full season. His ceiling is somewhat limited, but his advanced feel for pitching and three-pitch arsenal make him a solid prospect.PERSON throws his fastball in the low-90s, with good movement. He throws a splitter in lieu of a changeup, and his slider has good late break to it. PERSON will need to be a little more consistent with his secondary stuff, but both pitches have the potential to be average offerings.PERSON missed the first few months of the 2014 season due to a right lat strain, but he quickly got back up to speed once he returned to action. Though GPE still sees him as a starter, his power stuff would play up in the bullpen. PERSON is nearly ready for a chance to contribute in either role in the ORGANIZATION.

PERSON appeared in six games for ORGANIZATION (N.Y) as a freshman before transferring to GPE Stroudsburg University (Pa.), where he showed steady improvement as a starter over the next three years en route to becoming PERSON's seventh-round pick as a senior in 2016. A full-time move to the bullpen led to a breakout first full season for PERSON, as he showed impressive bat-missing ability, garnered All-Star honors in the Class A Advanced GPE League, and then capped his season with a successful turn in the ORGANIZATION. And while he began 2018 in extended spring training due to a hip/sciatic issue, PERSON quickly made up for the lost time in Double-A upon returning and earned his first big league promotion in July. PERSON's smooth delivery and short, clean arm action create late life on a fastball that will sit 92-95 mph while touching 96. He pairs his heater with a sharp, late-breaking slider in the mid- to upper-80s, and it's those two offerings that enabled him to pace all GPE League relievers with 13.1 strikeouts-per-nine innings. The right-hander also has a curveball and changeup, both slightly below-average pitches, at his disposal, and his entire arsenal does play up on account of his solid control and command.PERSON's four-pitch mix and overall durability makes him a candidate to one day rejoin a starting rotation, should the ORGANIZATION ever choose to pursue that route. For now, however, it's PERSON's knack for missing bats using largely his fastball-slider combo that is his ticket to a potential late-inning role in the ORGANIZATION.

The son of former big league player and manager PERSON, L.J. PERSON was a senior sign out of UConn who received a bonus more than $140,000 under the pick value of where he was taken. He's proven to be an even bigger bargain than anticipated, hitting his way through two levels of A ball before double-jumping to help out Triple-A Las Vegas in the playoffs, though he missed the start of the 2015 season due to a 50-game "drug of abuse" suspension. PERSON's best tool is his bat, a right-handed hitter with an advanced approach at the plate and solid on-base skills. While he's never going to be a huge home run hitter, he does have some extra-base ability. He doesn't seem to fear facing better pitching, and his bat got going further into the 2015 season. There were concerns about PERSON's defense, but he's improved at second base and the ORGANIZATION think he can stay there. An average runner, he might also be athletic enough to move to the outfield if needed. For now, PERSON will work on putting the suspension behind him and trying to prove he can develop into a decent offensive-minded second baseman.

The ORGANIZATION may have a reputation for developing young power arms and getting them to the big leagues. Their 2015 postseason run was fueled on them. PERSON, with his command rather than stuff approach, could give the staff an interesting change of pace.PERSON features a really good sinking fastball, one that touches 94 mph and sits in the 91-92 mph range. It's not an elite-level sinker, but the right-hander does elicit a fair share of ground-ball outs, throwing it downhill from his 6-foot-4 frame. Typically, sinkerballers use a slider as a breaking ball, but PERSON mixes in an average curveball he spins fairly well. His changeup is his best secondary offering, an average, if not better, offspeed pitch. PERSON throws strikes with all three and commands them well within the zone.PERSON made it to Double-A in 2015, finishing fifth in the organization in ORGANIZATION. His feel for pitching and ability to limit damage should allow him to reach his potential as a back-of-the-rotation starter. PERSON has shown some uptick in his velocity, and there's still some projection to his frame, so it's not out of the question there is a little more to unlock here.

GPE was just a name on a list of guys to monitor this spring unti March when the scouting community sat up and recognized the insane statistical season he was putting up. After putting up an .803 OPS in his draft-eligible sophomore year (he went in the 35th round and didn't sign), he put up a 1.276 OPS in his junior year, with 23 homers and a 38/30 BB/K ratio. While he's 6-foot-4, 200 pounds and a late-bloomer, he projects to be an average defender with an average arm at shortstop and has the bat speed to project continued performance at higher levels. There's a posture issue to fix in his swing, but clubs will be wary of trying to change too much while everything is going well.

A relief-only prospect with plus velocity and a funky delivery. PERSON is built like a pterodactyl and his funky delivery makes hitters uncomfortable. His fastball has life at the top of the strike zone. Could be PERSON Guerrero-ish late bloomer, so will probably be a 35+ FV for a while.

PERSON led all national high school players with 16 homers as a senior in 2016 -- finishing one ahead of PERSON, who signed with the ORGANIZATION for $2.5 million as a pitcher. He went undrafted because he was strongly committed to ORGANIZATION and lacked an obvious position. Three years later scouts still aren't sure where he fits best, but he's a switch-hitter who has hit for power in the LOCATION and draws some "poor man's PERSON" comparisons.PERSON generates impressive raw pop with a combination of bat speed, strength and loft in his swing. He has improved his plate discipline and contact rate throughout his college career and has a chance to hit for average as well. Though he has below-average speed, he's aggressive on the bases and has good feel for picking spots to steal.PERSON has played mostly left field at ORGANIZATION, showing at least average arm strength but limited range. The hope is that he can become an adequate defender in left, but he could wind up at first base or DH. He was a catcher in high school and has seen brief action behind the plate for the GPE, though the consensus is that he doesn't receive well enough to do so in pro ball.
